[[File:Tyra Kleen - from Svenskt Porträttgalleri XX.png|alt=Portrait of Tyra Kleen ca 1900, photographer unknown|thumb|Portrait of Tyra Kleen ca 1900, photographer unknown]]
'''Tyra Kleen''' (29 June 1874 - 17 September 1951) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] artist, author and women's rights activist.<ref>Sveriges Dödbok 1901–2009, DVD-ROM, Version 5.00, Sveriges Släktforskarförbund (2010).</ref> Her paintings, illustrations, lithographs and publications were important to the Swedish fin de siècle art movement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thielskagalleriet.se/en/utstallning/tyra-kleen-1874-1951-artist-vagabond-adventurer/|title=Tyra Kleen (1874–1951). Artist, vagabond, adventuress|website=The Thiel Gallery|language=en|access-date=2020-02-13}}</ref> But above all she was an independent ethnographical researcher.

== Biography ==
===Childhood and education===
Tyra Kleen was born in Sweden to Swedish diplomat and author [[Fredrik Herman Rikard Kleen]] (1841–1923) and Maria Charlotte Amalia née Wattrang (1842–1929). She had two siblings; an older brother [[Nils Rikardsson af Kleen]] (1872–1965) and  sister [[Ingeborg Kleen]] (1870–1911). Due to the frequent absence of the parents, the children were primarily educated by their grandfather, marshall [[Nils Adolf Wattrang]], who died in 1890 when Kleen was 16 years old. 

Kleen studied painting in [[Karlsruhe]] between 1892 and 1893, at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Munich|Academy of Fine Arts Munich]] 1894 and then at [[Académie Delécluse|Académie Delecluse]], [[Académie Colarossi]], [[Académie Julian]] and [[Académie Vitti]] between 1895 and 1897.<ref name=\Månsson 2018\">{{Cite web|url=https://tidningenkulturen.se/arkiv/92-konst/konst-portratt/15784-tyra-kleen-en-konstnaerlig-kosmopolit|title=Tyra Kleen – en konstnärlig kosmopolit - Tidningen Kulturen|last=Månsson|first=Lena|website=tidningenkulturen.se|language=sv-se|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> She devoted her work mainly to drawing

column1: From her diaries and letters it is clear that Kleen was a colourful and exciting androgynous<ref name=\":0\" /> personality
column2: besides being an extremely proficient artist.{{Citation needed|date=March 2020}} Her whole life she stayed single
column3: but she had several romances and received many offers of marriage. She loved her freedom and hated to be dominated by men or women. She was very ambitious and particular in traveling and doing business. She was very productive and could work for hours
column4: days and weeks to get results. On the one hand she could be charming and kind
column5: but she could switch quickly from friendship to hostility. She had years-long correspondences with her feminist friends
column6: but could drop people when she considered them no longer useful for her career or ambitions.<ref>Kerstin Gullstrand Hermelin

column2: the exhibition in Amsterdam at the Colonial Institute and the publication of her books made her internationally known. For her scientific ethnographic work on Bali
column3: Kleen was awarded the Johan August Wahlberg silver medal in April 1938
column4: given to individuals who have \"promoted anthropological and geographical science through outstanding efforts\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ssag.se/om/stadgar-och-bestammelser/johan-august-wahlbergs-medaljfond/|title=SSAG {{!}} Svenska Sällskapet för Antropologi och Geografi {{!}} Johan August Wahlbergs medaljfond|website=ssag.se|language=sv-SE|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref>

column1: [[Walter Spies]] was the central figure in the circle of artists residing on the island in Ubud
column2: Klungklung and Karangasem. He was considered to be the greatest expert on Balinese dance and drama. Together with the British dance critic [[Beryl de Zoete]]
column3: he wrote the standard 1938 work ''Dance and Drama in Bali''. Spies was jealous of the international success of Kleen{{Citation needed|date=March 2020}} and wrote a very critical nine-page review of the ''Temple Dances in Bali'' in the journal ''Djawa'' (1939). He complained
column4: \"the text and the depictions are filled with so many mistakes
column5: errors and incorrect statements that one must shake one's head.\" Spies claims that as an ethnographic document the book has no value.<ref>Elisabeth Lind
column6: The pencil in the service of ethnographical research
column8: </ref> As a result
column9: there were nearly no references to the work of Kleen in any ethnographic periodicals or publications after this critical review. It is only in 1962 that [[C. Hooykaas]] in his article \"Saiva-Siddhanta in Java and Bali\"<ref>Bijdragen tot de Taal-
column10: Land- en Volkenkunde 118 (1962) no 3(Leiden 309-327</ref> supported the importance of the study on mudras by de Kat Angelino and Kleen.

column1: Kleen contributed work to various European magazines
column2: including ''Sluyters' Monthly''
column3: ''Nederlandsch Indië Oud en Nieuw''
column4: ''Ord och Bild'' and ''Inter-Ocean''
column5: between 1920 and 1925<ref>Haks & Maris
column6: Lexicon of foreign artists who visualized Indonesia. (1600-1950)
column7: Singapore 1995</ref> and influenced in this way the perception and expectations of foreign visitors to Bali. Furthermore
column8: she influenced with her colourful
column9: vivid and dynamic art-deco drawing style the development of painting by local artists in Bali
column10: not in a one-way influence but more a kind of mutual influence.<ref>Bruce Granquist. Inventing art: The paintings of Batuan Bali. Satumata Press
column11: 2012</ref> Mostly these local paintings were made for the touristic market and depicted daily life instead of exclusively being concerned with gods
column12: demons and the [[Ramayana]] and [[Mahabharata]] epics. In this way
column13: she took part in the marketing of \"the last paradise\". This also meant that she became associated with this type of magazine drawing instead of her more important  ethnographic publications.

column2: Kleen visited Egypt to study the meanings of the different hand and foot movements depicted in the art
column3: which resulted in her last publication in 1946 of the book ''Solens Son'' about pharaoh [[Akhenaten|Echnaton]].

column1: Kleen left her collections to the Swedish House of Nobility on the condition that the archive would not be opened until 50 years after her death.[https://www.riddarhuset.se/tyra-kleens-samling] In 2001

column3: lithographs

Archives from Kleen are also held by the Swedish [[National Museums of World Culture]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://collections.smvk.se/carlotta-em/web/object/1022654/REFERENCES/164|title=Kleen

column1: From her diaries and letters it is clear that Kleen was a colourful and exciting androgynous<ref name=\":0\" /> personality
column2: besides being an extremely proficient artist.{{Citation needed|date=March 2020}} Her whole life she stayed single
column3: but she had several romances and received many offers of marriage. She loved her freedom and hated to be dominated by men or women. She was very ambitious and particular in traveling and doing business. She was very productive and could work for hours
column4: days and weeks to get results. On the one hand she could be charming and kind
column5: but she could switch quickly from friendship to hostility. She had years-long correspondences with her feminist friends
column6: but could drop people when she considered them no longer useful for her career or ambitions.<ref>Kerstin Gullstrand Hermelin
column7: Tyra Kleen and her background

column9: her life and work rediscovered
column10: Stockholm 2018</ref> Kleen was hardened by her childhood and refusing to give up her freedom for love.<ref>Niklas Franzén

column1:
| weather = Warm{{cite news |title=Liverpool revenge as Beardsley goal beats slow Arsenal |first=Brain |last=Glanville |page=68 |newspaper=The Sunday Times |location=London |date=13 August 1989}}
{{convert|21|°C|°F}}{{cite news |title=Weather |page=2 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}
The '''1989 FA Charity Shield''' (also known as the '''[[Wellpark Brewery|Tennent's]] FA Charity Shield''' for sponsorship reasons) was the 67th [[FA Community Shield|Charity Shield]]
column2: an annual English [[association football|football]] match played between the winners of the previous season's [[The Football League|Football League]] and [[FA Cup]]. It was held at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] on 12 August 1989. The match was contested by [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]
column3: champions of the [[1988–89 Football League]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]
column4: who beat [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in the [[1989 FA Cup Final|final]] of the [[1988–89 FA Cup]]. Watched by a crowd of 63
column6: Liverpool won the match 1–0.

column1: This was Arsenal's 10th Shield appearance and Liverpool's 14th. The two clubs had met in the [[Liverpool 0–2 Arsenal (26 May 1989)|last game of the previous season]]
column2: in a title decider at [[Anfield]] which Arsenal won 2–0 with a late goal from [[Michael Thomas (footballer
column3: born 1967)|Michael Thomas]]. Both clubs also faced each other in the [[Makita International Tournament]] at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] the previous month; [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] won the match 1–0. Journalists previewing the game argued this year's Shield had lost its spectacle given Liverpool's recent successes in the event as well as the prospect of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] beating Liverpool for a third time.

column1: New signing [[Glenn Hysén]] made his competitive debut for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Ian Rush]] started ahead of fellow striker [[John Aldridge]]. For [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]
column2: [[Gus Caesar]] replaced [[Steve Bould]] in the starting team. The only goal of the match came in the first half – a long ball from [[Barry Venison]] floated around the [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] defence and found [[Peter Beardsley]] in the penalty area to score. Afterwards [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] manager [[Kenny Dalglish]] spoke of his delight at his team's performance and the [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] manager [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] was complimentary of his opponents.

column1: The [[FA Community Shield|FA Charity Shield]] was founded in 1908 as a successor to the [[Sheriff of London Charity Shield]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Abandonment of the Sheriff Shield |page=11 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=19 April 1908}}</ref> It was a contest between the respective champions of the [[The Football League|Football League]] and [[Southern Football League|Southern League]]
column2: which then became an event for select teams of amateur and professional players by 1913.<ref>{{cite news |title=The F.A. Charity Shield |page=10 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=7 October 1913}}</ref> In 1921
column3: it was played between the Football League champions and [[FA Cup]] winners for the first time; this became standard practise from 1930.<ref>{{cite news |title=The FA Community Shield history |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/news/team-news/archive/2011/august/community-shield-2011/the-shield-from-the-beginning |first=Peter |last=Ferguson |work=mcfc.co.uk |publisher=Manchester City Football Club |date=4 August 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] acted as the host of the Shield from 1974.<ref>{{cite news|title=The FA Community Shield history |url=http://www.thefa.com/fa-community-shield/more/history |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=3 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hthw8Bhx?url=http://www.thefa.com/fa-community-shield/more/history |archivedate=6 July 2013 |url-status=live |df=dmy }}</ref>

column1: [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] qualified for the 1989 FA Charity Shield as winners of the [[1988–89 Football League]] First Division.<ref name=\"qul\">{{cite news |title=No Charity! |first=Steve |last=Curry |page=39 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> The team played [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] in the [[Liverpool F.C. 0–2 Arsenal F.C. (26 May 1989)|final game of the season]] and needed to win by two clear goals to be crowned champions.<ref name=\"anfl\">{{cite news |title=The night football was reborn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/mar/29/arsenal-liverpool-1989-football |first=Jason |last=Cowley |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=29 March 1989 |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> [[Alan Smith (footballer
column2: born 1962)|Alan Smith]] scored for Arsenal early in the second half to make it 1–0
column3: and [[Michael Thomas (footballer
column4: born 1967)|Michael Thomas]]'s goal with seconds left of the match ensured the team won the league title.<ref name=\"anfl\"/> Liverpool
column5: days before the league encounter with Arsenal
column6: defeated [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] to win the [[1989 FA Cup Final]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Final effort holds double threat |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=44 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=22 May 1989}}</ref> which meant they obtained the other Charity Shield place.<ref name=\"qul\"/>

column1: This was Arsenal's first appearance in the Charity Shield in 10 years; prior to the game they had won seven Shields ([[1930 FA Charity Shield|1930]]
column2: [[1931 FA Charity Shield|1931]]
column3: [[1933 FA Charity Shield|1933]]
column4: [[1934 FA Charity Shield|1934]]
column5: [[1938 FA Charity Shield|1938]]
column6: [[1948 FA Charity Shield|1948]] and [[1953 FA Charity Shield|1953]])
column7: and lost three ([[1935 FA Charity Shield|1935]]
column8: [[1936 FA Charity Shield|1936]] and [[1979 FA Charity Shield|1979]]). By contrast
column9: Liverpool had won seven previous Shields outright ([[1966 FA Charity Shield|1966]]
column13: [[1980 FA Charity Shield|1980]]
column14: [[1982 FA Charity Shield|1982]] and [[1988 FA Charity Shield|1988]])
column15: shared two with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] ([[1965 FA Charity Shield|1965]] and [[1977 FA Charity Shield|1977]]) and one apiece with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] ([[1986 FA Charity Shield|1986]]) and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] ([[1964 FA Charity Shield|1984]]). The club was runners-up in three Shields ([[1971 FA Charity Shield|1971]]
column16: [[1983 FA Charity Shield|1983]] and [[1984 FA Charity Shield|1984]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/community-shield/honours |title=English Community Shield: Honours |publisher=Statto Organisation |accessdate=21 May 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713124226/http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/community-shield/honours |archivedate=13 July 2014 }}</ref>

column1: This was the second time in a fortnight that Arsenal and Liverpool had played each other; at the end of July
column2: the two teams competed in the [[Makita International Tournament]] at Wembley.<ref name=\"gup\">{{cite news |title=Arsenal confident of hat-trick |first=David |last=Lacey |page=18 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> Arsenal won the game by a single goal to win the tournament and then on their pre-season travels beat Argentinian champions [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]].<ref name=\"gup\"/> The spectacle of the Charity Shield was lost on certain football journalists previewing the match
column3: because of Liverpool's recent successes in the Shield as well as the prospect of Arsenal beating Liverpool for a third time in succession.<ref name=\"ttp\">{{cite news |title=Charity's position overtaken |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=41 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> David Lacey wrote in ''[[The Guardian]]'' of 12 August 1989: \"The FA Charity Shield is now more of a pre-season finale than a pipe opener for the main event
column4: \"<ref name=\"gup\"/> and Stuart Jones of ''[[The Times]]'' went further in his assessment of its decline:

column1: {{blockquote|Whereas it was once an eagerly-awaited showpiece
column2: it resembles in the modern age little more than another public training exercise for sides who are increasingly being invited to practise for the season in more lucrative and prestigious events on foreign fields.<ref name=\"ttp\"/>}}
who in the previous season sustained a knee injury and was treated for [[Herpes zoster|shingles]] and [[hepatitis]]
column3: said before the match: \"I'm in great shape. Fitter than I have been since I came back from Italy.\"<ref name=\"dmp\">{{cite news |title=Rush: I'm still King Goal |first=Ted |last=Macauley |pages=22–23 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref>

column1: Arsenal was without injured defender [[Steve Bould]]
column2: but [[Nigel Winterburn]] returned to full action
column3: as did [[Brian Marwood]] – he recovered from a successful [[Achilles tendon]] operation.<ref name=\"gup\"/> Manager [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] deployed a [[Formation (association football)#5.E2.80.933.E2.80.932|5–3–2]] formation; [[Gus Caesar]] was brought into the defence to replace Bould.<ref name=\"str\"/>

column1: Liverpool had no injury concerns for the game other than long-term absentee [[Gary Gillespie]];<ref name=\"str\"/> New signing [[Glenn Hysén]] made his competitive debut for the club and striker [[John Aldridge]] was named on the substitutes bench; manager [[Kenny Dalglish]] lined the team up in a [[Formation (association football)#4–4–2|4–4–2]] formation.<ref name=\"str\"/> [[Alan Hansen]]
column2: who had missed Liverpool's final nine matches of the previous season
column3: was restored as captain.<ref name=\"ttr\">{{cite news |title=Beardsley shows no charity |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=22 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=14 August 1989}}</ref>

column1: Liverpool created the first chance of the game in the 20th minute. A pass from [[John Barnes (footballer)|John Barnes]] sent [[Steve Nicol]] clear to shoot
column2: but his effort saw the ball roll wide of the far post.<ref name=\"tos\">{{cite news |title=Liverpool back with a vengeance |first=Frank |last=McGhee |page=20 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=13 August 1989}}</ref> Liverpool created a further opportunity six minutes after – from a free-kick delivered by Barnes on the left
column3: Rush managed to outjump his marker and head the ball in the direction of the Arsenal goal. It however hit the near post and rebounded in the direction of Arsenal goalkeeper [[John Lukic]].<ref name=\"tos\"/> Minutes after the half-hour mark
column4: Liverpool scored the opening goal – a long ball from [[Barry Venison]] went behind the Arsenal defence and reached [[Peter Beardsley]]. Unimpeded
column5: he controlled the ball and shot it with his right foot to score.<ref name=\"str\"/> Arsenal's [[Kevin Richardson (footballer)|Kevin Richardson]] missed a chance to level the scoreline after good play by [[Lee Dixon]]; from outside the penalty box he scuffed his shot and the ball went over the crossbar.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Davies
column6: Barry (presenter)
column7: Motson
column8: John (commentator) |title=Match of the Day |time=22:10:00 pm to 23:00:00 pm |publisher=BBC |medium=Television production |date=12 August 1989}} See also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0B9-rkAhUPk#t=878 YouTube] footage.</ref>

column1: Liverpool continued to dominate proceedings in the second half; ''[[The Observer]]'' football correspondent Frank McGhee noted Arsenal's \"obvious need for a more adventurous approach.\"<ref name=\"tos\"/> The club's fans demanded Marwood's introduction to the match
column2: and in the 58th minute the player came on for Caesar.<ref name=\"str\"/> This meant Arsenal's formation was tweaked to 4–4–2
column3: with a [[flat back four]] defence.<ref name=\"str\"/> Arsenal found it hard to contain the Liverpool attack; Lukic saved an effort from Beardsley one-handed
column4: but only could turn the ball out for a corner.<ref name=\"str\"/> A pass by [[Ronnie Whelan]] managed to split the Arsenal defence and find Nicol; Winterburn however put an end to the move with a tackle.<ref name=\"str\"/> [[David Burrows (footballer)|David Burrows]]'s attempt on goal was blocked by O'Leary later on and Lukic did enough to save Rush's shot with his legs.<ref name=\"str\"/>

column1: |time=15:00 [[British Summer Time|BST]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Guide to the weekend fixtures |page=42 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref>

|report=<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=2419 |title=Match report from Liverpool – Arsenal played on 12 August 1989 |publisher=LFC History |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref>

column2: London
born 1967)|Michael Thomas]]
born 1962)|Alan Smith]] || || {{suboff|76}}

column1: Dalglish was pleased with Liverpool's game and told the press: \"The most important thing is that we got our own standard of football right. We were the better team in all departments and we know that if we get it right then we will be there or thereabouts.\"<ref name=\"dxp\">{{cite news |title=Hungover Gunners have only a bit part |first=Steve |last=Curry |page=38 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=14 August 1989}}</ref> Hysén
column2: the [[man of the match]]
column3: said of his centre-back partner Hansen: \"It is so easy playing alongside Alan. He tells you where to go and what position to take up.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/> He saw similarities with Liverpool and playing for a national team: \"The standards are so amazingly high. I just want to win things with them.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/>

column1: Graham praised his opponents – \"There is no need to take anything away from Liverpool because they were terrific\"
column2: and felt his team could have been more clinical.<ref name=\"dxp\"/> He described Arsenal's performance as \"below par\" and was upbeat about the season ahead: \"This might have done us the world of good. We will be all right by next week – don't worry about that.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/>

column2: which then became an event for select teams of amateur and professional players by 1913.<ref>{{cite news |title=The F.A. Charity Shield |page=10 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=7 October 1913}}</ref> In 1921
column3: it was played between the Football League champions and [[FA Cup]] winners for the first time; this became standard practise from 1930.<ref>{{cite news |title=The FA Community Shield history |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/news/team-news/archive/2011/august/community-shield-2011/the-shield-from-the-beginning |first=Peter |last=Ferguson |work=mcfc.co.uk |publisher=Manchester City Football Club |date=4 August 2011 |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] acted as the host of the Shield from 1974.<ref>{{cite news|title=The FA Community Shield history |url=http://www.thefa.com/fa-community-shield/more/history |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=3 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hthw8Bhx?url=http://www.thefa.com/fa-community-shield/more/history |archivedate=6 July 2013 |url-status=live |df=dmy }}</ref>

column1: [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] qualified for the 1989 FA Charity Shield as winners of the [[1988–89 Football League]] First Division.<ref name=\"qul\">{{cite news |title=No Charity! |first=Steve |last=Curry |page=39 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> The team played [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] in the [[Liverpool F.C. 0–2 Arsenal F.C. (26 May 1989)|final game of the season]] and needed to win by two clear goals to be crowned champions.<ref name=\"anfl\">{{cite news |title=The night football was reborn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/mar/29/arsenal-liverpool-1989-football |first=Jason |last=Cowley |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=29 March 1989 |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> [[Alan Smith (footballer
column2: born 1962)|Alan Smith]] scored for Arsenal early in the second half to make it 1–0
column3: and [[Michael Thomas (footballer
column4: born 1967)|Michael Thomas]]'s goal with seconds left of the match ensured the team won the league title.<ref name=\"anfl\"/> Liverpool
column5: days before the league encounter with Arsenal
column6: defeated [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] to win the [[1989 FA Cup Final]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Final effort holds double threat |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=44 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=22 May 1989}}</ref> which meant they obtained the other Charity Shield place.<ref name=\"qul\"/>

column1: This was Arsenal's first appearance in the Charity Shield in 10 years; prior to the game they had won seven Shields ([[1930 FA Charity Shield|1930]]
column2: [[1931 FA Charity Shield|1931]]
column3: [[1933 FA Charity Shield|1933]]
column4: [[1934 FA Charity Shield|1934]]
column5: [[1938 FA Charity Shield|1938]]
column6: [[1948 FA Charity Shield|1948]] and [[1953 FA Charity Shield|1953]])
column7: and lost three ([[1935 FA Charity Shield|1935]]
column8: [[1936 FA Charity Shield|1936]] and [[1979 FA Charity Shield|1979]]). By contrast
column9: Liverpool had won seven previous Shields outright ([[1966 FA Charity Shield|1966]]
column13: [[1980 FA Charity Shield|1980]]
column14: [[1982 FA Charity Shield|1982]] and [[1988 FA Charity Shield|1988]])
column15: shared two with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] ([[1965 FA Charity Shield|1965]] and [[1977 FA Charity Shield|1977]]) and one apiece with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] ([[1986 FA Charity Shield|1986]]) and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] ([[1964 FA Charity Shield|1984]]). The club was runners-up in three Shields ([[1971 FA Charity Shield|1971]]
column16: [[1983 FA Charity Shield|1983]] and [[1984 FA Charity Shield|1984]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/community-shield/honours |title=English Community Shield: Honours |publisher=Statto Organisation |accessdate=21 May 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713124226/http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/community-shield/honours |archivedate=13 July 2014 }}</ref>

column1: This was the second time in a fortnight that Arsenal and Liverpool had played each other; at the end of July
column2: the two teams competed in the [[Makita International Tournament]] at Wembley.<ref name=\"gup\">{{cite news |title=Arsenal confident of hat-trick |first=David |last=Lacey |page=18 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> Arsenal won the game by a single goal to win the tournament and then on their pre-season travels beat Argentinian champions [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]].<ref name=\"gup\"/> The spectacle of the Charity Shield was lost on certain football journalists previewing the match
column3: because of Liverpool's recent successes in the Shield as well as the prospect of Arsenal beating Liverpool for a third time in succession.<ref name=\"ttp\">{{cite news |title=Charity's position overtaken |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=41 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref> David Lacey wrote in ''[[The Guardian]]'' of 12 August 1989: \"The FA Charity Shield is now more of a pre-season finale than a pipe opener for the main event
column4: \"<ref name=\"gup\"/> and Stuart Jones of ''[[The Times]]'' went further in his assessment of its decline:

column1: {{blockquote|Whereas it was once an eagerly-awaited showpiece
column2: it resembles in the modern age little more than another public training exercise for sides who are increasingly being invited to practise for the season in more lucrative and prestigious events on foreign fields.<ref name=\"ttp\"/>}}
who in the previous season sustained a knee injury and was treated for [[Herpes zoster|shingles]] and [[hepatitis]]
column3: said before the match: \"I'm in great shape. Fitter than I have been since I came back from Italy.\"<ref name=\"dmp\">{{cite news |title=Rush: I'm still King Goal |first=Ted |last=Macauley |pages=22–23 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref>

column1: Arsenal was without injured defender [[Steve Bould]]
column2: but [[Nigel Winterburn]] returned to full action
column3: as did [[Brian Marwood]] – he recovered from a successful [[Achilles tendon]] operation.<ref name=\"gup\"/> Manager [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] deployed a [[Formation (association football)#5.E2.80.933.E2.80.932|5–3–2]] formation; [[Gus Caesar]] was brought into the defence to replace Bould.<ref name=\"str\"/>

column1: Liverpool had no injury concerns for the game other than long-term absentee [[Gary Gillespie]];<ref name=\"str\"/> New signing [[Glenn Hysén]] made his competitive debut for the club and striker [[John Aldridge]] was named on the substitutes bench; manager [[Kenny Dalglish]] lined the team up in a [[Formation (association football)#4–4–2|4–4–2]] formation.<ref name=\"str\"/> [[Alan Hansen]]
column2: who had missed Liverpool's final nine matches of the previous season
column3: was restored as captain.<ref name=\"ttr\">{{cite news |title=Beardsley shows no charity |first=Stuart |last=Jones |page=22 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=14 August 1989}}</ref>

column1: Liverpool created the first chance of the game in the 20th minute. A pass from [[John Barnes (footballer)|John Barnes]] sent [[Steve Nicol]] clear to shoot
column2: but his effort saw the ball roll wide of the far post.<ref name=\"tos\">{{cite news |title=Liverpool back with a vengeance |first=Frank |last=McGhee |page=20 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=13 August 1989}}</ref> Liverpool created a further opportunity six minutes after – from a free-kick delivered by Barnes on the left
column3: Rush managed to outjump his marker and head the ball in the direction of the Arsenal goal. It however hit the near post and rebounded in the direction of Arsenal goalkeeper [[John Lukic]].<ref name=\"tos\"/> Minutes after the half-hour mark
column4: Liverpool scored the opening goal – a long ball from [[Barry Venison]] went behind the Arsenal defence and reached [[Peter Beardsley]]. Unimpeded
column5: he controlled the ball and shot it with his right foot to score.<ref name=\"str\"/> Arsenal's [[Kevin Richardson (footballer)|Kevin Richardson]] missed a chance to level the scoreline after good play by [[Lee Dixon]]; from outside the penalty box he scuffed his shot and the ball went over the crossbar.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Davies
column6: Barry (presenter)
column7: Motson
column8: John (commentator) |title=Match of the Day |time=22:10:00 pm to 23:00:00 pm |publisher=BBC |medium=Television production |date=12 August 1989}} See also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0B9-rkAhUPk#t=878 YouTube] footage.</ref>

column1: Liverpool continued to dominate proceedings in the second half; ''[[The Observer]]'' football correspondent Frank McGhee noted Arsenal's \"obvious need for a more adventurous approach.\"<ref name=\"tos\"/> The club's fans demanded Marwood's introduction to the match
column2: and in the 58th minute the player came on for Caesar.<ref name=\"str\"/> This meant Arsenal's formation was tweaked to 4–4–2
column3: with a [[flat back four]] defence.<ref name=\"str\"/> Arsenal found it hard to contain the Liverpool attack; Lukic saved an effort from Beardsley one-handed
column4: but only could turn the ball out for a corner.<ref name=\"str\"/> A pass by [[Ronnie Whelan]] managed to split the Arsenal defence and find Nicol; Winterburn however put an end to the move with a tackle.<ref name=\"str\"/> [[David Burrows (footballer)|David Burrows]]'s attempt on goal was blocked by O'Leary later on and Lukic did enough to save Rush's shot with his legs.<ref name=\"str\"/>

column1: |time=15:00 [[British Summer Time|BST]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Guide to the weekend fixtures |page=42 |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=12 August 1989}}</ref>

|report=<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=2419 |title=Match report from Liverpool – Arsenal played on 12 August 1989 |publisher=LFC History |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref>

column2: London
born 1967)|Michael Thomas]]
born 1962)|Alan Smith]] || || {{suboff|76}}

column1: Dalglish was pleased with Liverpool's game and told the press: \"The most important thing is that we got our own standard of football right. We were the better team in all departments and we know that if we get it right then we will be there or thereabouts.\"<ref name=\"dxp\">{{cite news |title=Hungover Gunners have only a bit part |first=Steve |last=Curry |page=38 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=14 August 1989}}</ref> Hysén
column2: the [[man of the match]]
column3: said of his centre-back partner Hansen: \"It is so easy playing alongside Alan. He tells you where to go and what position to take up.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/> He saw similarities with Liverpool and playing for a national team: \"The standards are so amazingly high. I just want to win things with them.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/>

column1: Graham praised his opponents – \"There is no need to take anything away from Liverpool because they were terrific\"
column2: and felt his team could have been more clinical.<ref name=\"dxp\"/> He described Arsenal's performance as \"below par\" and was upbeat about the season ahead: \"This might have done us the world of good. We will be all right by next week – don't worry about that.\"<ref name=\"dmr\"/>
1989 FA Charity Shield
column3: //en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1989_FA_Charity_Shield

column1: The '''Hay Bridge''' is a [[road bridge]] that carries the [[Cobb Highway]] across the [[Murrumbidgee River]] at [[Hay
column2: New South Wales|Hay]]
column3: in the [[Hay Shire]] local government area of [[New South Wales]]
column4: Australia. The current bridge is the second bridge located in Hay that crosses the Murrumbidgee; the first bridge was in operation from 1873 until 1973; the second and current bridge has operated since 1973.

column1: The current Hay Bridge is a six-[[Span (architecture)|span]]
column2: [[reinforced concrete]] and steel [[box girder]] structure supported on steel piles and slender concrete piers. It has an overall length of {{convert|638|ft|m|0|order=flip}} with two {{convert|97|ft|m|0|adj=on|order=flip}} spans and four {{convert|105|ft|m|0|adj=on|order=flip}} spans
column3: and is {{convert|30|ft|m|0|order=flip}} between kerbs. A {{convert|5|ft|m|0|adj=mid|order=flip|spell=on|-wide}} [[footway]] has been provided for pedestrian use.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: Each box girder is made up of five cells each {{convert|6|ft|m|0|order=flip|spell=on}} wide and {{convert|3|ft|3|in|m|0|order=flip|spell=on}} high. The base and walls of each cell are steel plates and the reinforced concrete deck forms the top section. A feature of the design is the cantilever construction of the girders. This allows a greater distance between piers than a simply supported span design.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>
Hay is located on the Western Plains where the clay and silt deposit can be up to {{convert|1500|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in depth. Due to the complete absence of rock in this deposit
column2: {{convert|10|x|10|in|cm|0|order=flip}} in rolled \"H\" section steel piles have been used for the [[Foundation (construction)|foundations]]. These vary from {{convert|51|to|81|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in length.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: [[Coffer dam]]s of steel sheet piling were constructed in the river to enable the construction of the two pile caps and the lower portions of the two piers in the river. The steel girders were manufactured at Sydney in pairs {{convert|15|ft|m|0|order=flip}} wide
column2: transported by road to Hay and bolted together after having been placed in position on falsework. The longest sections handled were {{convert|65|ft|m|0|order=flip}}
column3: end to end
column4: and each weighed {{convert|24|ST|t|0|order=flip}}.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: The bridge was designed by Gordon Bull and Associates
column2: Consulting Engineers and was constructed by contract to and under the supervision of the Department by Central Constructions Pty Ltd of New South Wales. The approaches were designed and constructed by the Department. The total cost of the bridge and approaches was {{AUD}}890
column3: 000. The completion of this bridge by the Department
column4: together with the channelisation of the intersection of State Highways Nos 14 and 21 immediately south of the bridge and the reconstruction of Lachlan Street
column5: State Highway No. 21
column6: Cobb Highway by Hay Shire Council
column7: immediately north of the bridge
column8: ensured a smoother flow of traffic through the town of Hay.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: The bridge was opened by the Honourable [[Harry Jago]]
column2: the NSW Assistant Minister for Highways
column3: on {{start date|1973|06|08|df=y}}
column4: the same day as he also opened a replacement bridge across the Murrumbidgee River at {{NSWcity|Balranald}}
column5: located {{convert|80|mi|km|0|order=flip}} west.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: | image               = Hay Bridge over Murrumbidgee River (Leader
column2: Melbourne
column3: Sat 3 Oct 1908 Page 28).jpg

column1: | caption             = The old Hay Bridge in 1908
| fabricator          = [[Peter Nicol Russell|P. N. Russell and Co]]
| inaugurated         = {{end date|1874|08|29|df=y}} by [[Henry Parkes|Sir Henry Parkes]]
column2: [[Premier of New South Wales|NSW Premier]]

column1: | references          = <ref>{{cite news |author= |title=The Hay Bridge |work=The Leader |location=Melbourne |date=3 October 1908 |page=28 }}</ref>
The former Hay Bridge was a [[swing bridge]] that carried the Cobb Highway across the Murrumbidgee River at Hay
column2: New South Wales
column3: from 1873 to 1973.

column1: The bridge consisted of two fixed and two swing spans. It was of a [[lattice girder]] design
column2: with timber decking. The drum was a composite of cast and wrought iron that was carried on the centre pier. The opening of the bridge was operated by hand.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.rms.nsw.gov.au/documents/about/environment/protecting-heritage/moveable-span-bridge-study-volume-2-bascule-and-swing-span-bridges-part-2.pdf |title=Volume 2: Bascule and Swing Span Bridges - Movable Span Bridge Study |author=[[GHD Group]] |date=n.d. |website=[[Roads and Maritime Services]] |pages=144
column5: 149 |url-status=live |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=7 April 2020 }}</ref> The bridge was opened to allow [[List of Murray–Darling steamboats|riverboats]] to pass the bridge.

column1: The swing spans were each of {{convert|60|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in length. The swinging spans turned on a pier in the centre of the river. The lower portion of the central pier was cast iron and {{convert|13|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter; it continued {{convert|20|ft|m|1|order=flip}} below the bed of the river. The upper portion of the central pier was wrought iron
column2: {{convert|12|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter
column3: and {{convert|29|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in height
column4: with an ornamental moulding on top; within this was the iron rack on which a pinion gear allowed the swing span to the opened by one person. The pivot shaft was {{convert|8|ft|m|1|order=flip}} long and {{convert|8|in|cm|1|order=flip}} in diameter. The upper part of the central pier was fitted with adjusting screws to regulate weights
column5: and carried the gearing and platform used to turn the bridge.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The piers for the side spans each consisted of a pair of  cylinders
column2: each {{convert|6|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter of cast and wrought iron. All the piers were filled with brickwork and concrete and braced together with iron rivets. The piers of the side span had  adjusting screws for equalising the heights of swing and fixed spans. The roadway of side spans was {{convert|17|ft|m|1|order=flip}} wide
column3: and over swing spans was {{convert|15|ft|m|1|order=flip}} to allow for wrought-iron cantilevers to be accommodated.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The contractors for the ironwork were [[Peter Nicol Russell|P. N. Russell and Co.]]
column2: and the sinking and fixing of the piers was by the [[New South Wales Government]] under Mr K. A. Franklin.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13345068|title=THE PREMIER AT HAY.|date=1874-09-08|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=5 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> P. N. Russell and Co. won the tender for the iron bridgework in January 1870<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article223285633|title=Government Gazette Tenders and Contracts|date=1870-01-28|work=New South Wales Government Gazette |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=232 |via=Trove
column4: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> and the cylinders for the piers were cast at their works in Sydney during 1870.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63617555|title=OPENING OF MESSRS. P. N. RUSSELL'S NEW RAILWAY CARRIAGE FACTORY|date=1870-03-17|work=Illustrated Sydney News |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=1 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> There was a separate contract for the approaches
column6: which was the last piece of work to be finished. Construction began around September 1871<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18757032|title=GENERAL NEWS.|date=1871-09-07|work=Maitland Mercury and Hunter River General Advertiser |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=3 |via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> and all work was completed in 1873.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The bridge was officially opened by the [[Premier of New South Wales]]
column2: [[Henry Parkes|Sir Henry Parkes]]
column3: on 29 August 1874
column4: when he named the new bridge the \"Hay Bridge\".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5877578|title=MR. PARKES IN RIVERINA.|date=1874-09-01|work=Argus |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=6 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref name=\":1\" /> A toll was payable for using the bridge up to 1890.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140470419|title=ABOLITION OF THE HAY BRIDGE TOLLS.|date=1890-07-01|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column6: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> The bridge had a permanent caretaker whose job was to keep up the opening mechanism and open the bridge when needed to allow river traffic to pass.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article141023206|title=HAY MUNICIPAL COUNCIL.|date=1920-12-10|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020|pages=4|via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref>

column2: two riverboats had minor collisions with it.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113592419|title=DENILIQUIN.|date=1872-09-28|work=Riverine Herald |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> In 1906
column4: the river steamer ''William Davies'' was involved in an accident while passing the bridge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article145030016|title=Steamer Accident at Hay Bridge.|date=1906-09-29|work=Wagga Wagga Advertiser |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> There were also an extraordinary number of serious traffic accidents on the bridge and its approaches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140000413|title=SERIOUS ACCIDENT ON THE HAY BRIDGE.|date=1895-03-29|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column6: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article137215683|title=DAMAGES CLAIM FOLLOWS CAR ACCIDENT|date=1953-03-20|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=1 |via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article139811753|title=Sensational Motor Accident|date=1940-05-28|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column8: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article134751282|title=CAR ACCIDENT.|date=1912-05-22|work=Riverina Recorder |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=4 |via=Trove
column9: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article137217490|title=TRUCK BREAKS BRIDGE FENCING.|date=1954-09-21|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column10: [[National Library of Australia]]}}</ref> Some of these were put down to the poor condition of the bridge roadway
column12: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> which was very narrow for motor traffic.

column2: the opening mechanism of the old bridge had broken and the steamboat ''[[PS Pevensey]]'' had to pull the span open and then pull it closed again.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140664229 |title=THE HAY BRIDGE.|date=1931-07-31 |work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> By the 1930s river traffic on the Murrumbidgee was in decline. The last occasions when the bridge was opened were
column4: in August 1936
column5: for ''Ulonga'' and
column6: in early 1937 for ''Adeline
column7: '' carrying a load of timber.<ref name=\"Main Roads\" /> The swing span was locked in 1937.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The Hay Bridge was demolished in 1973 and replaced with a modern concrete bridge. The turntable of the old bridge was relocated to the Lions Park in Hay.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The '''Hay Bridge''' is a [[road bridge]] that carries the [[Cobb Highway]] across the [[Murrumbidgee River]] at [[Hay
column2: New South Wales|Hay]]
column3: in the [[Hay Shire]] local government area of [[New South Wales]]
column4: Australia. The current bridge is the second bridge located in Hay that crosses the Murrumbidgee; the first bridge was in operation from 1873 until 1973; the second and current bridge has operated since 1973.

column1: The current Hay Bridge is a six-[[Span (architecture)|span]]
column2: [[reinforced concrete]] and steel [[box girder]] structure supported on steel piles and slender concrete piers. It has an overall length of {{convert|638|ft|m|0|order=flip}} with two {{convert|97|ft|m|0|adj=on|order=flip}} spans and four {{convert|105|ft|m|0|adj=on|order=flip}} spans
column3: and is {{convert|30|ft|m|0|order=flip}} between kerbs. A {{convert|5|ft|m|0|adj=mid|order=flip|spell=on|-wide}} [[footway]] has been provided for pedestrian use.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: Each box girder is made up of five cells each {{convert|6|ft|m|0|order=flip|spell=on}} wide and {{convert|3|ft|3|in|m|0|order=flip|spell=on}} high. The base and walls of each cell are steel plates and the reinforced concrete deck forms the top section. A feature of the design is the cantilever construction of the girders. This allows a greater distance between piers than a simply supported span design.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>
Hay is located on the Western Plains where the clay and silt deposit can be up to {{convert|1500|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in depth. Due to the complete absence of rock in this deposit
column2: {{convert|10|x|10|in|cm|0|order=flip}} in rolled \"H\" section steel piles have been used for the [[Foundation (construction)|foundations]]. These vary from {{convert|51|to|81|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in length.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: [[Coffer dam]]s of steel sheet piling were constructed in the river to enable the construction of the two pile caps and the lower portions of the two piers in the river. The steel girders were manufactured at Sydney in pairs {{convert|15|ft|m|0|order=flip}} wide
column2: transported by road to Hay and bolted together after having been placed in position on falsework. The longest sections handled were {{convert|65|ft|m|0|order=flip}}
column3: end to end
column4: and each weighed {{convert|24|ST|t|0|order=flip}}.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: The bridge was designed by Gordon Bull and Associates
column2: Consulting Engineers and was constructed by contract to and under the supervision of the Department by Central Constructions Pty Ltd of New South Wales. The approaches were designed and constructed by the Department. The total cost of the bridge and approaches was {{AUD}}890
column3: 000. The completion of this bridge by the Department
column4: together with the channelisation of the intersection of State Highways Nos 14 and 21 immediately south of the bridge and the reconstruction of Lachlan Street
column5: State Highway No. 21
column6: Cobb Highway by Hay Shire Council
column7: immediately north of the bridge
column8: ensured a smoother flow of traffic through the town of Hay.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: The bridge was opened by the Honourable [[Harry Jago]]
column2: the NSW Assistant Minister for Highways
column3: on {{start date|1973|06|08|df=y}}
column4: the same day as he also opened a replacement bridge across the Murrumbidgee River at {{NSWcity|Balranald}}
column5: located {{convert|80|mi|km|0|order=flip}} west.<ref name=\"Main Roads\"/>

column1: | image               = Hay Bridge over Murrumbidgee River (Leader
column2: Melbourne
column3: Sat 3 Oct 1908 Page 28).jpg

column1: | caption             = The old Hay Bridge in 1908
| fabricator          = [[Peter Nicol Russell|P. N. Russell and Co]]
| inaugurated         = {{end date|1874|08|29|df=y}} by [[Henry Parkes|Sir Henry Parkes]]
column2: [[Premier of New South Wales|NSW Premier]]

column1: | references          = <ref>{{cite news |author= |title=The Hay Bridge |work=The Leader |location=Melbourne |date=3 October 1908 |page=28 }}</ref>
The former Hay Bridge was a [[swing bridge]] that carried the Cobb Highway across the Murrumbidgee River at Hay
column2: New South Wales
column3: from 1873 to 1973.

column1: The bridge consisted of two fixed and two swing spans. It was of a [[lattice girder]] design
column2: with timber decking  The drum was a composite of cast and wrought iron that was carried on the centre pier. The opening of the bridge was operated by hand.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.rms.nsw.gov.au/documents/about/environment/protecting-heritage/moveable-span-bridge-study-volume-2-bascule-and-swing-span-bridges-part-2.pdf |title=Volume 2: Bascule and Swing Span Bridges - Movable Span Bridge Study |author=[[GHD Group]] |date=n.d. |website=[[Roads and Maritime Services]] |pages=144
column5: 149 |url-status=live |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=7 April 2020 }}</ref> The bridge was opened to allow [[List of Murray–Darling steamboats|riverboats]] to pass the bridge.

column1: The swing spans were each of {{convert|60|ft|m|0|order=flip}} in length. The swinging spans turned on a pier in the centre of the river. The lower portion of the central pier was cast iron and {{convert|13|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter; it continued {{convert|20|ft|m|1|order=flip}} below the bed of the river. The upper portion of the central pier was wrought iron
column2: {{convert|12|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter
column3: and {{convert|29|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in height
column4: with an ornamental moulding on top; within this was the iron rack on which a pinion gear allowed the swing span to the opened by one person. The pivot shaft was {{convert|8|ft|m|1|order=flip}} long and {{convert|8|in|cm|1|order=flip}} in diameter. The upper part of the central pier was fitted with adjusting screws to regulate weights
column5: and carried the gearing and platform used to turn the bridge.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The piers for the side spans each consisted of a pair of  cylinders
column2: each {{convert|6|ft|m|1|order=flip}} in diameter of cast and wrought iron. All the piers were filled with brickwork and concrete and braced together with iron rivets. The piers of the side span had  adjusting screws for equalising the heights of swing and fixed spans. The roadway of side spans was {{convert|17|ft|m|1|order=flip}} wide
column3: and over swing spans was {{convert|15|ft|m|1|order=flip}} to allow for wrought-iron cantilevers to be accommodated.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The contractors for the ironwork were [[Peter Nicol Russell|P. N. Russell and Co.]]
column2: and the sinking and fixing of the piers was by the [[New South Wales Government]] under Mr K. A. Franklin.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13345068|title=THE PREMIER AT HAY.|date=1874-09-08|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=5 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> P. N. Russell and Co. won the tender for the iron bridgework in January 1870<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article223285633|title=Government Gazette Tenders and Contracts|date=1870-01-28|work=New South Wales Government Gazette |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=232 |via=Trove
column4: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> and the cylinders for the piers were cast at their works in Sydney during 1870.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63617555|title=OPENING OF MESSRS. P. N. RUSSELL'S NEW RAILWAY CARRIAGE FACTORY|date=1870-03-17|work=Illustrated Sydney News |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=1 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> There was a separate contract for the approaches
column6: which was the last piece of work to be finished. Construction began around September 1871<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18757032|title=GENERAL NEWS.|date=1871-09-07|work=Maitland Mercury and Hunter River General Advertiser |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=3 |via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> and all work was completed in 1873.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The bridge was officially opened by the [[Premier of New South Wales]]
column2: [[Henry Parkes|Sir Henry Parkes]]
column3: on 29 August 1874
column4: when he named the new bridge the \"Hay Bridge\".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5877578|title=MR. PARKES IN RIVERINA.|date=1874-09-01|work=Argus |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=6 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref name=\":1\" /> A toll was payable for using the bridge up to 1890.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140470419|title=ABOLITION OF THE HAY BRIDGE TOLLS.|date=1890-07-01|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column6: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> The bridge had a permanent caretaker whose job was to keep up the opening mechanism and open the bridge when needed to allow river traffic to pass.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article141023206|title=HAY MUNICIPAL COUNCIL.|date=1920-12-10|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020|pages=4|via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref>

column2: two riverboats had minor collisions with it.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113592419|title=DENILIQUIN.|date=1872-09-28|work=Riverine Herald |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> In 1906
column4: the river steamer ''William Davies'' was involved in an accident while passing the bridge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article145030016|title=Steamer Accident at Hay Bridge.|date=1906-09-29|work=Wagga Wagga Advertiser |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column5: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> There were also an extraordinary number of serious traffic accidents on the bridge and its approaches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140000413|title=SERIOUS ACCIDENT ON THE HAY BRIDGE.|date=1895-03-29|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column6: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article137215683|title=DAMAGES CLAIM FOLLOWS CAR ACCIDENT|date=1953-03-20|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=1 |via=Trove
column7: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article139811753|title=Sensational Motor Accident|date=1940-05-28|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column8: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article134751282|title=CAR ACCIDENT.|date=1912-05-22|work=Riverina Recorder |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=4 |via=Trove
column9: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article137217490|title=TRUCK BREAKS BRIDGE FENCING.|date=1954-09-21|work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column10: [[National Library of Australia]]}}</ref> Some of these were put down to the poor condition of the bridge roadway
column12: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> which was very narrow for motor traffic.

column2: the opening mechanism of the old bridge had broken and the steamboat ''[[PS Pevensey]]'' had to pull the span open and then pull it closed again.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140664229 |title=THE HAY BRIDGE.|date=1931-07-31 |work=Riverine Grazier |access-date=8 April 2020 |pages=2 |via=Trove
column3: [[National Library of Australia]] }}</ref> By the 1930s river traffic on the Murrumbidgee was in decline. The last occasions when the bridge was opened were
column4: in August 1936
column5: for ''Ulonga'' and
column6: in early 1937 for ''Adeline
column7: '' carrying a load of timber.<ref name=\"Main Roads\" /> The swing span was locked in 1937.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The Hay Bridge was demolished in 1973 and replaced with a modern concrete bridge. The turntable of the old bridge was relocated to the Lions Park in Hay.<ref name=\":0\" />

'''NCT Dream''' is the third sub-unit of South Korean boy group [[NCT (band)|NCT]]. The group follows an admission-graduation system, where they graduate from the unit after reaching the Korean age of 20 (19 internationally).<ref name=graduated/>

The group debuted on August 25, 2016, with the single \Chewing Gum\" and with seven members: [[Mark Lee (singer)|Mark]]
column5: Renjun
column6: Jeno
column7: Haechan
column8: [[Na Jae-min|Jaemin]]
column9: [[Zhong Chenle|Chenle]]
column10: and Jisung. Mark graduated from the group on December 31

column2: Haechan
column3: Jaemin
column4: Jisung
column5: and Jeno were previously a part of [[SM Rookies]]. [[Zhong Chenle|Chenle]] previously had a solo career and received two months of training prior to his debut with NCT.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://korea.people.com.cn/n3/2016/0819/c205178-9102771-2.html|title=SM新男团NCT DREAM将于25日出道 14岁中国籍成员公开|date=August 19
column6: 2016|website=People's Daily|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=April 13

column1: NCT was first announced in January 2016 by [[Lee Soo-man]] at a presentation
column2: where he talked about a group that would debut different teams around the world.<ref>{{cite web|last=Won|first=Ho-jung|url=http://kpopherald.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=201602231707438293945_2&ACE_SEARCH=1|title=S.M. Entertainment continues expansion with New Culture Technology|date=February 23
column3: 2016|work=Kpop Herald|publisher=Herald Corporation}}</ref> Mark debuted in the group's first unit
column4: [[Nct U|NCT U]]
column5: on April 4
column6: 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/culturesports/2016/04/04/19/0701000000AEN20160404006300315F.html|title=SM's neo-boy band 'NCT U' to launch this week|date=April 4
column7: 2016|website=[[Yonhap]]|accessdate=April 28
column8: 2016}}</ref> On July 7
column9: Haechan made his debut in the second unit
column11: alongside Mark.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hype.my/2016/113666/nct127-sm-entertainment-unveils-members-of-new-nct-sub-unit/|title=(UPDATE) #NCT127: SM Entertainment Unveils Members Of New NCT Sub-Unit|website=Hype|accessdate=February 12
column12: 2018}}</ref> NCT Dream was announced as the third subunit on August 18
column13: 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertain.naver.com/music/now/read?oid=108&aid=0002548916|title=NCT DREAM

column2: ''The First''
column3: and ''We Young''===

column1: NCT Dream released their debut single
column2: \"Chewing Gum\"
column3: on August 24
column4: 2016. Their debut stage was on August 25 on ''[[M Countdown]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nwww.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160825000512|title=NCT Dream releases new music video|date=August 25
column5: 2016|website=The Korea Herald}}</ref>

column3: SM Entertainment announced NCT Dream would release their first single album. It was revealed Jaemin would not be participating in the release due to complications from a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2017/02/02/sm-releases-statement-regarding-nct-dreams-jaemin|title=SM releases statement regarding NCT Dream's Jaemin|date=February 2
column4: 2017|website=SBS}}</ref> The group's single album
column5: ''[[The First (single)|The First]]
column6: '' was released on February 9 with its lead single
column7: \"My First and Last\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/7685137/nct-dream-charm-funk-pop-my-first-last-video|title=NCT Dream Charm With Funk and Pop in 'My First & Last' Video: Watch|date=August 2
column8: 2017|website=Billboard}}</ref> The album debuted at number one on the Gaon Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaonchart.co.kr/main/section/chart/album.gaon?termGbn=week&hitYear=2017&targetTime=06&nationGbn=T|title=국내 대표 음악 차트 가온차트!|website=Gaon Chart|accessdate=February 17
column9: 2017|language=ko}}</ref> The unit had their comeback stage on ''M Countdown''
column13: \"Dunk Shot\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mwave.me/en/news/news/view/112437/%5BVideo%5D-SF9-and-NCT-DREAM-Perform-Comeback-Stages-on-%E2%80%B2M-COUNTDOWN%E2%80%B2|title=[Video] SF9 and NCT DREAM Perform Comeback Stages on ′M COUNTDOWN′|date=February 10
column15: NCT Dream was revealed to have won 1st place on the 100th episode of SBS MTV's ''[[The Show (South Korean TV series)|The Show]]''
column16: marking the first music show win for a NCT unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2017/02/15/nct-dream-get-first-ever-win-my-first-and-last|title=NCT Dream get first ever win with 'My First and Last'|date=February 15

column2: NCT Dream released their single
column3: \"Trigger the Fever\"
column4: as official ambassadors for the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] Korea.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pop.heraldcorp.com/view.php?ud=201703151305595804687_1|title=NCT드림
column5: 'FIFA U-20 월드컵' 오피셜송 가창..오늘(15일) 공개|website=Herald Corporation|date=March 15
column6: 2017|language=ko}}</ref>

column3: on August 17
column4: 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pop.heraldcorp.com/view.php?ud=201708090904064107580_1|access-date=August 9
column5: 2017|date=August 9
column6: 2017|title=NCT DREAM
column7: 17일 첫 미니앨범 컴백…청량함 듬뿍 담았다|website=Herald Corporation|language=Korean}}</ref> The group's first comeback stage was held on ''M Countdown''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mwave.me/en/news/news/view/116637/NCT-Dream-and-SONAMOO-to-Perform-Comeback-Stage-Through-%E2%80%B2M-COUNTDOWN%E2%80%B2|title=NCT Dream and SONAMOO to Perform Comeback Stage Through ′M COUNTDOWN′|date=August 17
column8: 2017|website=Mwave}}</ref>

column2: \"Joy
column3: \" as part of [[SM Station]] on December 15
column4: 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/8070790/nct-dream-christmas-joy|title=NCT Dream Releases Christmas-Themed 'Joy': Watch|date=December 15
column5: 2017|website=Billboard}}</ref>

column2: ''We Go Up''
column3: and Mark's graduation===

column1: [[File:180902 스카이페스티벌 NCT DREAM 2.jpg|thumb|right|NCT Dream at the 2018 Incheon Airport Sky Festival
column2: with former member [[Mark Lee (singer)|Mark]] (''far left'').]]

column1: NCT Dream promoted alongside NCT U and NCT 127 as [[NCT (band)|NCT 2018]] for the first quarter of 2018. On March 4
column3: NCT Dream released their single
column5: which was included in NCT's first album
column6: ''[[NCT 2018 Empathy]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8231620/nct-dream-rebellious-side-go-music-video|title=NCT Dream Show Their Rebellious Side With 'Go' Music Video: Watch|work=Billboard|date=March 5
column7: 2018}}</ref> It also marked the group's first comeback with Jaemin since their debut.

'''NCT Dream''' is the third sub-unit of South Korean boy group [[NCT (band)|NCT]]. The group follows an admission-graduation system, where they graduate from the unit after reaching the Korean age of 20 (19 internationally).<ref name=graduated/>

The group debuted on August 25, 2016, with the single \Chewing Gum\" and with seven members: [[Mark Lee (singer)|Mark]]
column3: Renjun
column4: Jeno
column5: Haechan
column6: [[Na Jae-min|Jaemin]]
column7: [[Zhong Chenle|Chenle]]
column8: and Jisung. Mark graduated from the group on December 31
column9: 2018.<ref name=markg/>

column2: Haechan
column3: Jaemin
column4: Jisung
column5: and Jeno were previously a part of [[SM Rookies]]. [[Zhong Chenle|Chenle]] previously had a solo career and received two months of training prior to his debut with NCT.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://korea.people.com.cn/n3/2016/0819/c205178-9102771-2.html|title=SM新男团NCT DREAM将于25日出道 14岁中国籍成员公开|date=August 19
column6: 2016|website=People's Daily|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=April 13

column1: NCT was first announced in January 2016 by [[Lee Soo-man]] at a presentation
column2: where he talked about a group that would debut different teams around the world.<ref>{{cite web|last=Won|first=Ho-jung|url=http://kpopherald.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=201602231707438293945_2&ACE_SEARCH=1|title=S.M. Entertainment continues expansion with New Culture Technology|date=February 23
column3: 2016|work=Kpop Herald|publisher=Herald Corporation}}</ref> Mark debuted in the group's first unit
column4: [[Nct U|NCT U]]

column6: 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/culturesports/2016/04/04/19/0701000000AEN20160404006300315F.html|title=SM's neo-boy band 'NCT U' to launch this week|date=April 4
column7: 2016|website=[[Yonhap]]|accessdate=April 28
column8: 2016}}</ref> On July 7
column9: Haechan made his debut in the second unit
column11: alongside Mark.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hype.my/2016/113666/nct127-sm-entertainment-unveils-members-of-new-nct-sub-unit/|title=(UPDATE) #NCT127: SM Entertainment Unveils Members Of New NCT Sub-Unit|website=Hype|accessdate=February 12
column12: 2018}}</ref> NCT Dream was announced as the third subunit on August 18
column13: 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertain.naver.com/music/now/read?oid=108&aid=0002548916|title=NCT DREAM

column2: \"Chewing Gum\"
column3: on August 24
column4: 2016. Their debut stage was on August 25 on ''[[M Countdown]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nwww.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160825000512|title=NCT Dream releases new music video|date=August 25
column5: 2016|website=The Korea Herald}}</ref>

column3: SM Entertainment announced NCT Dream would release their first single album. It was revealed Jaemin would not be participating in the release due to complications from a [[Spinal disc herniation|herniated disc]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2017/02/02/sm-releases-statement-regarding-nct-dreams-jaemin|title=SM releases statement regarding NCT Dream's Jaemin|date=February 2
column4: 2017|website=SBS}}</ref> The group's single album
column5: ''[[The First (single)|The First]]

column7: \"My First and Last\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/7685137/nct-dream-charm-funk-pop-my-first-last-video|title=NCT Dream Charm With Funk and Pop in 'My First & Last' Video: Watch|date=August 2
column8: 2017|website=Billboard}}</ref> The album debuted at number one on the Gaon Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaonchart.co.kr/main/section/chart/album.gaon?termGbn=week&hitYear=2017&targetTime=06&nationGbn=T|title=국내 대표 음악 차트 가온차트!|website=Gaon Chart|accessdate=February 17

column13: \"Dunk Shot\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mwave.me/en/news/news/view/112437/%5BVideo%5D-SF9-and-NCT-DREAM-Perform-Comeback-Stages-on-%E2%80%B2M-COUNTDOWN%E2%80%B2|title=[Video] SF9 and NCT DREAM Perform Comeback Stages on ′M COUNTDOWN′|date=February 10

column16: marking the first music show win for a NCT unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2017/02/15/nct-dream-get-first-ever-win-my-first-and-last|title=NCT Dream get first ever win with 'My First and Last'|date=February 15

Chase]] | successor2 = [[Hugh McCulloch]] | state3 = [[Maine]] | district3 = {{ushr|ME|2|2nd}} | term_start3 = March 4, 1841 | term_end3 = March 3, 1843 | predecessor3 = [[Albert Smith (Maine politician)|Albert Smith]] | successor3 = [[Robert P. Dunlap]] | birth_name = William Pitt Fessenden | birth_date = {{birth date|1806|10|16}} | birth_place = [[Boscawen, New Hampshire]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1869|9|8|1806|10|16}} | death_place = [[Portland, Maine]], U.S. | restingplace = [[Evergreen Cemetery (Portland, Maine)|Evergreen Cemetery]] | party = [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] {{small|(Before 1854)}}
[[Opposition Party (Northern U.S.)|Opposition]] {{small|(1854–1860)}}
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] {{small|(1860–1869)}} | spouse = Ellen Deering | children = 5, including Samuel Fessenden, [[James Deering Fessenden|James]], [[Francis Fessenden|Francis]] | education = [[Bowdoin College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} | signature = Appletons' Fessenden Samuel - William Pitt signature.jpg }} '''William Pitt Fessenden''' (October 16, 1806{{spaced ndash}}September 8, 1869) was an [[Politics of the United States|American politician]] from the U.S. state of [[Maine]]. Fessenden was a [[United States Whig Party|Whig]] (later a [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]) and member of the [[List of United States political families#The Fessendens|Fessenden political family]]. He served in the [[United States House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] before becoming [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]] under President [[Abraham Lincoln]] during the [[American Civil War]]. A lawyer, he was a leading antislavery Whig in Maine; in Congress, he fought the [[Slave Power]] (the plantation owners who controlled southern states). He built an antislavery coalition in the state legislature that elected him to the U.S. Senate; it became Maine's Republican organization. In the Senate, Fessenden played a central role in the debates on Kansas, denouncing the expansion of slavery. He led [[Radical Republicans]] in attacking Democrats [[Stephen Douglas]], [[Franklin Pierce]], and [[James Buchanan]]. Fessenden's speeches were read widely, influencing Republicans such as [[Abraham Lincoln]] and building support for Lincoln's 1860 Republican presidential nomination. During the war, Senator Fessenden helped shape the Union's taxation and financial policies. He moderated his earlier radicalism, and supported Lincoln against the Radicals, becoming Lincoln's Treasury Secretary.Landis (2008) After the war, Fessenden was back in the Senate, as chair of the [[Joint Committee on Reconstruction]], which established terms for resuming congressional representation for the southern states, and which drafted the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. Later, Fessenden provided critical support that prevented Senate conviction of President [[Andrew Johnson]], who had been impeached by the House. He was the first Republican Senator to ring out \...''not guilty''\" followed by six other Republican Senators resulting in the acquittal of President Johnson.

column1: He is the only person to have three streets in Portland named for him: William
column2: Pitt and Fessenden streets in the city's Oakdale neighborhood.

column4: 1806.  His father was attorney and legislator [[Samuel Fessenden]].  His mother was Ruth Greene. The parents were unmarried. William was separated from his mother at his birth
column5: and he was raised by his paternal grandmother for seven years.{{clarify|date=February 2014}}

column1: He graduated from [[Bowdoin College]] in 1823 and then studied law. He was a founding member of the [[Temperance movement|Maine Temperance Society]] in 1827.<ref>{{cite book |last=Rolde |first=Neal |title=Maine: A Narrative History |year=1990 |publisher=Harpswell Press |location=Gardiner

column10: becoming chairman of the house committee to revise the statutes of the state.

column1: He was elected for one term in the [[United States House of Representatives]] as a Whig in 1840. During this term
column2: he moved to repeal the rule that excluded anti-slavery petitions and spoke upon the loan and bankrupt bills
column3: and the army. At the end of his term in Congress
column4: he turned his attention wholly to his law business until he was again in the Maine legislature in 1845–46. He acquired a national reputation as a lawyer and an anti-slavery Whig
column5: and in 1849 prosecuted before the [[United States Supreme Court]] an appeal from an adverse decision of Judge [[Joseph Story]]
column6: and gained a reversal by an argument which [[Daniel Webster]] pronounced the best he had heard in twenty years. He was again in the Maine legislature in 1853 and 1854.

column1: [[President of the United States|President]] [[Abraham Lincoln]] appointed Fessenden [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]] upon [[Salmon P. Chase]]'s resignation.  It was the darkest hour of national finances of the United States.{{According to whom|date=March 2018}} Chase had just withdrawn a loan from the market for want of acceptable bids
column2: and the capacity of the country to lend seemed exhausted. The currency had been enormously inflated:  the paper dollar was worth only 34 cents; gold was at $280/ounce. Fessenden at first refused the office
column3: but at last
column4: accepted in obedience to the universal public pressure. When his acceptance became known
column5: gold fell to $225/ounce. He declared that no more currency should be issued
column6: and
column7: making an appeal to the people
column8: he prepared and put upon the market the seven-thirty loan
column9: which proved a triumphant success. This loan was in the form of bonds bearing interest at the rate of 7.30%
column10: which were issued in denominations as low as $50 so that people of moderate means could take them. He also framed and recommended the measures
column12: which permitted the subsequent consolidation and funding of the government loans into the 4% and 4.5% bonds.

Fessenden began his service as Secretary of the Treasury on July 5
column2: 1864. The financial situation becoming favorable

column7: to return to the Senate
column8: to which he had now for the third time been elected.

column2: he headed the [[Joint Committee on Reconstruction]]
column3: which was responsible for overseeing the readmission of states from the former [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]] into the Union. He wrote its report
column4: which vindicated the power of congress over the rebellious states
column5: showed their relations to the government under the constitution and the law of nations
column6: and recommended the constitutional safeguards made necessary by the rebellion. At this point
column7: Fessenden was the acknowledged leader in the senate of the Republicans. He was considered a moderate
column8: rather than Radical
column9: Republican.

column1: During President [[Andrew Johnson]]'s [[Impeachment of Andrew Johnson|impeachment trial]] in 1868
column2: Fessenden broke party ranks
column3: along with six other Republican senators
column4: and in a brazen act of political betrayel
column5: voted for acquittal. These seven Republican senators were disturbed by how the proceedings had been manipulated in order to give a one-sided presentation of the evidence. He
column6: [[Joseph S. Fowler]]
column7: [[James W. Grimes]]
column8: [[John B. Henderson]]
column9: [[Lyman Trumbull]]
column11: <ref>[http://law.jrank.org/pages/13490/Andrew-Johnson-Trial.html \"Andrew Johnson Trial: The Consciences of Seven Republicans Save Johnson\".]</ref> and [[Edmund G. Ross]]<ref>[http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/john.htm \"The Trial of Andrew Johnson
column12: 1868\".]</ref> defied their party and public opinion and voted against conviction. As a result
column13: a 35-19 vote in favor of removing the President from office failed by a single vote of reaching a 2/3 majority.  After the trial
column14: Congressman [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin F. Butler]] of Massachusetts conducted hearings on the widespread reports that Republican senators had been bribed to vote for Johnson's acquittal.  In Butler's hearings
column16: there was increasing evidence that some acquittal votes were acquired by promises of patronage jobs and cash cards.<ref>David O. Stewart
column17: ''Impeached: The Trial of President Andrew Johnson and the Fight for Lincoln's Legacy'' (2009)

column1: He served as chairman of the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Finance|Finance Committee]] during the [[37th United States Congress|37th]] through [[39th United States Congress|39th Congress]]es (from 1861 to 1867)
column2: which led to his Cabinet appointment. He also served as a chairman of the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds|Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds]] during the [[40th United States Congress|40th Congress]]
column3: the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations Committee]] during the [[41st United States Congress|41st Congress]] and the [[U.S. Senate Committee on the Library]]
column4: also during the 41st Congress. In 1867
column5: he was one of two senators (the other was Senator [[Justin S. Morrill]] of Vermont) who voted against the purchase of [[Alaska]] from Russia.<ref>http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llej&fileName=017/llej017.db&recNum=249</ref> His last speech in the Senate was upon the bill to strengthen the public credit. He advocated the payment of the principal of the public debt in gold and opposed the notion that it might lawfully be paid in depreciated greenbacks.

column2: he was a regent of the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. He received the degree of [[LL.D.]] from Bowdoin in 1858
column3: and from [[Harvard University]] in 1864.
while serving in the U.S. Senate. He was interred at the [[Evergreen Cemetery (Portland
column4: Maine)|Evergreen Cemetery]] in Portland

column10: stayed in Maine to take care of the law practice his father had established.  Their fifth child was Mary Elizabeth Deering Fessenden who died in childhood.
