column3: which was responsible for overseeing the readmission of states from the former [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]] into the Union. He wrote its report
column4: which vindicated the power of congress over the rebellious states
column5: showed their relations to the government under the constitution and the law of nations
column6: and recommended the constitutional safeguards made necessary by the rebellion. At this point
column7: Fessenden was the acknowledged leader in the senate of the Republicans. He was considered a moderate
column8: rather than Radical
column9: Republican.

column1: [[File:Portrait of William P. Fessenden.jpg|thumb|left|[[Frederic Porter Vinton]]'s portrait of Fessenden
column2: posthumous. Circa. 1870]]

column1: During President [[Andrew Johnson]]'s [[Impeachment of Andrew Johnson|impeachment trial]] in 1868
column2: Fessenden broke party ranks
column3: along with six other Republican senators
column4: and in a courageous act of political suicide
column5: voted for acquittal. These seven Republican senators were disturbed by how the proceedings had been manipulated in order to give a one-sided presentation of the evidence. He
column6: [[Joseph S. Fowler]]
column7: [[James W. Grimes]]
column8: [[John B. Henderson]]
column9: [[Lyman Trumbull]]
column11: <ref>[http://law.jrank.org/pages/13490/Andrew-Johnson-Trial.html \"Andrew Johnson Trial: The Consciences of Seven Republicans Save Johnson\".]</ref> and [[Edmund G. Ross]]<ref>[http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/john.htm \"The Trial of Andrew Johnson
column12: 1868\".]</ref> defied their party and public opinion and voted against conviction. As a result
column13: a 35-19 vote in favor of removing the President from office failed by a single vote of reaching a 2/3 majority.  After the trial
column14: Congressman [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin F. Butler]] of Massachusetts conducted hearings on the widespread reports that Republican senators had been bribed to vote for Johnson's acquittal.  In Butler's hearings
column16: there was increasing evidence that some acquittal votes were acquired by promises of patronage jobs and cash cards.<ref>David O. Stewart
column17: ''Impeached: The Trial of President Andrew Johnson and the Fight for Lincoln's Legacy'' (2009)

column1: He served as chairman of the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Finance|Finance Committee]] during the [[37th United States Congress|37th]] through [[39th United States Congress|39th Congress]]es (from 1861 to 1867)
column2: which led to his Cabinet appointment. He also served as a chairman of the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds|Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds]] during the [[40th United States Congress|40th Congress]]
column3: the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations Committee]] during the [[41st United States Congress|41st Congress]] and the [[U.S. Senate Committee on the Library]]
column4: also during the 41st Congress. In 1867
column5: he was one of two senators (the other was Senator [[Justin S. Morrill]] of Vermont) who voted against the purchase of [[Alaska]] from Russia.<ref>http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llej&fileName=017/llej017.db&recNum=249</ref> His last speech in the Senate was upon the bill to strengthen the public credit. He advocated the payment of the principal of the public debt in gold and opposed the notion that it might lawfully be paid in depreciated greenbacks.

column2: he was a regent of the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. He received the degree of [[LL.D.]] from Bowdoin in 1858
column3: and from [[Harvard University]] in 1864.
while serving in the U.S. Senate. He was interred at the [[Evergreen Cemetery (Portland
column4: Maine)|Evergreen Cemetery]] in Portland
column5: Maine.  On December 14
column7: [[George Henry Williams]] addressed the U.S. Senate to deliver a tribute to his friend and fellow Senator.<ref>Williams
column8: George H. (1895). Occasional Addresses. Portland
column9: Oregon: F.W. Baltes and Company. pp. 21-28.</ref>

column2: [[Samuel C. Fessenden|Samuel Clement Fessenden]] and [[T. A. D. Fessenden|Thomas Amory Deblois Fessenden]]

column1: Fessenden married Ellen M. Deering in 1832
column2: and she died in 1857.  They had three sons who served in the [[American Civil War]]: Samuel Fessenden
column3: who was killed at the [[Second Battle of Bull Run]]
column4: the Brigadier-General [[James Deering Fessenden]]
column5: and the Major-General [[Francis Fessenden]]
column6: the latter of whom wrote a two-volume biography of his father
column7: ''The Life and Services of William Pitt Fessenden
column8: '' which was published in 1907.  A fourth son
column9: [[William Howard Fessenden]]
column10: stayed in Maine to take care of the law practice his father had established.  Their fifth child was Mary Elizabeth Deering Fessenden who died in childhood.

column1: Actress [[Beverly Garland]] is his great-great-granddaughter who dropped her real name Fessenden and went by her married name Garland.

column2: Fessenden is played by actor Walt Smith.

The fire jumped across the [[Peshtigo River]] and burned both sides of the town.<ref name = \"map\">{{cite web | last = Hipke | first = Deana C. | title = The Great Peshtigo Fire of 1871 | url = http://www.peshtigofire.info/gallery/burntmap.htm | access-date = 2013-01-26 }}</ref> Survivors reported that the [[firestorm]] generated a [[fire whirl]] (described as a tornado) that threw rail cars and houses into the air. Many escaped the flames by immersing themselves in the Peshtigo River
column2: wells
column3: or other nearby bodies of water. Some drowned while others succumbed to [[hypothermia]] in the frigid river. The [[Green Island Light (Wisconsin)|Green Island Light]] was kept lit during the day because of the obscuring smoke
column4: but the three-masted schooner ''George L. Newman'' was wrecked offshore
column5: although the crew was rescued.<ref name=\"Pepper\">{{cite web |url = http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/michigan/green-island/keepers.htm |title = Green Island Lighthouse |publisher=Terry Pepper |access-date=2010-11-26 }}</ref>

column1: The chapel where Sister Adele Brise and others sheltered from the fire has become the [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Good Help]]. The site is a [[Shrines to the Virgin Mary|Marian shrine]]
column2: where visitors can make religious [[pilgrimage]]s.<ref name=\"Cipin\">{{cite web |url= http://shrineofourladyofgoodhelp.com/htmPages/g_hst_p5.html |publisher=Shrine of Our Lady of Good Help |title=Troubles and Miracles |first1=Vojtech |last1=Cipin |year=2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131127043314/http://shrineofourladyofgoodhelp.com/htmPages/g_hst_p5.html| archivedate= 2013-11-27|access-date=March 1

column2: [[topography]] and ignition sources that created the firestorm
column3: primarily representing the conditions at the boundaries of human settlement and natural areas
column4: is known as the \"Peshtigo Paradigm\".<ref name=\"sun\">{{cite web | last = Tasker | first = G. | title = Worst fire largely unknown | work = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | publisher = | date = 2003-10-10 | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2003-10-10/news/0310100309_1_firestorm-chicago-fire-fire-museum | access-date = 2013-10-09}}</ref> The condition was closely studied by the American and British military during [[World War II]] to learn how to recreate [[firestorm]] conditions for bombing campaigns against cities in Germany and Japan. The [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II|bombing of Dresden]] and the even more severe [[bombing of Tokyo]] by [[incendiary device]]s resulted in death tolls comparable to the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]].<ref name=\"sun\" />

The fire jumped across the [[Peshtigo River]] and burned both sides of the town.<ref name = \"map\">{{cite web | last = Hipke | first = Deana C. | title = The Great Peshtigo Fire of 1871 | url = http://www.peshtigofire.info/gallery/burntmap.htm | access-date = 2013-01-26 }}</ref> Survivors reported that the [[firestorm]] generated a [[fire whirl]] (described as a tornado) that threw rail cars and houses into the air. Many escaped the flames by immersing themselves in the Peshtigo River
column2: wells
column3: or other nearby bodies of water. Some drowned while others succumbed to [[hypothermia]] in the frigid river. The [[Green Island Light (Wisconsin)|Green Island Light]] was kept lit during the day because of the obscuring smoke
column4: but the three-masted schooner ''George L. Newman'' was wrecked offshore
column5: although the crew was rescued.<ref name=\"Pepper\">{{cite web |url = http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/michigan/green-island/keepers.htm |title = Green Island Lighthouse |publisher=Terry Pepper |access-date=2010-11-26 }}</ref>

column2: first suggested in 1883
column3: was that the occurrence of the Peshtigo and Chicago fires on the same day was not just a coincidence
column4: but that all the major fires that occurred in Illinois
column5: Michigan and Wisconsin on that day were caused by the impact from fragments of [[Biela's Comet]]. This theory was revived in a 1985 book
column6: <ref>{{cite book|title=Mrs. O'Leary's Comet: Cosmic Causes of the Great Chicago Fire|last=Waskin|first=Mel|publisher=[[Academy Chicago Publishers]]|year=1985|ISBN=0897331818|location=|pages=}}</ref> studied in a 1997 documentary
column7: <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=11IujPVv8ys Fire From The Sky]. WTBS documentary
column8: 1997</ref> and investigated in a 2004 paper to the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://pdf.aiaa.org/preview/CDReadyMPDC04_865/PV2004_1419.pdf |title = Did Biela's Comet Cause The Chicago And Midwest Fires? |publisher=[[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]] |year=2004 |access-date=May 31
column9: 2012 |last=Wood |first = Robert M. |format=PDF |url-status=dead |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090325065110/http://pdf.aiaa.org/preview/CDReadyMPDC04_865/PV2004_1419.pdf |archive-date = March 25
column10: 2009 }}</ref> Scientists with expertise in the area argue that [[meteorite]]s cannot ignite a fire
column11: as they are cold to the touch when they reach the Earth's surface
column12: <ref name = \"Calfee\" /> and that there has never been a credible report of a fire anywhere having been started by a meteorite.<ref name = \"Calfee\">{{cite journal

column1: The chapel where Sister Adele Brise and others sheltered from the fire has become the [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Good Help]]. The site is a [[Shrines to the Virgin Mary|Marian shrine]]
column2: where visitors can make religious [[pilgrimage]]s.<ref name=\"Cipin\">{{cite web |url= http://shrineofourladyofgoodhelp.com/htmPages/g_hst_p5.html |publisher=Shrine of Our Lady of Good Help |title=Troubles and Miracles |first1=Vojtech |last1=Cipin |year=2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131127043314/http://shrineofourladyofgoodhelp.com/htmPages/g_hst_p5.html| archivedate= 2013-11-27|access-date=March 1
column3: 2013|url-status= dead}}</ref>

column2: [[topography]] and ignition sources that created the firestorm
column3: primarily representing the conditions at the boundaries of human settlement and natural areas
column4: is known as the \"Peshtigo Paradigm\".<ref name=\"sun\">{{cite web | last = Tasker | first = G. | title = Worst fire largely unknown | work = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | publisher = | date = 2003-10-10 | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2003-10-10/news/0310100309_1_firestorm-chicago-fire-fire-museum | access-date = 2013-10-09}}</ref> The condition was closely studied by the American and British military during [[World War II]] to learn how to recreate [[firestorm]] conditions for bombing campaigns against cities in Germany and Japan. The [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II|bombing of Dresden]] and the even more severe [[bombing of Tokyo]] by [[incendiary device]]s resulted in death tolls comparable to the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]].<ref name=\"sun\" />

2003 (UK subsidiary) | founder = Paul Share Steve Share Willie Horden | defunct = 3rd August 2010 | hq_location_city = [[Nuenen]] | hq_location_country = NL | area_served = Europe | key_people = Paul Share (CEO) | products = Buget video games, movies | owner = Paul Share, Steve Share | num_employees = 10 | num_employees_year = 2003 | parent = [[Midas Interactive Entertainment]] | divisions = Phoenix Games B.V. Phoenix Games LTD. Phoenix Games Asia | subsid = | website = {{URL|http://web.archive.org/web/20080821123206/http://www.phoenixgamesgroup.com|http://www.phoenixgamesgroup.com}} }} '''''Phoenix Games''''' is a partly-defunct Dutch video game publisher founded by Willie Horden, Paul Share and Steve Share, that released a large amount of low-effort titles for the Sony [[PlayStation]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]] and the Nintendo [[Wii]]. They had contracts with over 50 developer Studios around the globe. They published games based on [[Dingo Pictures]] films on the aforementioned consoles (barring Windows). Their last known published game was Lion and the King 3 on Nintendo DS, released on February 12th, 2010. The German Video Game Archive claims that they published 99 games on the PlayStation 2 alone.[http://www.gamereset.de/va/coverstrophen.html Coverstropfen] on German Videogamearchive

column4: '''Tejon Mountain Village''' is a proposed residential, commercial, and recreational development of pristine, rugged property in the [[Tehachapi Mountains]] owned by the [[Tejon Ranch]] Company in [[Lebec, California|Lebec]], southern [[Kern County, California]]. The development includes the largest conservation and [[Land use|land-use]] agreement in California history.<ref name=Californian080508>[http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1365314776/Tejon-land-pact-divides-environmentalists Stacey Shepard, \Tejon land pact divides environmentalists
column5: \" ''Bakersfield Californian
column6: '' May 8
column7: 2008]</ref> It was approved by the county's [[Board of Supervisors]] in October 2009. Opponents launched a legal challenge that was denied in state district court in April 2012.

Chumash ceremonial leader Mat Waiya said that Tejon Ranch had disturbed Indian cultural sites in the early 2000s but that the ranch had followed protocols since then.<ref name=Californian091006/> The developer has now agreed to provide a {{convert|2500|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility in the commercial center for a museum that could serve as a repository for artifacts.<ref name=Enterprise091009/>

column2: 000 acres comprising the Tejon Ranch was rejected by the Ninth [[U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals]] in June 2015.<ref name=TejonRanchNotOwnedCVBT>[http://www.centralvalleybusinesstimes.com/stories/001/?ID=28549 \"Tejon Ranch Not Owned by Indians

column1: [[Category:Proposed populated places in the United States]]

column2: '''Tejon Mountain Village''' is a proposed residential, commercial, and recreational development of pristine, rugged property in the [[Tehachapi Mountains]] owned by the [[Tejon Ranch]] Company in [[Lebec, California|Lebec]], southern [[Kern County, California]]. The development includes the largest conservation and [[Land use|land-use]] agreement in California history.<ref name=Californian080508>[http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1365314776/Tejon-land-pact-divides-environmentalists Stacey Shepard, \Tejon land pact divides environmentalists
column3: \" ''Bakersfield Californian
column4: '' May 8
column5: 2008]</ref> It was approved by the county's [[Board of Supervisors]] in October 2009. Opponents launched a legal challenge which was denied in state district court in April 2012.

column1: The pact between the Tejon Ranch Company and a coalition of environmental groups
column2: announced in May 2008
column3: <ref name=LAT080508>[http://www.latimes.com/news/la-me-tejon8-2008may08
column6: 25201.story Louis Sahagun
column7: \"Tejon Ranch pact would allow 26
column8: 000 homes on the range
column9: \" ''Los Angeles Times
column11: 2008]</ref> is designed to permanently protect {{convert|240000|acre|km2}} of the historic ranch
column12: including a vast amount outside the borders of the Tejon Mountain Village subdivision.

column5: and a maximum of 750 hotel rooms.<ref name=Californian090918/>

column1: <blockquote>Houses and apartments would be grouped in small enclaves around the lake and on the level tops of surrounding ridges. Larger lot custom homes would rise from the more remote hilltops in the northwest and northeast sections of the development area. Buildings would be designed to fit into the existing land rather than the land being molded to fit the buildings.<ref name=Californian090918>[http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x616725528/Massive-Tejon-project-headed-to-first-vote James Burger

column2: two 18-hole golf courses
column3: and about {{convert|320000|sqft|m2}} of support space for the \"commercial amenities.\"<ref name=Enterprise090918/>

column1: | caption             = 1667 edition of 120 hymns by [[Paul Gerhardt]]
column2: which contains \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" as its first item.<ref>[http://resolver.staatsbibliothek-berlin.de/SBB0001071A00010000 p. 6] of ''Pauli Gerhardi Geistliche Andachten'' at [[Berlin State Library]] website.</ref>

column1: | Title_English       = A Lambkin goes and bears the guilt

\"'''Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld'''\" (A Lambkin goes and bears the guilt) is a Lutheran [[Passion hymn]] in German by [[Paul Gerhardt]]. The hymn text was first published in [[Johann Crüger]]'s ''[[Praxis Pietatis Melica]]''
column2: starting from the lost 1647 edition. [[Wolfgang Dachstein]]'s 16th-century \"[[An Wasserflüssen Babylon]]\" melody is commonly indicated as its [[hymn tune]]
column3: although other settings exist.

column1: From the late 17th century Gerhardt's hymn text is used in larger vocal works such as [[Passion (music)|Passion setting]]s. With Dachstein's hymn tune it is included in the Protestant hymnal ''[[Evangelisches Gesangbuch]]''.
Paul Gerhardt's \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" was first published in 1647
column2: in a lost edition of Johann Crüger's ''Praxis Pietatis Melica''.<ref name=\"Korth\" /> The earliest extant print of the hymn
column3: in the ''Praxis Pietatis Melica'' of 1648
column4: indicates Wolfgang Dachstein's 16th-century \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" melody as its singing tune:<ref name=\"Julian\">{{cite book |last1=Julian |first1=John |date=1901 |chapter=Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld |title=[[:commons:Category:Dictionary of Hymnology|A Dictionary of Hymnology]] |volume=[[:File:A Dictionary of Hymnology Vol. 1.pdf|I]] |publisher=[[Dover Publications]] |pages=[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf/page343-972px-A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf.jpg 325]–[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf/page344-981px-A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf.jpg 326] |ref=harv}}</ref>

column1: The hymn was originally used as a [[Eucharist in Lutheranism|communion]] song.<ref name=\"Axmacher\" /> Later it was described as \"the masterpiece of all Passion hymns\".<ref name=\"Julian\" />

column2: allegoria della legge e della grazia 01.JPG|thumb|upright=1.15|[[Lucas Cranach the Elder]]
column3: \"Grace\" panel of the ''Allegorie auf Gesetz und Gnade'' painting (16th century)
column4: picturing the [[Lamb of God]]
column5: and referring in its inscription to [[John 1]]:29]]

column1: \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" has been characterised as a paraphrase of the [[Agnus Dei (liturgy)|Agnus Dei]].<ref name=\"Korth\" /> The hymn text is based on [[Isaiah 53]]:4–7 and [[John 1]]:29.<ref name=\"Julian\" /><ref name=\"Gerhardt\">[https://books.google.com/books?id=qGxFAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA19 V. Leiden Christi. Charfreitag. / 13. Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld] Paulus Gerhardts geistliche Lieder
column2: ed. Samuel Gottlieb Liesching
column3: 1853</ref> The hymn is in 10 [[stanza]]s of ten lines.<ref name=\"Julian\" /> The first four stanzas reflect on the [[Passion of Christ]] and the last four stanzas reflect on the believer's participation by receiving the sacrifice in form of the [[Eucharist]].<ref name=\"Axmacher\" /> The two middle stanzas are a transition in which the singer turns in devotion to remembering the sacrifice.<ref name=\"Axmacher\" />

column1: English translations of the hymn include \"A Lamb goes uncomplaining forth\".<ref name=\"Julian\" />

[[File:Stölzel-Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld-Berlin manuscript-p1.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|First page of a manuscript copy from around 1750 of [[Gottfried Heinrich Stölzel]]'s ''Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld'' Passion oratorio (1720)<ref>[http://resolver.staatsbibliothek-berlin.de/SBB0001902C000C0000 Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld: Passions-Oratorio di Stölzel] at [[Berlin State Library]] website.</ref>]]
After the mid-17th century Dachstein's \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" hymn tune
column2: [[Zahn number|Zahn No.]] 7663
column3: was commonly named \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\".<ref name=\"Zahn\">{{cite book |last1=Zahn |first1=Johannes |author-link1=Johannes Zahn |date=1891 |title=[[scores:Die Melodien der deutschen evangelischen Kirchenlieder (Zahn
column4: Johannes)|Die Melodien der deutschen evangelischen Kirchenlieder]] |volume=[https://archive.org/details/1508286757bsb11304502 IV] |location=Gütersloh |publisher=[[Bertelsmann]] |language=de |pages=[https://archive.org/stream/1508286757bsb11304502#page/n513/mode/2up 508–509] (No. 7663)
column5: [https://archive.org/stream/1508286757bsb11304502#page/n515/mode/2up 511] (No. 7669) and [https://archive.org/stream/1508286757bsb11304502#page/n519/mode/2up 515–518] (Nos. 7681–7688) |ref=harv }}</ref> With this tune
column6: the hymn has been included in several hymnals
column7: such as [[Christian Friedrich Witt]]'s ''Neues Cantional'' and the ''[[Evangelisches Gesangbuch]]''
column8: where it is numbered EG 83.<ref name=\"Axmacher\" /><ref>[[Christian Friedrich Witt]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tmg2drOjUWMC ''Neues Cantional mit dem General-Bass''.] Reyhern
column10: [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tmg2drOjUWMC&pg=PA58 p. 58]</ref> Gerhardt's hymn was however also sung to the tune of \"Herr Gott
column13: and several other melodies were composed for the text: [[Johannes Zahn]] lists three 17th-century melodies composed for \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" (Nos. 7681–7683)
column15: the first of which was composed for a reworked version of the text)
column16: and two from the 19th century (Nos. 7687–7688).<ref name=\"Zahn\" />

column1: The third part of a [[Passion (music)|Passion setting]] presented in [[Rudolstadt]] in 1688 opens with Gerhardt's \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" in the format of an [[aria]]
column2: using the \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" melody.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Spitta |first1=Philipp |author-link1=Philipp Spitta |others=Translated by [[Clara Bell]] and [[J. A. Fuller Maitland]] |date=1899 |title=Johann Sebastian Bach: His Work and Influence on the Music of Germany
column3: 1685–1750 |volume=[https://archive.org/details/johannsebastianb02spituoft II] |publisher=[[Novello & Co]] |pages=[https://archive.org/stream/johannsebastianb02spituoft#page/486/mode/2up 487–490] }}</ref>{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA110 110–112]}} [[Reinhard Keiser]] was the first composer who used Gerhardt's hymn in a [[Passion oratorio]] in [[Hamburg]]: his 1711 setting of Johann Ulrich König's ''Thränen unter dem Creutze Jesus'' libretto opens with it.{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA203 203–204]}} The second part of [[Johann Friedrich Fasch]]'s setting of the ''[[Brockes Passion]]'' libretto
column4: composed around 1717–1719
column5: opens with a [[chorale]] adaptation of \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\".<ref>{{IMSLP|work=Brockes-Passion
column6: FaWV F:1 (Fasch
column7: Johann Friedrich)|cname=Brockes-Passion
column8: FaWV F:1 (Fasch
column9: Johann Friedrich)}}</ref> A Passion oratorio performed in [[Gotha]] in 1719 contained an aria based on an excerpt of Gerhardt's hymn.{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA190 190]}}

column2: [[Gottfried Heinrich Stölzel]] composed a meditation of the [[stations of the Cross]] as a Passion oratorio which he titled ''[[Die leidende und am Creutz sterbende Liebe Jesu]]'' (The love of Jesus which suffered and died on the Cross)
column3: which is also known by its [[incipit]]
column4: ''Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld''.{{sfn|Schabalina|2008|pp=77–84}}<ref>{{RISM|452511199}}</ref><ref>{{IMSLP|work=Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld (Stölzel
column5: Gottfried Heinrich)|cname=Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld (Stölzel
column6: Gottfried Heinrich)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sing-akademie.de/209-0-2016.html?detail=petites-perceptions-ii---stoelzel&did=1333 |title=Die leidende und am Creutz sterbende Liebe Jesu / \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" / Ein Passionsoratorium von Gottfried Heinrich Stölzel |publisher=Sing-Akademie zu Berlin | accessdate = 14 March 2018}}</ref>{{sfn|Glöckner|2009}}{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA338 338–345]}} Composed for Gotha

column1: | caption             = 1667 edition of 120 hymns by [[Paul Gerhardt]]
column2: which contains \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" as its first item.<ref>[http://resolver.staatsbibliothek-berlin.de/SBB0001071A00010000 p. 6] of ''Pauli Gerhardi Geistliche Andachten'' at [[Berlin State Library]] website.</ref>

column1: | Title_English       = A Lambkin goes and bears the guilt

\"'''Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld'''\" (A Lambkin goes and bears the guilt) is a [[Lutheran hymn]] for [[Passiontide]] by [[Paul Gerhardt]]. The hymn text was first published in [[Johann Crüger]]'s ''[[Praxis Pietatis Melica]]''
column2: starting from the lost 1647 edition. [[Wolfgang Dachstein]]'s 16th-century \"[[An Wasserflüssen Babylon]]\" melody is commonly indicated as its [[hymn tune]]
column3: although other settings exist.

column1: From the late 17th century Gerhardt's hymn text is used in larger vocal works such as [[Passion (music)|Passion setting]]s. With Dachstein's hymn tune it is included in the Protestant hymnal ''[[Evangelisches Gesangbuch]]''.
Paul Gerhardt's \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" was first published in 1647
column2: in a lost edition of Johann Crüger's ''Praxis Pietatis Melica''.<ref name=\"Korth\" /> The earliest extant print of the hymn
column3: in the ''Praxis Pietatis Melica'' of 1648
column4: indicates Wolfgang Dachstein's 16th-century \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" melody as its singing tune:<ref name=\"Julian\">{{cite book |last1=Julian |first1=John |date=1901 |chapter=Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld |title=[[:commons:Category:Dictionary of Hymnology|A Dictionary of Hymnology]] |volume=[[:File:A Dictionary of Hymnology Vol. 1.pdf|I]] |publisher=[[Dover Publications]] |pages=[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf/page343-972px-A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf.jpg 325]–[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf/page344-981px-A_Dictionary_of_Hymnology_Vol._1.pdf.jpg 326] |ref=harv}}</ref>

column1: The hymn was originally used as a [[Eucharist in Lutheranism|communion]] song.<ref name=\"Axmacher\" /> Later it was described as \"the masterpiece of all Passion hymns\".<ref name=\"Julian\" />

column2: allegoria della legge e della grazia 01.JPG|thumb|upright=1.15|[[Lucas Cranach the Elder]]
column3: \"Grace\" panel of the ''Allegorie auf Gesetz und Gnade'' painting (16th century)
column4: picturing the [[Lamb of God]]
column5: and referring in its inscription to [[John 1]]:29]]

column1: \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" has been characterised as a paraphrase of the [[Agnus Dei (liturgy)|Agnus Dei]].<ref name=\"Korth\" /> The hymn text is based on [[Isaiah 53]]:4–7 and [[John 1]]:29.<ref name=\"Julian\" /><ref name=\"Gerhardt\">[https://books.google.com/books?id=qGxFAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA19 V. Leiden Christi. Charfreitag. / 13. Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld] Paulus Gerhardts geistliche Lieder
column2: ed. Samuel Gottlieb Liesching
column3: 1853</ref> The hymn is in 10 [[stanza]]s of ten lines.<ref name=\"Julian\" /> The first four stanzas reflect on the [[Passion of Christ]] and the last four stanzas reflect on the believer's participation by receiving the sacrifice in form of the [[Eucharist]].<ref name=\"Axmacher\" /> The two middle stanzas are a transition in which the singer turns in devotion to remembering the sacrifice.<ref name=\"Axmacher\" />

column1: English translations of the hymn include \"A Lamb goes uncomplaining forth\".<ref name=\"Julian\" />

[[File:Stölzel-Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld-Berlin manuscript-p1.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|First page of a manuscript copy from around 1750 of [[Gottfried Heinrich Stölzel]]'s ''Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld'' Passion oratorio (1720)<ref>[http://resolver.staatsbibliothek-berlin.de/SBB0001902C000C0000 Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld: Passions-Oratorio di Stölzel] at [[Berlin State Library]] website.</ref>]]
After the mid-17th century Dachstein's \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" hymn tune
column2: [[Zahn number|Zahn No.]] 7663
column3: was commonly named \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\".<ref name=\"Zahn\">{{cite book |last1=Zahn |first1=Johannes |author-link1=Johannes Zahn |date=1891 |title=[[scores:Die Melodien der deutschen evangelischen Kirchenlieder (Zahn

column1: The third part of a [[Passion (music)|Passion setting]] presented in [[Rudolstadt]] in 1688 opens with Gerhardt's \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\" in the format of an [[aria]]
column2: using the \"An Wasserflüssen Babylon\" melody.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Spitta |first1=Philipp |author-link1=Philipp Spitta |others=Translated by [[Clara Bell]] and [[J. A. Fuller Maitland]] |date=1899 |title=Johann Sebastian Bach: His Work and Influence on the Music of Germany
column3: 1685–1750 |volume=[https://archive.org/details/johannsebastianb02spituoft II] |publisher=[[Novello & Co]] |pages=[https://archive.org/stream/johannsebastianb02spituoft#page/486/mode/2up 487–490] }}</ref>{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA110 110–112]}} [[Reinhard Keiser]] was the first composer who used Gerhardt's hymn in a [[Passion oratorio]] in [[Hamburg]]: his 1711 setting of Johann Ulrich König's ''Thränen unter dem Creutze Jesus'' libretto opens with it.{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA203 203–204]}} The second part of [[Johann Friedrich Fasch]]'s setting of the ''[[Brockes Passion]]'' libretto
column4: composed around 1717–1719
column5: opens with a [[chorale]] adaptation of \"Ein Lämmlein geht und trägt die Schuld\".<ref>{{IMSLP|work=Brockes-Passion

column9: Johann Friedrich)}}</ref> A Passion oratorio performed in [[Gotha]] in 1719 contained an aria based on an excerpt of Gerhardt's hymn.{{sfn|Scheitler|2005|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NxxgXwt8UE4C&pg=PA190 190]}}

'''Antonio López Habas''' (born 28 May 1957) is a Spanish retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]], and the current [[Manager (association football)|manager]] of Indian club [[ATK (football club)|ATK]].

==Playing career==
Born in [[Pozoblanco]], [[Province of Córdoba (Spain)|Córdoba]], López had an unassuming career as a professional footballer, appearing in 48 [[La Liga]] matches over four seasons, eight of those for [[Sevilla FC]] to where he arrived in 1977 from local amateurs [[CD Pozoblanco]], first being assigned to [[Sevilla Atlético]].

He also represented [[Real Murcia]], [[Burgos CF (I)|Burgos CF]] and [[Atlético Madrid]] (no appearances for the latter), retiring from the game at only 29 years of age. In [[1981–82 Segunda División|1981–82]] he scored an astonishing 13 goals in 32 games for Burgos,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1981/11/12/pagina-18/1068857/pdf.html|title=3–0: No fue rival el Oviedo para el Burgos|trans-title=3–0: Burgos no match for Oviedo|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|first=J.A.|last=Paramo|language=Spanish|date=12 November 1981|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1981/12/21/pagina-15/1077240/pdf.html|title=Burgos 2, – Málaga 0|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=J.A.|last=Paramo|language=Spanish|date=21 December 1981|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1982/04/05/pagina-15/1084064/pdf.html|title=5–3: ¡Como un torrente!|trans-title=5–3: Like a tornado!|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=Emilio|last=Rey|language=Spanish|date=5 April 1982|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> which nonetheless suffered [[Segunda División]] relegation due to financial irregularities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1982/07/12/pagina-26/1085383/pdf.html|title=Burgos, un club al borde de la bancarrota|trans-title=Burgos, a club on the verge of bankruptcy|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=12 July 1982|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref>

==Coaching career==
López started coaching in the early 1990s, with [[Atlético Madrid B|Atlético's reserves]]. After one season apiece in amateur football, also in the [[Community of Madrid|Madrid area]], he took charge of the [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia national team]], first as an assistant to [[Xabier Azkargorta]], and eventually appeared with it them as head coach at two [[Copa América]] tournaments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.furialiga.fr/2019/06/18/azkargorta-et-lopez-en-bolivie-quand-la-verde-affrontait-guardiola-au-mondial-et-ronaldo-en-finale-de-copa-america/|title=Azkargorta et Lopez en Bolivie : Quand la Verde affrontait Guardiola au Mondial et Ronaldo en finale de Copa America|last=Benjamin|date=2019-06-18|website=Furia Liga|language=fr-FR|access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> He then returned to club action with [[Club Bolívar]], followed by a spell in his homeland with [[UE Lleida]], in the [[Segunda División|second division]] – whilst at the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] side, he briefly accumulated with his work as the national coach of the [[South America]]n country, which he left for good in 1997<ref name=LVG>{{cite news|url=https://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/deportes/2008/03/11/estudioso-teoria-futbol-sobrada-experiencia-banquillos-titular/00031205191605925677251.htm|title=Un estudioso de la teoría del fútbol con sobrada experiencia en los banquillos como titular|trans-title=A scholar of the football theory with head coach experience to spare|newspaper=[[La Voz de Galicia]]|language=Spanish|date=11 March 2008|accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> to sign with [[Sporting de Gijón]], being dismissed by the Spanish second-tier side shortly after his arrival.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1998/10/06/pagina-28/397403/pdf.html|title=Directiva y técnico, a la calle|trans-title=Board and manager, out you go|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=José Luis|last=Calleja|language=Spanish|date=6 October 1998|accessdate=11 April 2020}}</ref>

Three years after his last job, with [[Club Bolívar]], López was hired by [[Valencia CF]] as assistant to [[Rafael Benítez]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/interviews/Sacking-Rafael-Benitez-was-a-mistake-Habas/articleshow/50477422.cms|title=Sacking Rafael Benitez was a mistake: Habas|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|last=Mukherjee|first=Debayan|date=7 January 2016|accessdate=4 February 2020}}</ref> However, after the sacking of Italian [[Claudio Ranieri]], he managed the first team for 14 games as the ''Che'', the [[2003–04 La Liga|previous league champions]], eventually [[2004–05 La Liga|finished seventh]].<ref name=LVG/> Additionally, he worked at the [[Mestalla Stadium]] as youth system coordinator.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com.ar/nota?id=304423|title=Llega un bombero con agua fresca|trans-title=Fireman arrives with fresh water|publisher=[[ESPN]]|language=Spanish|date=25 February 2005|accessdate=17 March 2020}}</ref>

López became [[CD Tenerife]]'s second head coach of [[2005–06 Segunda División|the following campaign]] in November 2005,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://eldia.es/jornada/2005-11-15/9-LOPEZ-aqui-ahora.htm|title=LÓPEZ, \aquí y ahora\"|trans-title=LÓPEZ
column5: \"here and now\"|newspaper=[[El Día (Canary Islands)|El Día]]|language=Spanish|date=15 November 2005|accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> being fired himself after only six second level matches. Two years later
column6: he joined [[Juan Ramón López Caro]]'s staff at [[RC Celta de Vigo]] in the same tier. With the [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicians]] constantly battling relegation until the last month of [[2007–08 Segunda División|competition]]
column7: he was named [[Interim management|interim coach]] for the final three months<ref name=LVG/> as the team eventually managed to stay afloat; he was the third manager for the club in approximately one year.

'''Antonio López Habas''' (born 28 May 1957) is a Spanish retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]], and the current [[Manager (association football)|manager]] of Indian club [[ATK (football club)|ATK]].

==Playing career==
Born in [[Pozoblanco]], [[Province of Córdoba (Spain)|Córdoba]], López had an unassuming career as a professional footballer, appearing in 48 [[La Liga]] matches over four seasons, eight of those for [[Sevilla FC]] to where he arrived in 1977 from local amateurs [[CD Pozoblanco]], first being assigned to [[Sevilla Atlético]].

He also represented [[Real Murcia]], [[Burgos CF (I)|Burgos CF]] and [[Atlético Madrid]] (no appearances for the latter), retiring from the game at only 29 years of age. In [[1981–82 Segunda División|1981–82]] he scored an astonishing 13 goals in 32 games for Burgos,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1981/11/12/pagina-18/1068857/pdf.html|title=3–0: No fue rival el Oviedo para el Burgos|trans-title=3–0: Burgos no match for Oviedo|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|first=J.A.|last=Paramo|language=Spanish|date=12 November 1981|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1981/12/21/pagina-15/1077240/pdf.html|title=Burgos 2, – Málaga 0|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=J.A.|last=Paramo|language=Spanish|date=21 December 1981|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1982/04/05/pagina-15/1084064/pdf.html|title=5–3: ¡Como un torrente!|trans-title=5–3: Like a tornado!|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=Emilio|last=Rey|language=Spanish|date=5 April 1982|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> which nonetheless suffered [[Segunda División]] relegation due to financial irregularities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1982/07/12/pagina-26/1085383/pdf.html|title=Burgos, un club al borde de la bancarrota|trans-title=Burgos, a club on the verge of bankruptcy|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=12 July 1982|accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref>

==Coaching career==
López started coaching in the early 1990s, with [[Atlético Madrid B|Atlético's reserves]]. After one season apiece in amateur football, also in the [[Community of Madrid|Madrid area]], he took charge of the [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia national team]], first as an assistant to [[Xabier Azkargorta]], and eventually appeared with it them as head coach at two [[Copa América]] tournaments. He then returned to club action with [[Club Bolívar]], followed by a spell in his homeland with [[UE Lleida]], in the [[Segunda División|second division]] – whilst at the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] side, he briefly accumulated with his work as the national coach of the [[South America]]n country, which he left for good in 1997<ref name=LVG>{{cite news|url=https://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/deportes/2008/03/11/estudioso-teoria-futbol-sobrada-experiencia-banquillos-titular/00031205191605925677251.htm|title=Un estudioso de la teoría del fútbol con sobrada experiencia en los banquillos como titular|trans-title=A scholar of the football theory with head coach experience to spare|newspaper=[[La Voz de Galicia]]|language=Spanish|date=11 March 2008|accessdate=23 November 2018}}</ref> to sign with [[Sporting de Gijón]], being dismissed by the Spanish second-tier side shortly after his arrival.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1998/10/06/pagina-28/397403/pdf.html|title=Directiva y técnico, a la calle|trans-title=Board and manager, out you go|newspaper=Mundo Deportivo|first=José Luis|last=Calleja|language=Spanish|date=6 October 1998|accessdate=11 April 2020}}</ref>

Three years after his last job, with [[Club Bolívar]], López was hired by [[Valencia CF]] as assistant to [[Rafael Benítez]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/interviews/Sacking-Rafael-Benitez-was-a-mistake-Habas/articleshow/50477422.cms|title=Sacking Rafael Benitez was a mistake: Habas|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|last=Mukherjee|first=Debayan|date=7 January 2016|accessdate=4 February 2020}}</ref> However, after the sacking of Italian [[Claudio Ranieri]], he managed the first team for 14 games as the ''Che'', the [[2003–04 La Liga|previous league champions]], eventually [[2004–05 La Liga|finished seventh]].<ref name=LVG/> Additionally, he worked at the [[Mestalla Stadium]] as youth system coordinator.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com.ar/nota?id=304423|title=Llega un bombero con agua fresca|trans-title=Fireman arrives with fresh water|publisher=[[ESPN]]|language=Spanish|date=25 February 2005|accessdate=17 March 2020}}</ref>

López became [[CD Tenerife]]'s second head coach of [[2005–06 Segunda División|the following campaign]] in November 2005,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://eldia.es/jornada/2005-11-15/9-LOPEZ-aqui-ahora.htm|title=LÓPEZ, \aquí y ahora\"|trans-title=LÓPEZ

column3: <ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.ndtv.com/indian-super-league-2014/news/234371-isl-atletico-de-kolkata-sneak-into-semifinals-after-fikru-teferra-s-equaliser|title=ISL: Atletico de Kolkata sneak into semifinals after Fikru Teferra's equaliser|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=10 December 2014|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> meeting the same opponent once again and defeating them on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/isl-live-fc-goa-vs-atletico-de-kolkata-semifinal-2nd-leg/1/407359.html|title=ISL: Atletico de Kolkata beat FC Goa on penalties to enter final|publisher=[[India Today]]|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> In [[2014 Indian Super League Final|the decisive match]]
column4: against [[Kerala Blasters FC]]
column5: he benched marquee player [[Luis Garcia (footballer
column6: born 1978)|Luis García]] and also-compatriot [[Jofre]]
column7: for which he was praised by critics
column8: <ref>{{cite journal|title=আমি  হাবাসের সাহস দেখাতে  পারতাম না|trans-title=|publisher=আনন্দ বাজার পত্রিকা|page=19|date=21 December 2014}}</ref> and the side won thanks to a goal by [[Mohammed Rafique (footballer)|Mohammed Rafique]] in [[Overtime (sports)|extra time]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiansuperleague.com/news/1850-substitute-mohammed-rafique-hands-atletico-de-kolkata-the-title|title=Substitute Mohammed Rafique hands Atlético de Kolkata the title|publisher=Indian Super League|date=20 December 2014|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>

The '''National Film and Sound Archive of Australia''' ('''NFSA''') is [[Australia]]'s audiovisual archive, responsible for developing, preserving, maintaining, promoting and providing access to a national collection of [[film]], [[television]], sound, [[radio]], video games, new media, and related documents and artefacts. The collection ranges from works created in the late nineteenth century when the recorded sound and film industries were in their infancy, to those made in the present day.

The NFSA collection first started as the National Historical Film and Speaking Record Library (within the then [[National Library of Australia|Commonwealth National Library]]) in 1935, becoming an independent cultural organisation in 1984. On 3 October, Prime Minister [[Bob Hawke]] officially opened the NFSA's headquarters in Canberra.

==History of the organisation==

The work of the Archive can be officially dated to the establishment of the National Historical Film and Speaking Record Library (part of the then [[National Library of Australia|Commonwealth National Library]]) by a [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]] decision on 11 December 1935.

After being part of the National Library of Australia, and its predecessors, for nearly 50 years, the National Film and Sound Archive was created as a separate [[Commonwealth]] collecting institution through an announcement in Parliament on 5 April 1984 that took immediate effect.<ref name=\NAA CA 4123\">{{citation|title=CA 4123: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
column5: Central Office|url=http://naa12.naa.gov.au/scripts/SearchOld.asp?Number=CA+4123|publisher=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref> At that time
column6: an Advisory Committee was established to guide the institution.

column2: the name was changed to ScreenSound Australia
column3: the National Collection of Screen and Sound
column4: and changed again in early 2000 to ScreenSound Australia
column5: National Screen and Sound Archive. It reverted to its original name
column6: National Film and Sound Archive
column7: in December 2004.

column2: consequent on amendments to the [[Australian Film Commission]] Act which took effect on 1 July 2003
column3: it ceased to be a semi-autonomous entity within the Department of Communications
column4: Information Technology and the Arts and became an integrated branch
column5: later a division
column6: of the Australian Film Commission
column7: a funding and promotional body.

column2: the Liberal Government announced the creation of a new agency to be called [[Screen Australia]] which would incorporate the main functions of the Film Finance Corporation
column3: the Australian Film Commission (including the Archive)
column4: and [[Film Australia]]. Following elections in November 2007
column5: however
column6: the new Labor Government implemented an election promise to allow the NFSA to become a [[statutory authority]]
column7: similar to other major cultural institutions including the [[National Library of Australia]]
column8: the [[National Gallery of Australia]] and the [[National Museum of Australia]]. The NFSA Act became law on 20 March 2008 and came into effect on 1 July 2008
column9: with celebrations held that day.<ref>Massola
column10: James (2008) \"Innovative film sets the scene for the Archive's new role\"
column13: p. 7</ref>

The NFSA collection includes more than 3 million items

column1: * NFSA Restores is the NFSA's program to digitise
column2: restore and preserve

column1: * Non-Theatrical Lending Collection: Non-theatrical screenings take place on a non-commercial basis (no direct admission charge is levied) and are held by: educational

column1: <!-- This is a SUMMARY. Please don't add new information or details here
column2: but instead at the main article [[Australian Institute of Anatomy]]! -->

column1: [[File:National Film and Sound Archive viewed near McCoy Circuit.jpg|right|thumb|The National Film and Sound Archive fronts onto McCoy Circuit.]]

The building to which the Archive moved in 1984 was the home of the Australian Institute of Anatomy from 1931-84. Originally it held the anatomy collection of [[William Colin Mackenzie|Sir Colin MacKenzie]]. This collection included the heart of the celebrated Australian racehorse [[Phar Lap]].
The building is often classified as [[art deco]]
column2: though its overall architectural style is technically \"Late 20th Century Stripped Classical\"
column3: the style of ancient Greece and Rome but simplified and modernised.  It features a symmetrical façade
column4: a horizontal skyline
column5: classical columns and a central entrance. The decorative foyer features images of native flora
column6: fauna and Aboriginal art and motifs. Face masks of well-known scientists from the late 19th century and early 20th century are featured on the foyer’s walls as a reminder of its previous incarnation as the Institute of Anatomy.

column1: The building also features a landscaped courtyard
column2: theatre and research centre. In 1999
column3: the building was extended to accommodate the Archive's growth. The new wing’s design is in keeping with the Art Deco style of the main structure with details and finishes to match the original.

column1: The Ken G Hall Film Preservation Award was established in 1995 as a tribute to producer/director Ken G Hall. It is presented in recognition of an individual
column2: group
column3: or organisation
column4: for their outstanding contribution to the art of moving image and its preservation. It is presented to candidates where there is a significant link between their work and its impact or relationship to the Australian film industry. Examples of this contribution include technical innovation
column5: scholarship in the field
column6: involvement with the survival of film as an art form and as a cultural experience
column7: advocacy
column8: sponsorship and fundraising.

column1: The NFSA National Folk Recording Award was established in 2001 to encourage and reward excellence in Australian folk music recording. Award entrants are selected from recordings submitted each year to the National Folk Festival in Canberra. The judging panel comprises representatives from the National Folk Festival
column2: [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC Radio]] and the Archive.<ref>[http://www.nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/national-folk-recording-award/ NFSA 2008 National Folk Recording Award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302102212/http://nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/national-folk-recording-award/ |date=2 March 2014 }}</ref>

*2010 ''A Voice that was Still'' by [[Chloe and Jason Roweth]]
column2: with Jim McWhinnie

*2008 ''The Next Turn'' by Trouble in the Kitchen
*2005 ''Songs of the Wallaby Track'' by [[Dave de Hugard]]
*2003 ''Swapping Seasons'' by Kate Burke and Ruth Hazleton

column2: Lynne (24 April 2009) \"Uniting folk in triumph of voices\"

column4: p. 5</ref>

column1: The Cochrane-Smith Award for Sound Heritage<ref>National Film and Sound Archive: [http://www.nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/cochrane-smith-award-sound-heritage/ Cochrane-Smith Award for Sound Heritage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324125108/http://nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/cochrane-smith-award-sound-heritage/ |date=24 March 2012 }}</ref> recognises the achievements of a person who has made a substantial contribution to the preservation
column2: survival and recognition of sound heritage. It is named for [[Fanny Cochrane Smith]]
column3: who features on the only known recording of Tasmanian Aboriginal songs and language.

column1: The Orlando Short Film Award is an annual celebration of Australia’s best lesbian
column2: gay
column3: bisexual
column4: transgender or intersex short films. It recognises the nation’s cultural diversity and the role screen culture plays within the broader community.

column1: *2012 Craig Boreham 	Writer and director of ''Drowning''
*2011 [[Grant Scicluna]] 	Writer and director of ''Neon Skin''

column2: the NFSA Australian Cinematographers Society John Leake OAM Award for an Emerging Cinematographer is designed to enable emerging cinematographers to develop their craft
column3: and is presented annually at the [[Australian Cinematographers Society]]   Awards. The Award is named in honour of Australian Cinematographers Society (ACS) co-founder and industry icon John Leake OAM ACS (1927–2009). The judging panel will comprise the Federal President of the Australian Cinematographers Society
column4: the Chief Executive Officer of the National Film and Sound Archive
column5: and two other executive members of the ACS.

column1: The South East Asia Pacific Audiovisual Archives Association (SEAPAVAA) NFSA Preservation Awardrecognises the extraordinary efforts of individuals or organisations within the South East Asia and Pacific region in preserving or promoting audiovisual archiving in the region. It is presented at the annual SEAPAVAA conference.

column3: which inform or reflect life in Australia. It was established in 2007. Each year
column4: the Australian public nominates new sounds to be added with final selections determined by a panel of industry experts.

column1: * NFSA Restores is the NFSA's program to digitise
column2: restore and preserve
column3: at the highest archival standards
column4: classic and cult Australian films so they can be seen on the big screen in today's digital cinemas.

column1: * Non-Theatrical Lending Collection: Non-theatrical screenings take place on a non-commercial basis (no direct admission charge is levied) and are held by: educational
column2: cultural
column3: social and religious institutions; community groups; churches; film societies; government bodies; hospitals; libraries; museums and galleries.

column1: <!-- This is a SUMMARY. Please don't add new information or details here
column2: but instead at the main article [[Australian Institute of Anatomy]]! -->

column1: [[File:National Film and Sound Archive viewed near McCoy Circuit.jpg|right|thumb|The National Film and Sound Archive fronts onto McCoy Circuit.]]

The building to which the Archive moved in 1984 was the home of the Australian Institute of Anatomy from 1931-84. Originally it held the anatomy collection of [[William Colin Mackenzie|Sir Colin MacKenzie]]. This collection included the heart of the celebrated Australian racehorse [[Phar Lap]].
The building is often classified as [[art deco]]
column2: though its overall architectural style is technically \"Late 20th Century Stripped Classical\"
column3: the style of ancient Greece and Rome but simplified and modernised.  It features a symmetrical façade
column4: a horizontal skyline
column5: classical columns and a central entrance. The decorative foyer features images of native flora
column6: fauna and Aboriginal art and motifs. Face masks of well-known scientists from the late 19th century and early 20th century are featured on the foyer’s walls as a reminder of its previous incarnation as the Institute of Anatomy.

column1: The building also features a landscaped courtyard
column2: theatre and research centre. In 1999
column3: the building was extended to accommodate the Archive's growth. The new wing’s design is in keeping with the Art Deco style of the main structure with details and finishes to match the original.

column1: The Ken G Hall Film Preservation Award was established in 1995 as a tribute to producer/director Ken G Hall. It is presented in recognition of an individual
column2: group
column3: or organisation
column4: for their outstanding contribution to the art of moving image and its preservation. It is presented to candidates where there is a significant link between their work and its impact or relationship to the Australian film industry. Examples of this contribution include technical innovation
column5: scholarship in the field
column6: involvement with the survival of film as an art form and as a cultural experience
column7: advocacy
column8: sponsorship and fundraising.

column1: The NFSA National Folk Recording Award was established in 2001 to encourage and reward excellence in Australian folk music recording. Award entrants are selected from recordings submitted each year to the National Folk Festival in Canberra. The judging panel comprises representatives from the National Folk Festival
column2: [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC Radio]] and the Archive.<ref>[http://www.nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/national-folk-recording-award/ NFSA 2008 National Folk Recording Award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302102212/http://nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/national-folk-recording-award/ |date=2 March 2014 }}</ref>

*2010 ''A Voice that was Still'' by [[Chloe and Jason Roweth]]

column1: The Cochrane-Smith Award for Sound Heritage<ref>National Film and Sound Archive: [http://www.nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/cochrane-smith-award-sound-heritage/ Cochrane-Smith Award for Sound Heritage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324125108/http://nfsa.gov.au/about/awards-and-lectures/cochrane-smith-award-sound-heritage/ |date=24 March 2012 }}</ref> recognises the achievements of a person who has made a substantial contribution to the preservation
column2: survival and recognition of sound heritage. It is named for [[Fanny Cochrane Smith]]
column3: who features on the only known recording of Tasmanian Aboriginal songs and language.

column1: The Orlando Short Film Award is an annual celebration of Australia’s best lesbian
column2: gay
column3: bisexual
column4: transgender or intersex short films. It recognises the nation’s cultural diversity and the role screen culture plays within the broader community.

column1: *2012 Craig Boreham 	Writer and director of ''Drowning''
*2011 [[Grant Scicluna]] 	Writer and director of ''Neon Skin''

column2: the NFSA Australian Cinematographers Society John Leake OAM Award for an Emerging Cinematographer is designed to enable emerging cinematographers to develop their craft
column3: and is presented annually at the [[Australian Cinematographers Society]]   Awards. The Award is named in honour of Australian Cinematographers Society (ACS) co-founder and industry icon John Leake OAM ACS (1927–2009). The judging panel will comprise the Federal President of the Australian Cinematographers Society
column4: the Chief Executive Officer of the National Film and Sound Archive
column5: and two other executive members of the ACS.

column1: The South East Asia Pacific Audiovisual Archives Association (SEAPAVAA) NFSA Preservation Awardrecognises the extraordinary efforts of individuals or organisations within the South East Asia and Pacific region in preserving or promoting audiovisual archiving in the region. It is presented at the annual SEAPAVAA conference.
The following exhibitions have been developed by the NFSA:
* [[The Art of Sound (Exhibition)|The Art of Sound]]
column2: in collaboration with regional art galleries
in partnership with the [[National Portrait Gallery of Australia]]. The exhibition premiered in Canberra from 10 November 2017 – 4 March 2018
column3: followed by an Australian tour including [[Adelaide]]
column4: [[Gold Coast
column5: Queensland|Gold Coast]]
column6: [[Bathurst
column7: New South Wales|Bathurst]] and [[Geraldton]].

from 18 April to 18 August 2019. Developed by FilmArt Media and curated by designer Marion Boyce.
from 27 September 2019 to 9 March 2020. Developed by the [[Australian Centre for the Moving Image]].

'''Hatton William Sumners''' (May 30, 1875 – April 19, 1962) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Congressman from the [[Dallas, Texas]] area, serving from 1913 to 1947. He rose to become Chairman of the powerful [[House Judiciary Committee]].

==Early life and career==
Hatton Sumners, the second of three children of William A. and Anna Elizabeth Walker Sumners, was born near [[Fayetteville, Tennessee]] on May 30, 1875. He grew up on a farm in Lincoln County and attended local schools.<ref name=Sumners>[https://baylorarchives.cuadra.com/cgi-bin/starfetch.exe?QgID14lsjbYp8zWJvsu0Wt8HlfdX6ps3oLYSzUh9HPLokzGHPuBb3ixgF6QcwJkjAaMaKFHQXxMOGIWJlR48sGx@nuLe@m1XnRv@p1uDMN4/0007e3.xml Hatton Sumners Papers] #91, Baylor Collections of Political Materials, W. R. Poage Legislative Library, Baylor University.</ref>

In 1893, he moved to [[Garland, Texas]], near [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], at a time when the city was beginning to industrialize and was a booming business center. In 1895, as a 20-year-old newcomer to Dallas County, Sumners persuaded the Dallas City Attorney, Alfred P. Wozencraft, to let him \[[read law]]\" in his office
column5: a common alternative to law school.<ref>[http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html Old Red Museum
column6: Dallas County Historical Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629012503/http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html |date=June 29
column7: 2007 }}</ref> Sumners was admitted to the bar in 1897 and commenced practice in Dallas.

column1: Sumners was elected as prosecuting attorney of [[Dallas County
column2: Texas|Dallas County]] in 1900
column3: serving two non-consecutive terms.  As [[prosecutor]]
column4: he brought charges against gamblers in an attempt to clean up Dallas.  As a result of his investigations and his campaign against drinking and vice
column5: Sumners was not re-elected in 1902.<ref name=TexasHandbook>

column2: HATTON WILLIAM

column1: </ref> He continued his campaign against gambling and voting irregularities in Dallas
column2: ultimately influencing state legislation enacted to reform the system. After that
column3: Sumners was elected Dallas County prosecutor again.  Instead of continuing in that position for additional terms
column4: he accepted the presidency of the district and county attorneys' association of Texas in 1906 and 1907
column5: where he campaigned against betting interests.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>

column1: Sumners ran for and was elected in 1912 to an [[Texas's At-large congressional district|at-large seat]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the Sixty-third Congress
column2: taking office on March 4
column3: 1913.  He was the first of the 132 freshmen congressmen in that Congress to get a bill through the House; the bill made Dallas a port of entry for US Customs.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>  In 1914
column4: he ran for the seat from [[Texas's 5th congressional district]]
column5: which included [[Dallas]]
column6: Ellis
column7: [[Rockwall County
column8: Texas|Rockwall]]
column9: Hill

column1: Sumners was a lifetime defender of states' rights. He was quoted as saying
column2: \"There are but two sorts of government – a government by the people and a government the voice of which comes from the top downward. With us more and more
column3: the voice of the government is spoken in Washington downward to the people. What we need in America is a people conscious of their responsibility
column4: conscious of their power
column5: conscious they are the government and then get on the job.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sumners|first=Hatton|date=February 19
column6: 1942|title=We the People|url=|journal=National Association of Retail Druggists Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

column2: Sumners spoke out against the [[Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill]]
column3: introduced by a Republican congressman from [[St. Louis|Saint Louis
column4: Missouri]]. Sumners said that the bill's sponsors did not have adequate statistics to prove their case (that lynching should be a federal crime)
column5: that the bill would increase racial mob violence. Sumners also questioned the constitutionality of the bill and posited the bill ultimately impinged on [[states' rights]].<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/01/05/98966810.pdf \"Filibuster Delays Anti-Lynching Bill
column6: \" ''New York Times
column7: '' January 5
column8: 1922]</ref> He believed part of the solution to end lynching would start with local sentiment. In his zeal to protect states’ rights he stated the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill “would mark the greatest advance toward the obliteration of the states as independent governmental agencies which has yet been registered by any expression of legislative or public attitude.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ross|first=Charlie|date=January 7
column9: 1922|title=Dyer's Arguments in Favor of Antilynching bill; Answer Summers [sic] of Texas
column10: Chief Opponent|url=|journal=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> He also marked the bill as a direct threat to local and state responsibility stating
column11: “This bill strikes at the very heart of state sovereignty and the sense of local responsibility.  When you destroy these
column12: what sort of protection have the people who live in a community
column13: <ref>January 4
column15: page 803</ref>” and “it permits the Federal Government to lay coercive hands on states
column16: and establishes a precedent of sweeping encroachment on states’ rights.\"<ref>January 4

column1: Speaking on the House floor while some African Americans watched from the balcony
column2: Sumners attacked the bill using racial stereotypes: \"Only a short time ago... their ancestors roamed the jungles of Africa in absolute savagery…[Y]ou do not know where the beast is among them. Somewhere in that black mass of people is the man who would outrage your wife or your child
column3: and every man who lives in the country knows it.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kevincmurphy.com/uatw-legacies-shame.html|title=Uphill All the Way: The Fortunes of Progressivism
column4: 1919-1929 (Copyright KcM 2013)|website=www.kevincmurphy.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WBqedYHYMXAC&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=%22their+ancestors+roamed+the+jungles+of+Africa+in+absolute+savagery%22#v=onepage&q=%22their+ancestors+roamed+the+jungles+of+Africa+in+absolute+savagery%22&f=false|title=At the Hands of Persons Unknown: The Lynching of Black America|first=Philip|last=Dray|date=18 December 2007|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|via=Google Books|isbn=9780307430663}}</ref>

column1: Sumners served on the powerful [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives]] and was appointed regularly to investigate allegations of corruption among [[federal judge]]s. He served on the impeachment committees for three federal judges: [[George W. English]]
column2: [[Harold Louderback]]
column3: and [[Halsted L. Ritter]].<ref>Congressional Biography</ref><ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fsu04|title=SUMNERS
column4: HATTON WILLIAM|last=MONROE|first=MARY CATHERINE|date=2010-06-15|website=tshaonline.org|language=en|access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>

column2: Sumners became acquainted with U.S. Chief Justice [[William Howard Taft]] and worked with him to pass a bill amending the judicial code
column3: also known as the \"Judges Bill.\" Sumners appeared before the Supreme Court several times on behalf of Congress
column4: including for the Pocket Veto Case of 1928
column5: the McCracken Contempt Case of 1934
column6: and the Municipal Bankruptcy Act Case of 1936.<ref name=\"Sumners\" /> Sumners became Chairman of the Judiciary Committee in 1932.<ref name=\"TexasHandbook\" /> In 1934
column7: he drafted a constitution for the [[Philippines]]
column8: developing a reputation as an authority on constitutional law.<ref name=\"Sumners\" /> Sumners was responsible for bringing the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas|Federal Reserve Bank]] to Dallas.<ref name=\":0\" /> As a loyal Democrat
column9: he supported much of President [[Franklin Roosevelt]]'s [[New Deal]] legislation.

column1: He drew the line at Roosevelt's plan to expand the US Supreme Court
column2: after the Court began to rule that key parts of the New Deal were unconstitutional. Roosevelt announced his so-called [[Judiciary Reorganization Bill of 1937|court-packing plan]] in 1936. As Chairman of the Judiciary Committee
column3: Sumners discreetly worked in opposition. When the plan's bill was in trouble
column4: Sumners reportedly said
column5: \"Boys
column6: here's where I cash in my chips
column7: \" referring to his waning support for the President.<ref name=\"TexasHandbook\" />  Ultimately
column8: Chairman Sumners came out formally against the Court-packing plan. He and two other Texans
column9: Vice President [[John Nance Garner]] and Senator [[Tom Connally|Thomas T. Connally]]
column10: led the fight against the court plan because they saw the president’s request as a symbolic desire for unlimited power. Sumners
column11: as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee
column12: decided that the reorganization bill would not come up in his committee
column13: because he wanted to avoid it being sent to and passing in the full House. He traveled around the country making speeches about constitutional government. The bill never left his committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/jzc01|title=COURT-PACKING PLAN OF 1937|last=PATENAUDE|first=LIONEL V.|date=2010-06-12|website=tshaonline.org|language=en|access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>

column1: He faced two serious opponents in the 1938 election
column2: but was re-elected and was not seriously challenged again.
Sumners responded strongly to the lynching of Jesse James Payne
column3: a prisoner in custody of Sheriff Lonnie T. Davis in [[Madison
column4: Florida|Madison
column5: FL]]. Sheriff Davis was investigated for any wrongdoing associated with the lynching of Payne.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Jack. E.|date=January 1990|title=\"Whitewash\" in Florida: The Lynching of Jesse James Payne and Its Aftermath|journal=The Florida Historical Quarterly|volume=68|issue=3|pages=277–298|jstor=30146708}}</ref> Upon hearing the news
column6: Sumners warned Florida Governor [[Millard Caldwell]]
column7: “If these facts are true
column8: or approximately true
column9: this sheriff is not only guilty of a violation of official duty
column11: but he is guilty of a direct assault upon the sovereignty of the state.”<ref>Personal letter to then Florida Governor Millard Caldwell

column1: Sumners chaired the House Judiciary Committee when the [[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|Administrative Procedure Act]] passed on June 11
column2: 1946. The act governs the way administrative agencies of the federal government may propose and establish regulations and grants the judiciary oversight over all agency actions.<ref>USC §706</ref>
Sumners announced he would not seek re-election; he served seventeen consecutive terms.

column1: He was a member of the [[Henry Pomeroy Miller|Miller group]] in Washington.<ref>{{cite book |authorlink=Robert Caro |last=Caro |first=Robert A. |series=[[The Years of Lyndon Johnson]] |title=The Path to Power |year=1982 |publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf
column2: Inc.]] |location=[[New York City|New York]] |isbn=978-0394499734 |page=271}}</ref>

column1: Sumners introduced the [[War Powers Act of 1941]]. This act gave President Roosevelt increased powers to execute [[World War II]] in a more efficient manner. This legislation was passed by both houses and signed into law in three days.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Public Law 354 |url=http://legisworks.org/congress/77/publaw-354.pdf|website=legisworks.org|access-date=2019-01-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017131142/http://legisworks.org/congress/77/publaw-354.pdf |archive-date=October 17
column2: 2015 |via=Wayback Machine}}</ref>

column1: While Sumners started his time in Congress as a man viewed by some as unconcerned by racial violence
column2: he was outspoken against states and figures he viewed as ineffective in stopping lynching. Less than a decade after he challenged the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill
column3: Sumners wrote in response to lynchings in Mississippi in 1931
column4: “What we want to do is to have a meeting to oppose lynchings in Mississippi and to see if we can get Mississippi to do something about it
column5: and if we can get other states to become more effective in suppressing lynchings.”<ref>Personal letter to Mrs. Jessie Danie Ames
column6: May 12
column8: Dallas Historical Society
column9: HWS Collection

column1: In the wake of the lynchings of Roosevelt Townes and Robert McDaniels in 1937
column2: Sumners was asked to speak about anti-lynching legislation to the Mississippi Council of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching
column3: but declined
column4: writing
column5: “It has occurred to me that it would not be good strategy for me to make an address on the subject suggested at the Public Meeting to be held by your Council at [[Jackson
column6: Mississippi|Jackson]] on May 27<sup>th</sup>.  The meeting would be construed as being opposed to anti-lynching legislation; whereas
column7: to be effective it should be a meeting opposed to lynching. This suggestion is very important…everything should indicate that you are trying to stop mob violence and that this is the whole purpose of the meeting.”<ref>Personal letter to Mrs. L. W. Alford
column8: Chairman of the Mississippi Council of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching
column9: May 4

column2: an outraged Sumners sent the Governor of Mississippi a telegram that stated “If the press reports are even approximately correct
column3: and they seem to be
column4: these lynchings
column5: both with regard to lynchers and the officers involved
column6: were as dastardly a crime as cowardice could devise and brutality execute. It is the sort of thing which makes it hard for us who are trying to protect the governmental sovereignty of the states.  It will be effectively seized upon as a demonstration of the ability of states to govern. As one Southern man to another
column7: I hope I will not be considered impertinent by stating candidly my own reaction and that is that the State of Mississippi cannot escape this reflection upon its governmental capacity
column8: in fact cannot escape in effect becoming an accessory after the fact unless it is able to and does bring these lynchers and officers to speedy and adequate punishment.”<ref>Western Union Telegram to Honorable Hugh White
column9: Governor of Mississippi
column13: HWS Collection
column14: D-97.6.</ref> Sumners called for justice against anyone involved in the now-infamous lynchings including the sheriffs
column17: regardless of the crime charged against him
column18: for execution by some agency other than that provided by the laws of the country is a confession of unfitness to govern.”<ref>Personal letter to Attorney General of Alabama

column2: Sumners was the Director of Research for the [[Southwestern Legal Foundation]]. Sumners formed the Hatton W. Sumners Foundation in 1949
column3: which still awards loans and scholarships to worthy students.  The foundation is also a sponsor of the [[Internet]] project 'Vote Smart.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/voting_category.php?can_id=93666|title=Project Vote Smart|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=July 18
column4: 2010}}</ref> Organizations like the [[YMCA]]
column5: the Red Cross
column6: and his local church also benefitted from Sumner's generosity.<ref name=Sumners/>

column1: Sumners received an honorary doctor of laws from [[Southern Methodist University]] and the [[American Bar Association Medal]].  He died on April 19
column2: 1962. After services in the Highland Park Methodist Church in Dallas
column3: he was interred in the [[Knights of Pythias]] Cemetery in [[Garland
column4: Texas|Garland]]
column5: Texas.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>

column1: Sumners wrote ''The Private Citizen and His Democracy'' in 1959.
