'''Hatton William Sumners''' (May 30, 1875 – April 19, 1962) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Congressman from the [[Dallas, Texas]] area, serving from 1913 to 1947. He rose to become Chairman of the powerful [[House Judiciary Committee]].

==Early life and career==
Hatton Sumners, the second of three children of William A. and Anna Elizabeth Walker Sumners, was born near [[Fayetteville, Tennessee]] on May 30, 1875. He grew up on a farm in Lincoln County and attended local schools.<ref name=Sumners>[https://baylorarchives.cuadra.com/cgi-bin/starfetch.exe?QgID14lsjbYp8zWJvsu0Wt8HlfdX6ps3oLYSzUh9HPLokzGHPuBb3ixgF6QcwJkjAaMaKFHQXxMOGIWJlR48sGx@nuLe@m1XnRv@p1uDMN4/0007e3.xml Hatton Sumners Papers] #91, Baylor Collections of Political Materials, W. R. Poage Legislative Library, Baylor University.</ref>

In 1893, he moved to [[Garland, Texas]], near [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], at a time when the city was beginning to industrialize and was a booming business center. In 1895, as a 20-year-old newcomer to Dallas County, Sumners persuaded the Dallas City Attorney, Alfred P. Wozencraft, to let him \[[read law]]\" in his office
column5: a common alternative to law school.<ref>[http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html Old Red Museum
column6: Dallas County Historical Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629012503/http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html |date=June 29
column7: 2007 }}</ref> Sumners was admitted to the bar in 1897 and commenced practice in Dallas.

column1: Sumners was elected as prosecuting attorney of [[Dallas County
column2: Texas|Dallas County]] in 1900
column3: serving two non-consecutive terms.  As [[prosecutor]]
column4: he brought charges against gamblers in an attempt to clean up Dallas.  As a result of his investigations and his campaign against drinking and vice
column5: Sumners was not re-elected in 1902.<ref name=TexasHandbook>

column2: HATTON WILLIAM

column1: </ref> He continued his campaign against gambling and voting irregularities in Dallas
column2: ultimately influencing state legislation enacted to reform the system. After that
column3: Sumners was elected Dallas County prosecutor again.  Instead of continuing in that position for additional terms
column4: he accepted the presidency of the district and county attorneys' association of Texas in 1906 and 1907
column5: where he campaigned against betting interests.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>

column1: Sumners ran for and was elected in 1912 to an [[Texas's At-large congressional district|at-large seat]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the Sixty-third Congress
column2: taking office on March 4
column3: 1913.  He was the first of the 132 freshmen congressmen in that Congress to get a bill through the House; the bill made Dallas a port of entry for US Customs.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>  In 1914
column4: he ran for the seat from [[Texas's 5th congressional district]]
column5: which included [[Dallas]]
column6: Ellis
column7: [[Rockwall County
column8: Texas|Rockwall]]
column9: Hill

column1: Sumners was a lifetime defender of states' rights. He was quoted as saying
column2: \"There are but two sorts of government – a government by the people and a government the voice of which comes from the top downward. With us more and more
column3: the voice of the government is spoken in Washington downward to the people. What we need in America is a people conscious of their responsibility
column4: conscious of their power
column5: conscious they are the government and then get on the job.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sumners|first=Hatton|date=February 19
column6: 1942|title=We the People|url=|journal=National Association of Retail Druggists Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

column2: Sumners spoke out against the [[Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill]]
column3: introduced by a Republican congressman from [[St. Louis|Saint Louis
column4: Missouri]]. Sumners said that the bill's sponsors did not have adequate statistics to prove their case (that lynching should be a federal crime)
column5: that the bill would increase racial mob violence. Sumners also questioned the constitutionality of the bill and posited the bill ultimately impinged on [[states' rights]].<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/01/05/98966810.pdf \"Filibuster Delays Anti-Lynching Bill
column6: \" ''New York Times
column7: '' January 5
column8: 1922]</ref> He believed part of the solution to end lynching would start with local sentiment. In his zeal to protect states’ rights he stated the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill “would mark the greatest advance toward the obliteration of the states as independent governmental agencies which has yet been registered by any expression of legislative or public attitude.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ross|first=Charlie|date=January 7
column9: 1922|title=Dyer's Arguments in Favor of Antilynching bill; Answer Summers [sic] of Texas
column10: Chief Opponent|url=|journal=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> He also marked the bill as a direct threat to local and state responsibility stating
column11: “This bill strikes at the very heart of state sovereignty and the sense of local responsibility.  When you destroy these
column12: what sort of protection have the people who live in a community

column15: page 803</ref>” and “it permits the Federal Government to lay coercive hands on states
column16: and establishes a precedent of sweeping encroachment on states’ rights.\"<ref>January 4

'''Hatton William Sumners''' (May 30, 1875 – April 19, 1962) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Congressman from the [[Dallas, Texas]] area, serving from 1913 to 1947. He rose to become Chairman of the powerful [[House Judiciary Committee]].

==Early life and career==
Hatton Sumners, the second of three children of William A. and Anna Elizabeth Walker Sumners, was born near [[Fayetteville, Tennessee]] on May 30, 1875. He grew up on a farm in Lincoln County and attended local schools.<ref name=Sumners>[https://baylorarchives.cuadra.com/cgi-bin/starfetch.exe?QgID14lsjbYp8zWJvsu0Wt8HlfdX6ps3oLYSzUh9HPLokzGHPuBb3ixgF6QcwJkjAaMaKFHQXxMOGIWJlR48sGx@nuLe@m1XnRv@p1uDMN4/0007e3.xml Hatton Sumners Papers] #91, Baylor Collections of Political Materials, W. R. Poage Legislative Library, Baylor University.</ref>

In 1893, he moved to [[Garland, Texas]], near [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], at a time when the city was beginning to industrialize and was a booming business center. In 1895, as a 20-year-old newcomer to Dallas County, Sumners persuaded the Dallas City Attorney, Alfred P. Wozencraft, to let him \[[read law]]\" in his office
column3: a common alternative to law school.<ref>[http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html Old Red Museum
column4: Dallas County Historical Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629012503/http://www.oldred.org/history/social_history_1.html |date=June 29
column5: 2007 }}</ref> Sumners was admitted to the bar in 1897 and commenced practice in Dallas.

column1: Sumners was elected as prosecuting attorney of [[Dallas County
column2: Texas|Dallas County]] in 1900
column3: serving two non-consecutive terms.  As [[prosecutor]]
column4: he brought charges against gamblers in an attempt to clean up Dallas.  As a result of his investigations and his campaign against drinking and vice
column5: Sumners was not re-elected in 1902.<ref name=TexasHandbook>

column2: HATTON WILLIAM

column1: </ref> He continued his campaign against gambling and voting irregularities in Dallas
column2: ultimately influencing state legislation enacted to reform the system. After that
column3: Sumners was elected Dallas County prosecutor again.  Instead of continuing in that position for additional terms
column4: he accepted the presidency of the district and county attorneys' association of Texas in 1906 and 1907
column5: where he campaigned against betting interests.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>

column1: Sumners ran for and was elected in 1912 to an [[Texas's At-large congressional district|at-large seat]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to the Sixty-third Congress
column2: taking office on March 4
column3: 1913.  He was the first of the 132 freshmen congressmen in that Congress to get a bill through the House; the bill made Dallas a port of entry for US Customs.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>  In 1914
column4: he ran for the seat from [[Texas's 5th congressional district]]
column5: which included [[Dallas]]
column6: Ellis
column7: [[Rockwall County
column8: Texas|Rockwall]]
column9: Hill

column1: Sumners was a lifetime defender of states' rights. He was quoted as saying
column2: \"There are but two sorts of government – a government by the people and a government the voice of which comes from the top downward. With us more and more
column3: the voice of the government is spoken in Washington downward to the people. What we need in America is a people conscious of their responsibility
column4: conscious of their power
column5: conscious they are the government and then get on the job.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sumners|first=Hatton|date=February 19
column6: 1942|title=We the People|url=|journal=National Association of Retail Druggists Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

column2: Sumners spoke out against the [[Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill]]
column3: introduced by a Republican congressman from [[St. Louis|Saint Louis
column4: Missouri]]. Sumners said that the bill's sponsors did not have adequate statistics to prove their case (that lynching should be a federal crime)
column5: that the bill would increase racial mob violence. Sumners also questioned the constitutionality of the bill and posited the bill ultimately impinged on [[states' rights]].<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/01/05/98966810.pdf \"Filibuster Delays Anti-Lynching Bill
column6: \" ''New York Times
column7: '' January 5
column8: 1922]</ref> He believed part of the solution to end lynching would start with local sentiment. In his zeal to protect states’ rights he stated the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill “would mark the greatest advance toward the obliteration of the states as independent governmental agencies which has yet been registered by any expression of legislative or public attitude.\"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ross|first=Charlie|date=January 7
column9: 1922|title=Dyer's Arguments in Favor of Antilynching bill; Answer Summers [sic] of Texas
column10: Chief Opponent|url=|journal=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> He also marked the bill as a direct threat to local and state responsibility stating
column11: “This bill strikes at the very heart of state sovereignty and the sense of local responsibility.  When you destroy these
column12: what sort of protection have the people who live in a community
column13: <ref>January 4
column15: page 803</ref>” and “it permits the Federal Government to lay coercive hands on states
column16: and establishes a precedent of sweeping encroachment on states’ rights.\"<ref>January 4

column1: Speaking on the House floor while some African Americans watched from the balcony
column2: Sumners attacked the bill using racial stereotypes: \"Only a short time ago... their ancestors roamed the jungles of Africa in absolute savagery…[Y]ou do not know where the beast is among them. Somewhere in that black mass of people is the man who would outrage your wife or your child
column3: and every man who lives in the country knows it.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kevincmurphy.com/uatw-legacies-shame.html|title=Uphill All the Way: The Fortunes of Progressivism
column4: 1919-1929 (Copyright KcM 2013)|website=www.kevincmurphy.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WBqedYHYMXAC&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=%22their+ancestors+roamed+the+jungles+of+Africa+in+absolute+savagery%22#v=onepage&q=%22their+ancestors+roamed+the+jungles+of+Africa+in+absolute+savagery%22&f=false|title=At the Hands of Persons Unknown: The Lynching of Black America|first=Philip|last=Dray|date=18 December 2007|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|via=Google Books|isbn=9780307430663}}</ref>

column1: Sumners served on the powerful [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives]] and was appointed regularly to investigate allegations of corruption among [[federal judge]]s. He served on the impeachment committees for three federal judges: [[George W. English]]
column2: [[Harold Louderback]]
column3: and [[Halsted L. Ritter]].<ref>Congressional Biography</ref><ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fsu04|title=SUMNERS
column4: HATTON WILLIAM|last=MONROE|first=MARY CATHERINE|date=2010-06-15|website=tshaonline.org|language=en|access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>

column2: Sumners became acquainted with U.S. Chief Justice [[William Howard Taft]] and worked with him to pass a bill amending the judicial code
column3: also known as the \"Judges Bill.\" Sumners appeared before the Supreme Court several times on behalf of Congress
column4: including for the Pocket Veto Case of 1928
column5: the McCracken Contempt Case of 1934
column6: and the Municipal Bankruptcy Act Case of 1936.<ref name=\"Sumners\" /> Sumners became Chairman of the Judiciary Committee in 1932.<ref name=\"TexasHandbook\" /> In 1934
column7: he drafted a constitution for the [[Philippines]]
column8: developing a reputation as an authority on constitutional law.<ref name=\"Sumners\" /> Sumners was responsible for bringing the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas|Federal Reserve Bank]] to Dallas.<ref name=\":0\" /> As a loyal Democrat
column9: he supported much of President [[Franklin Roosevelt]]'s [[New Deal]] legislation.

column1: He drew the line at Roosevelt's plan to expand the US Supreme Court
column2: after the Court began to rule that key parts of the New Deal were unconstitutional. Roosevelt announced his so-called [[Judiciary Reorganization Bill of 1937|court-packing plan]] in 1936. As Chairman of the Judiciary Committee
column3: Sumners discreetly worked in opposition. When the plan's bill was in trouble
column4: Sumners reportedly said
column5: \"Boys
column6: here's where I cash in my chips
column7: \" referring to his waning support for the President.<ref name=\"TexasHandbook\" />  Ultimately
column8: Chairman Sumners came out formally against the Court-packing plan. He and two other Texans
column9: Vice President [[John Nance Garner]] and Senator [[Tom Connally|Thomas T. Connally]]
column10: led the fight against the court plan because they saw the president’s request as a symbolic desire for unlimited power. Sumners
column11: as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee
column12: decided that the reorganization bill would not come up in his committee
column13: because he wanted to avoid it being sent to and passing in the full House. He traveled around the country making speeches about constitutional government. The bill never left his committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/jzc01|title=COURT-PACKING PLAN OF 1937|last=PATENAUDE|first=LIONEL V.|date=2010-06-12|website=tshaonline.org|language=en|access-date=2019-01-15}}</ref>

column1: He faced two serious opponents in the 1938 election
column2: but was re-elected and was not seriously challenged again.
Sumners responded strongly to the lynching of Jesse James Payne
column3: a prisoner in custody of Sheriff Lonnie T. Davis in [[Madison
column4: Florida|Madison
column5: FL]]. Sheriff Davis was investigated for any wrongdoing associated with the lynching of Payne.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Jack. E.|date=January 1990|title=\"Whitewash\" in Florida: The Lynching of Jesse James Payne and Its Aftermath|journal=The Florida Historical Quarterly|volume=68|issue=3|pages=277–298|jstor=30146708}}</ref> Upon hearing the news
column6: Sumners warned Florida Governor [[Millard Caldwell]]
column7: “If these facts are true
column8: or approximately true
column9: this sheriff is not only guilty of a violation of official duty
column11: but he is guilty of a direct assault upon the sovereignty of the state.”<ref>Personal letter to then Florida Governor Millard Caldwell

column1: Sumners chaired the House Judiciary Committee when the [[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|Administrative Procedure Act]] passed on June 11
column2: 1946. The act governs the way administrative agencies of the federal government may propose and establish regulations and grants the judiciary oversight over all agency actions.<ref>USC §706</ref>
Sumners announced he would not seek re-election; he served seventeen consecutive terms.

column1: He was a member of the [[Henry Pomeroy Miller|Miller group]] in Washington.<ref>{{cite book |authorlink=Robert Caro |last=Caro |first=Robert A. |series=[[The Years of Lyndon Johnson]] |title=The Path to Power |year=1982 |publisher=[[Alfred A. Knopf
column2: Inc.]] |location=[[New York City|New York]] |isbn=978-0394499734 |page=271}}</ref>

column1: Sumners introduced the [[War Powers Act of 1941]]. This act gave President Roosevelt increased powers to execute [[World War II]] in a more efficient manner. This legislation was passed by both houses and signed into law in three days.<ref>{{Cite web |title:Public Law 354 ||url=http://legisworks.org/congress/77/publaw-354.pdf|website=legisworks.org|access-date=2019-01-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017131142/http://legisworks.org/congress/77/publaw-354.pdf |via=Wayback Machine}}</ref>
While Sumners started his time in Congress as a man viewed by some as unconcerned by racial violence
column2: he was outspoken against states and figures he viewed as ineffective in stopping lynching. Less than a decade after he challenged the Dyer Anti-Lynching Bill
column3: Sumners wrote in response to lynchings in Mississippi in 1931
column4: “What we want to do is to have a meeting to oppose lynchings in Mississippi and to see if we can get Mississippi to do something about it
column5: and if we can get other states to become more effective in suppressing lynchings.”<ref>Personal letter to Mrs. Jessie Danie Ames
column6: May 12
column8: Dallas Historical Society
column9: HWS Collection

column1: In the wake of the lynchings of Roosevelt Townes and Robert McDaniels in 1937
column2: Sumners was asked to speak about anti-lynching legislation to the Mississippi Council of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching
column3: but declined
column4: writing
column5: “It has occurred to me that it would not be good strategy for me to make an address on the subject suggested at the Public Meeting to be held by your Council at [[Jackson
column6: Mississippi|Jackson]] on May 27<sup>th</sup>.  The meeting would be construed as being opposed to anti-lynching legislation; whereas
column7: to be effective it should be a meeting opposed to lynching. This suggestion is very important…everything should indicate that you are trying to stop mob violence and that this is the whole purpose of the meeting.”<ref>Personal letter to Mrs. L. W. Alford
column8: Chairman of the Mississippi Council of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching
column9: May 4

column2: an outraged Sumners sent the Governor of Mississippi a telegram that stated “If the press reports are even approximately correct
column3: and they seem to be
column4: these lynchings
column5: both with regard to lynchers and the officers involved
column6: were as dastardly a crime as cowardice could devise and brutality execute. It is the sort of thing which makes it hard for us who are trying to protect the governmental sovereignty of the states.  It will be effectively seized upon as a demonstration of the ability of states to govern. As one Southern man to another
column7: I hope I will not be considered impertinent by stating candidly my own reaction and that is that the State of Mississippi cannot escape this reflection upon its governmental capacity
column8: in fact cannot escape in effect becoming an accessory after the fact unless it is able to and does bring these lynchers and officers to speedy and adequate punishment.”<ref>Western Union Telegram to Honorable Hugh White
column9: Governor of Mississippi

column14: D-97.6.</ref> Sumners called for justice against anyone involved in the now-infamous lynchings including the sheriffs
column17: regardless of the crime charged against him
column18: for execution by some agency other than that provided by the laws of the country is a confession of unfitness to govern.”<ref>Personal letter to Attorney General of Alabama

column2: Sumners was the Director of Research for the [[Southwestern Legal Foundation]]. Sumners formed the Hatton W. Sumners Foundation in 1949
column3: which still awards loans and scholarships to worthy students.  The foundation is also a sponsor of the [[Internet]] project 'Vote Smart.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/voting_category.php?can_id=93666|title=Project Vote Smart|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=July 18
column4: 2010}}</ref> Organizations like the [[YMCA]]
column5: the Red Cross
column6: and his local church also benefitted from Sumner's generosity.<ref name=Sumners/>

column1: Sumners received an honorary doctor of laws from [[Southern Methodist University]] and the [[American Bar Association Medal]].  He died on April 19
column2: 1962. After services in the Highland Park Methodist Church in Dallas
column3: he was interred in the [[Knights of Pythias]] Cemetery in [[Garland
column4: Texas|Garland]]
column5: Texas.<ref name=TexasHandbook/>

'''''Quiz''''' is a [[Play (theatre)|play]] written by [[James Graham (playwright)|James Graham]]. Originally commissioned by theatre producer, William Village,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.williamvillage.com/|title=William Village {{!}} Independent theatre producer and general manager|last=Village|first=William|website=William Village|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-07-02}}</ref> it made its world premiere at the [[Minerva Theatre, Chichester]], in November 2017, before transferring to the [[Noel Coward Theatre]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] in March 2018. The play centres on the true story of [[Charles Ingram]] and [[R v Ingram, C., Ingram, D. and Whittock, T.|the coughing scandal]] that surrounded his 2001 win of £1,000,000 on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]''.<ref name = \Cough\"/> In 2020
column5: the stage play was adapted for a TV series.

column1: ''Quiz'' is written by British playwright [[James Graham (playwright)|James Graham]].<ref name=\"Cough\">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43700097| title=Millionaire cough scandal: 'The most British crime of all time' | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=12 April 2018 | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> The play centres around the true story of [[Charles Ingram]] (who later came to be known as \"the Coughing Major\")<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/vdqdw9/15-years-of-the-coughing-major-who-wants-to-be-a-millionare |title=15 years since \"the Coughing Major\" |work=Vice |accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> and the coughing scandal that surrounded his 2001 win of £1

(UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' and the subsequent court trial.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/theatre/what-to-see/wants-millionaire-scandal-inspires-new-play-happened-next-coughing/| title=Who Wants to be Millionaire scandal inspires new play: what happened next to the coughing Major? | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date=16 February 2017 | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>

column3: booking for a limited period until 16 June.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/james-grahams-quiz-announces-west-end-transfer/| title=James Graham's Quiz announces West End transfer| work=[[The Stage]] | date=1 December 2017 | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/news/james-graham-quiz-west-end-transfer-who-wants-millionaire_45259.html| title=James Graham's Quiz to transfer to the West End | work=Whats On Stage | date=1 December 2017 | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> It was produced by William Village
column4: Playful Productions and Chichester Festival Theatre<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2017/james-grahams-quiz-announces-west-end-transfer/|title=James Graham’s Quiz announces West End transfer|date=2017-12-01|work=The Stage|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en-US}}</ref>. Sharon Ballard joined the original cast for the London run.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://officiallondontheatre.com/news/quiz-announces-west-end-transfer-casting-111407555/| title=Quiz announced West End On Stage Seating And Casting| work=Official London Theatre  | date=25 January 2018 | accessdate=4 May 2018}}</ref> Prior to the production transferring around 40% of the play was rewritten by Graham<ref name = \"Cough\"/>  and on stage seating added to provide a more studio like environment for audiences.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/james-graham-quiz-west-end-millionaire-seating_45619.html| title=James Graham's Quiz West End transfer to have onstage seating| work=Whats On Stage | date=25 January 2018 | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> Explaining the extensive rewrite Graham explained that the changes were:<blockquote>not because we weren't happy with what happened in Chichester
column5: but you learn so much when you do a tryout for a show
column6: so we streamlined the narrative
column7: I reordered some of the structure
column8: we had to think about a West End proscenium Victorian theatre
column9: which is very different to a studio theatre in Chichester. In addition
column10: people that were involved in the production of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'' had seen the show in Chichester and had provided additional information
column11: which in turn had allowed Graham to enhance the play. One who attended
column13: was the erstwhile host of the show
column14: Chris Tarrant. He would later write a piece for the ''Daily Mail'' saying the show was entertaining but Ingram was guilty. <ref name = \"Cough\"/>

column1: The audience are given the opportunity to act as the jury via electronic voting<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/nov/19/quiz-minerva-chichester-review-james-graham-who-wants-to-be-a-millionaire | title=James Graham has all the right answers| work=[[The Guardian]]| date=19 November 2017 | accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> after each act
column2: where they will have witnessed the arguments for the prosecution and the defence to decide whether Ingram was guilty.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/reviews/quiz-review-noel-coward-theatre-who-wants-millionaire-cast-tickets-james-graham-a8299351.html | title=In James Graham's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire play

At new West End play Quiz you get to decide| work=[[i (newspaper)|I]]  | date=11 April 2018 | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref>

column1: The West End production was nominated for two Olivier Awards in 2019: Best New Comedy and Best Actor in a Supporting Role (Keir Charles).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://officiallondontheatre.com/olivier-awards/year/2019/|title=Winners list for the Olivier Awards 2019 with Mastercard {{!}} Official Website|website=Olivier Awards|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-07-30}}</ref>

Quiz will tour the UK and Ireland between August - November 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://quiztheplay.co.uk/|title=Quiz the Play|website=Quiz the Play Official Website|language=en-GB|access-date=2020-01-23}}</ref>

'''''Quiz''''' is a [[Play (theatre)|play]] written by [[James Graham (playwright)|James Graham]]. Originally commissioned by theatre producer, William Village,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.williamvillage.com/|title=William Village {{!}} Independent theatre producer and general manager|last=Village|first=William|website=William Village|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-07-02}}</ref> it made its world premiere at the [[Minerva Theatre, Chichester]], in November 2017, before transferring to the [[Noel Coward Theatre]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] in March 2018. The play centres on the true story of [[Charles Ingram]] and [[R v Ingram, C., Ingram, D. and Whittock, T.|the coughing scandal]] that surrounded his 2001 win of £1,000,000 on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]''.<ref name = \Cough\"/> In 2020
column3: the stage play was adapted for a TV series.

column1: ''Quiz'' is written by British playwright [[James Graham (playwright)|James Graham]].<ref name=\"Cough\">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43700097| title=Millionaire cough scandal: 'The most British crime of all time' | publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=12 April 2018 | accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> The play centres around the true story of [[Charles Ingram]] (who later came to be known as \"the Coughing Major\")<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/vdqdw9/15-years-of-the-coughing-major-who-wants-to-be-a-millionare |title=15 years since \"the Coughing Major\" |work=Vice |accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> and the coughing scandal that surrounded his 2001 win of £1
column3: 000 on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' and the subsequent court trial.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/theatre/what-to-see/wants-millionaire-scandal-inspires-new-play-happened-next-coughing/| title=Who Wants to be Millionaire scandal inspires new play: what happened next to the coughing Major? | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date=16 February 2017 | accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>

column2: a major in the [[British Army]] entered British quiz show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'' in September 2001. Suspicions arose during filming after coughing was heard loudly adjacent to the correct answers. A sound technician informed [[Celador]] CEO Paul Smith of their suspicions
column3: with filming allowed to continue and the tapes reviewed after filming had completed.<ref name=mf /> Ingram eventually won the million pounds
column4: <ref name=mf /> however upon reviewing the tapes and each cough heard
column5: Ingram was accused of cheating by having his wife
column6: Diana
column7: and an accomplice
column8: Tecwen Whittock
column9: cough as Ingram announced the correct answer from the available choices.<ref name=mf /><ref>{{cite web|author=Jonathan Evans |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/coughing-major-welsh-accomplice-who-8467202 |title=\"Coughing Major\" and his Welsh accomplice
column10: who cheated their way to Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? jackpot

column12: Who Wants to be a Millionaire bosses tell 'cheating major' Charles Ingram |publisher=BT |date=10 September 2016 |accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> Ingram \"refuted\" the claims.<ref name=mf>{{cite episode

column6: a jury declared the Ingrams and Whittock guilty of [[procuring the execution of a valuable security by deception]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insidetime.org/%EF%BF%BCbad-show-quiz-cough-millionaire-major/ |title=Bad show: The Quiz
column7: The Cough and the Millionaire Major |work=Inside Time |accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> The Ingrams were sentenced to an 18-month [[suspended sentence]] and a fine of £15
column8: 000 plus £10
column9: 000 for costs each. Whittock received a 12-month suspended sentence with a £10
column11: 500 costs order.<ref name=jail>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2910119.stm |title=Millionaire trio escape jail |publisher=BBC News |date=8 April 2003 |accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref>

column1: Graham was a teenager when ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?'' first appeared on British television in 1998<ref name = \"teen\"/> and became \"fixated\" by the subsequent trial and what he describes as the most \"British crime in the history of the world.\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/theatre/james-graham-on-why-the-quiz-scandal-is-the-most-british-crime-in-history-a3811246.html| title=James Graham on why the Quiz scandal is 'the most British crime in history'| work=[[Evening Standard]] | date=11 April 2018 | accessdate=3 May 2018}}</ref> He later received a copy of the 2015 book ''Bad Show: The Quiz
column2: the Cough

{{short description|Wikipedia list article}}
This list of '''phylogenetic tree viewing software''' is a compilation of software tools and web portals used in visualising [[phylogenetic trees]].

==Online software==
{| class=\wikitable sortable\"

column1: |<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cazaux|first=Bastien|last2=Castel|first2=Guillaume|last3=Rivals|first3=Eric|date=2019-01-14|title=AQUAPONY: visualization and interpretation of phylogeographic information on phylogenetic trees|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=35|issue=17|pages=3163–3165|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btz011|pmid=30649190|issn=1367-4803|url=https://hal-lirmm.ccsd.cnrs.fr/lirmm-01980994/file/aquapony-ms.pdf}}</ref>
| an online tool for phylogenetic tree view (newick format) that allows multiple sequence alignments to be shown together with the trees (fasta format)

'''Marco Simone''' ({{IPA-it|ˈmarko siˈmoːne}}; born 7 January 1969) is an Italian former professional [[association football|football]]er, who played as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] or [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]. He most prominently played for [[A.C. Milan]], with whom he won four [[Serie A]] championships and two [[UEFA Champions League]] titles, as well as French club [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]], and Monégasque outfit [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]]. At international level, Simone played four games for the [[Italy national football team|Italian national team]].

As a manager, Simone, has also served as the head coach of [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in [[Ligue 2]], and [[FC Lausanne-Sport|Lausanne-Sport]].

==Playing career==

===Early career===
Simone was born in [[Castellanza]]. He debuted in [[Serie A]] for [[Como Calcio 1907|Como]] on 11 January 1987. After a few appearances in the top-flight Serie A, he was put [[loan (football)|on loan]] at [[A.S.D. F.C. Alzano|Virescit Boccaleone]] in the secondary [[Serie C1]] league. He scored 15 goals for Virescit in the 1987–88 season, and finished as top scorer of the Serie C1 league.<ref name=magliarossonera.it>{{cite web|title=Marco Simone|url=http://www.magliarossonera.it/protagonisti/Gioc-Simone.html|publisher=Maglia Rossonera|accessdate=13 May 2015|language=Italian}}</ref>

He returned to [[Como Calcio 1907|Como]] for the [[1988–89 Serie A|1988–89 Serie A season]], in which he scored 6 goals. Como finished dead last in the tournament, and was [[relegated]] to [[Serie B]].

===Milan===
In the summer of 1989, Simone was brought into the squad of third-place finishers [[A.C. Milan]] by manager [[Arrigo Sacchi]]. His stay at Milan would be long and successful, as he won the 1990 [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] under manager Sacchi, as well as four Serie A titles in five years from 1992 to 1996 and the 1994 [[UEFA Champions League]] under the management of [[Fabio Capello]].<ref name=magliarossonera.it/><ref name=\A.C. Milan Hall of Fame: Marco Simone\">{{cite web|url=https://www.acmilan.com/en/marco-simone|title=A.C. Milan Hall of Fame: Marco Simone|website=acmilan.com|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>

column1: His best season for Milan came during the [[1994–95 Serie A|1994–95 Serie A season]]
column2: where he scored 17 goals in 30 games
column3: as well as 4 in the Champions League
column4: for a total of 21 goals in all competitions
column5: as Milan reached the [[1995 UEFA Champions League Final]]
column6: only to be defeated by [[Ajax F.C.|Ajax]]. He also managed 11 goals in all competitions during the [[1995–96 A.C. Milan season|1995–96 season]]
column7: 8 of which came in [[1995–96 Serie A|Serie A]]
column8: finishing as the club's second highest goalscorer behind [[George Weah]] as Milan won the Serie A title. Despite competing for the attacking spots at Milan with the three [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] award winners [[Marco van Basten]] (1992)
column9: [[Roberto Baggio]] (1993) and [[George Weah]] (1995) (as well as the presence of [[Ruud Gullit]]
column13: [[Jean-Pierre Papin]]
column16: he scored a total of 74 goals in 245 games in all competitions for Milan.<ref name=magliarossonera.it/><ref>{{in lang|da}} [http://www.acmilandk.net/club/index.php?module=pagesetter&func=viewpub&tid=3&pid=4 Marco Simone] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928125702/http://www.acmilandk.net/club/index.php?module=pagesetter&func=viewpub&tid=3&pid=4 |date=28 September 2007 }} at ''ACMilan.dk''</ref>

column2: Simone also made his senior debut for the [[Italy national football team|Italian national team]] on 19 December 1992
column3: under then national team manager Arrigo Sacchi
column4: in a 2–1 away win in a [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|1994 World Cup qualifier]] against [[Malta national football team|Malta]]. He would go on to play four games in total for the national team between 1992 and 1996
column5: but did not score any goals for Italy.<ref name=magliarossonera.it/><ref name=\"figc\">{{cite web|url=http://www.figc.it/nazionali/DettaglioConvocato?codiceConvocato=27&squadra=2|title=Nazionale in cifre: Simone
column6: Marco|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref>

column2: Monaco and return to Italy===
Simone moved abroad to play for French club [[Paris Saint-Germain FC|Paris Saint-Germain]]
column3: with whom he won both domestic cups in his first season. He scored in both the [[1998 Coupe de la Ligue Final|Coupe de la Ligue]] final and the [[1998 Coupe de France Final|Coupe de France]] final against [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] and [[RC Lens|Lens]] respectively.<ref>{{cite news
Coupe de la Ligue 97-98
Coupe de France 97-98

column1: |accessdate=3 January 2020}}</ref> He transferred to [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] in 1999. He scored 21 goals and made 15 assists in 34 games during the [[1999–2000 French Division 1|1999–2000 season]]
column2: and helped Monaco win the [[Ligue 1]] championship in 2000. He returned to Milan for parts of the [[2001–02 Serie A|2001–02 Serie A season]]
column3: scoring his last goal with the Rossoneri in Coppa Italia against Lazio in 2002. He returned to Monaco
column4: but rarely played during the [[2002–03 Ligue 1]] season.<ref name=magliarossonera.it/>

column1: Following an unsuccessful [[2003–04 Ligue 1|season]] playing for [[OGC Nice]]
column2: he retired from football in 2004
column3: at the age of 35. He made a short come-back as he played a single game for [[Serie C2]] club [[A.C. Legnano|Legnano]] in 2005.<ref name=magliarossonera.it/>

column2: gifted with pace
column3: good movement
column4: an eye for goal
column5: and excellent technique. He was capable of playing in several attacking positions
column6: and was best used as a [[Forward (association football)#Second striker|second striker]]
column7: due to his small stature and slender physical build
column8: although he was also capable of playing in a [[Forward (association football)#Centre-forward|central role]] as a main [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]]
column9: or even as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]].<ref name=magliarossonera.it/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.milannews.it/terza-pagina-milanday/l-uomo-in-piu-36089 |title=L'uomo in più |publisher=MilanNews.it |language=Italian |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=21 March 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.football-italia.net/68275/simone-appointed-tours |title=Simone appointed at Tours |publisher=Football Italia |date=25 June 2015 |accessdate=21 March 2020 }}</ref>

{{Politics of Argentina}}
The '''Constitution of Argentina''' is the basic governing document of [[Argentina]], and the primary source of existing [[Law of Argentina|law in Argentina]]. [[Argentine Constitution of 1853|Its first version]] was written in 1853 by a Constitutional Assembly gathered in [[Santa Fe, Argentina|Santa Fe]], and the doctrinal basis was taken in part from the [[United States Constitution]]. It was then reformed in 1860, 1866, 1898, 1949, 1957 (which mainly repealed the 1949 reform), and the current version is the [[1994 reform of the Argentine Constitution|reformed text of 1994]].

==History==
[[Image:JuanBaustistaAlberdi.JPG|thumb|230px|[[Juan Bautista Alberdi]], the legal scholar who drafted the 1853 Constitution.]] 
The first attempt to divide political power in [[Argentina]] was during the government created after the [[May Revolution]] (Spanish: Revolución de Mayo): the [[Primera Junta]] could not create new taxes without the ''Cabildo'''s authorization.

Many revolutionary leaders, led by [[Mariano Moreno]], wanted to declare independence immediately and to make a constitution in order to build an independent state. In October 1811, the [[Junta Grande]], which succeeded the Primera Junta, enacted the Regulation for the Division of Power, but it was not accepted by the [[First Triumvirate (Argentina)|executive power]]. Nevertheless, the [[freedom of press]] and the Decree on Individual Security were accepted by November.
In 1813, the [[Asamblea del Año XIII|General Constitutional Assembly]] was intended to declare a constitution but it could only declare the freedom for slaves' sons.

In [[Argentine Constitution of 1819|1819]] and [[Argentine Constitution of 1826|1826]] were declared two constitutions that eventually failed because of the disagreement between [[Federalist Party (Argentina)|Federalists]] and [[Unitarian Party|Unitarians]].
Many other ''constitutional'' pacts existed between 1820 and 1853 (when the current Argentine Constitution was enacted). The most important of them are: the [[Treaty of Pilar]] (1820), the [[Quadrilateral Treaty|Treaty of the ''Cuadrilátero'']] (1822), the [[Pacto Federal|Federal Pact]] (1831), the Palermo Protocol (1852), and the [[San Nicolás Agreement|Treaty of San Nicolás]] (1852).

The [[Pacto Federal|Federal Pact]] urged all the provinces to call a General Federal Congress, however this would have limited [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]]'s power who was the most powerful province governor, so the Congress was never called.
When Rosas was defeated, in 1852, the [[San Nicolás Agreement|Treaty of San Nicolás]] finally called the Constitutional Congress that, in Santa Fe, on May 1, 1853, sworn to make effective the federal Constitution. Consequently, the [[Buenos Aires Province|Province of Buenos Aires]] left the [[Argentine Confederation]] until 1859.

===Reforms to the 1853 Constitution===
The first constitutional amendment to the original 1853 text was performed in 1860 after Buenos Aires rejoined the Argentine Confederation. It consisted of several changes to many of the original articles. One of the major changes was the renaming of the state: according to the reform, the country would be officially named ''República Argentina'' (\Argentine Republic\") and
column5: for legal purposes
column6: ''Nación Argentina'' (\"Argentine Nation\")
column7: replacing the older Argentine Confederation denomination in all articles of the constitution. Another important inclusion was the constitutional recognizing of Buenos Aires' exclusive rights guaranteed by the Treaty of San Nicolás.

column1: The following reform was done in 1866 and established that exportation and importation taxes would be destined to the National Treasury indefinitely
column2: no longer until 1866 as the 1860 reform did.

another minor constitutional amendment was approved. It allowed a more flexible ratio for proportional apportionment in the [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|Chamber of Deputies]] and set the number of ministries to eight.

column1: During [[Juan Domingo Perón]]'s government the [[Argentine Constitution of 1949]] was successfully passed
column2: a major revision of the constitution. Its goal was to modernize and adapt the text to the twentieth century's concepts of democracy
column3: as for example
column4: including a list of ''social rights'' including better working conditions for the working class
column5: right to good education
column6: etc. This also was included into the principles stated on the Preamble. Also
column7: it permitted the indefinite reelection of the president.

column1: During the military regime known as the ''[[Revolución Libertadora]]'' that had deposed Perón's government in 1955
column2: in 1957 and before the elections that had to be held in 1958
column3: a Constitutional Convention was elected to reform the constitution. This reform does not include 1949's
column4: implicitly annulling it so the text was based on the 1898 one. The only changes done were to include a summary of Perón's social articles known as ''article 14 bis'' (existing currently) and to establish the necessity to have a Labour and Social Security Code.

column2: a \"Constitutional Amendment\" done by the military government led by general [[Alejandro A. Lanusse]] reformed the 1957 text. This had to last until 1977 but its application could be extended until 1981 if no Constitutional Convention in 1976 decided either to accept it or reject it definitively. This amendment was not fully applied by the democratic government of Perón in his third term nor by his wife [[Isabel Perón]] acting as President after his death. Some changes were related to the size of Senate and one-term reelection of president and vice-president. Also reduced presidential
column3: senatorial and deputies' terms all to four years.

column1: The last (and current) version of the Argentine Constitution was done by [[Carlos Saúl Menem]] in 1994. It included many of the modifications from the 1972 \"amendment\" as the growth of the Senate size (three per Province)
column2: one-term presidential reelection and reduction of its term to four years. It also made [[Buenos Aires|Buenos Aires City]] an [[Autonomous city|autonomous entity]] with its own authorities. Other changes were done to ensure a softer presidentialist regime
column3: the inclusion of a new chapter into the Bill of Rights related to politics
column4: health and environment
column5: and also the adoption of a much faster legislative procedure for creating laws. In addition with the 1994 constitutional reform
column6: the requirement of belonging to the Roman Catholic faith in order to be President or Vice President of the Republic
column7: was also abolished.<ref>{{cite web|title=Argentina 1853 (reinst. 1983
column8: rev. 1994)|url=https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Argentina_1994?lang=en|website=Constitute|accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref>

column2: Titles
column3: Divisions and Chapters
column4: though these need not be present all the time. For example
column5: the First Part is divided into Chapters but not into Titles nor Sections. The scheme of the Constitution is the following:

[[Image:Constitución Nacional Argentina 1853 - página 1.jpeg|thumb|240px|left|''\"Nos los Representantes del Pueblo de la Nación Argentina …\"'']]
The Preamble of the Argentine Constitution states or implies
column2: in short terms
column3: a number of starting points for the conception of the nation
column4: such as a representative government. It acknowledges previous agreements to create a constitution (in order to legitimize the gathering of the Assembly). Finally
column5: it lays the foundations for the policy of support of [[immigration in Argentina|immigration]]
column6: by asking \"for the protection of [[God]]
column7: source of all reason and justice\" for all people who desire to inhabit Argentina.

column2: rights and guarantees ==

column1: The Constitution establishes a Bill of Rights and Guarantees for all individuals
column2: Argentine or foreign; the inviolability of the right of life
column3: liberty
column4: equality
column5: security and property. The second chapter
column6: added in 1994
column7: deals with public ethics
column8: political rights
column9: environmental protection and consumer rights.

column1: Civil rights are recognized to all inhabitants with no distinction of nationality. This is a consequence of the traditional interest of Argentina in the affluence of foreigners and foreign investment. Labor rights are also acknowledged (this is part of the legacy of [[Peronism]]
column2: resulting in the 1949 and 1957 reforms). These include limited labor day
column3: just salary
column4: right of organization
column5: social security benefits
column6: etc.

column1: The constitution declares that no one can be deprived of property
column2: except in case of judicial sentence based on previously enacted legislation
column3: or through expropriation for reasons of public utility
column4: dully qualified by law and previously indemnified. The person
column5: its judicial defense
column6: its domicile and correspondence are inviolable.

column1: What the law does not forbid is permitted. Individuals have complete freedom to do or refuse to do anything in private
column2: except if that interferes with public order or morality
column3: or causes damage to third parties.

column1: The 1994 reform introduces several new legal figures: ''amparo judicial'' (an [[injunction]])
column2: ''habeas corpus'' and ''habeas data''. Injunctions are destined to protect citizens from actual or imminent damage; ''[[habeas corpus (Argentine law)|habeas corpus]]'' (known for a long time to Argentine jurisprudence
column3: and related to the [[habeas corpus]] of [[Common Law]]) is to protect the citizen's physical freedom; and ''[[habeas data (Argentine law)|habeas data]]'' is a person's right to access information about himself or herself
column4: and request its confidentiality
column5: a change or a suppression.

column1: The Argentine Constitution's rights are divided in four groups: Civil
column2: patrimonial
column3: politic and social.

column1: Declarations state the basis that hold the nation's politics and define it as an independent entity
column2: for example
column3: Article 1 states that the government is representative
column4: republican and federal and Article 35 lists the Country's official names.

column1: They are institutional methods to protect the exercise of fundamental rights. They are so important that it is possible to say that a right can be held as long as it has a guarantee to protect it.
Most of Guarantees are in the sections 18 and 43
column2: between these are: habeas corpus
column3: the abolition of death penalty and torture.

column1: The Argentine Constitution's rights are divided in four groups: Civil
column2: patrimonial
column3: politic and social.

column1: * '''Civil''' rights are related to the people as individuals. Some examples are: right to live
column2: have honor
column3: have a name
column4: make associations and to express opinions.

column1: * '''Patrimonial''' rights protect men in relation to their goods. Some examples are: to own
column2: to sell
column3: to hire
column4: and to build legal industries.

column1: * '''Politic''' rights allow people to take part in the government
column2: by themselves or by electing representatives: this category includes the right to choose and be chosen for the government and to make or join a political party.

column1: * '''Social''' rights are related to people as part of society: these are (among many others) the rights to work
column2: to have fair wages
column3: to know
column4: to learn
column5: to teach.

column2: Freedom is one of the most important rights. Section 19 says that private actions of men that don't harm the public order or another man can not be judged by authorities. Moreover
column3: it holds the \"principle of legality\": ''No inhabitant of the Nation will be forced to do what the law doesn't order nor forbidden to do what the law doesn't forbid''.

column1: Equality is as important as freedom. Section 16 states that in the country there are no noble titles and \"all its inhabitants are equal before the law\"

column2: Argentina is a representative [[federalism|federal]] [[republic]]
column3: divided in [[provinces of Argentina|provinces]]
column4: [[municipality|municipalities]]
column5: and the Autonomous City of [[Buenos Aires]]. Each province has the right and duty to dictate its own constitution
column6: respecting the same principles as the national constitution.

column1: [[Image:Edificio del Congreso en Buenos Aires 2004.JPG|thumb|250px|Congress building in Buenos Aires
column2: Argentina]]

column1: The Constitution mandates a strict separation of government powers
column2: into three branches (Executive
column3: Legislative
column4: and Judicial) and the Public Ministry.

column1: The Executive Branch is formed by the [[President of Argentina|President]]
column2: who is both head of state
column3: as well as chief executive and head of government. (Art. 87). The Vice-President replaces the President in case of illness
column4: absence from the capital
column5: death
column6: resignation
column7: or removal.

column1: The Vice-President doesn't belong to the executive branch. Curiously
column2: it belongs to the legislative branch since he is also the President of the Senate. (Art. 57)

column1: The President promulgates the laws sanctioned by Congress
column2: and has veto power over them. The President directs international relations and is the Commander in Chief of the Army. In some cases
column3: the President can issue [[Necessity and Urgency Decree|emergency decrees]].

column1: In the 1994 amendments to the 1853 Constitution
column2: the post of the Chief of the Cabinet Ministers was created who would serve as chief operating officer and would run the day-to-day operations of the government and will be at the same time
column3: be politically responsible to the both Houses of the National Congress
column4: the Senate and Chamber of Deputies and they can remove him or her via censure. The creation of the post was intended to reduce the presidentialist character of the country's presidential form of government.

column1: The Legislative Branch is composed of the Vice-President
column2: a bicameral Congress
column3: the General Auditing Office of the Nation and the Ombudsman. Congress is divided in two Houses: ''Cámara de Diputados'' ([[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|Chamber of Deputies]]
column4: the Lower House) and ''Cámara de Senadores'' ([[Argentine Senate|Senate]]
column5: the Upper House).

column1: The Vice-President belongs in the Legislative Branch since he (or she) is also the President of the Senate Chamber.
The General Auditing Office of the Nation is a technical advisory body of Congress with functional autonomy.
The Ombudsman is an independent body which works without receiving instructions from any authority. The mission of the Ombudsman is the defense and protection of human rights
column2: civil rights and guarantees
column3: and the control of the Administration.

column1: The Judicial Branch is formed by the Supreme Court
column2: and lower courts throughout the country. The Supreme Justices and all judges hold their offices as long as they are not deposed for misbehavior.

column1: The Public Ministry is an independent body with functional autonomy and financial autarchy
column2: with the function of promoting justice for the defense of legality
column3: of the general interests of society
column4: in coordination with the other authorities of the Republic.

column1: It is composed of an Attorney General of the Nation and an Ombudsman General of the Nation
column2: and such other members as the law may establish.

****Third Chapter ''Powers of the Executive Branch'' (1 section sub-divided 20 times)

column2: of which one is sub-divided 13 times)

column1: ****First Chapter ''Of its nature and duration'' (8 sections)
****Second Chapter ''Powers of the Judicial Branch'' (4 sections)
***Fourth Section ''Of the Office of the Public Prosecution'' (1 section)
[[Image:Constitución Nacional Argentina 1853 - página 1.jpeg|thumb|240px|left|''\"Nos los Representantes del Pueblo de la Nación Argentina …\"'']]
The Preamble of the Argentine Constitution states or implies
column2: in short terms
column3: a number of starting points for the conception of the nation
column4: such as a representative government. It acknowledges previous agreements to create a constitution (in order to legitimize the gathering of the Assembly). Finally
column5: it lays the foundations for the policy of support of [[immigration in Argentina|immigration]]
column6: by asking \"for the protection of [[God]]
column7: source of all reason and justice\" for all people who desire to inhabit Argentina.

column2: rights and guarantees ==

column1: The Constitution establishes a Bill of Rights and Guarantees for all individuals
column2: Argentine or foreign; the inviolability of the right of life
column3: liberty
column4: equality
column5: security and property. The second chapter
column6: added in 1994
column7: deals with public ethics
column8: political rights
column9: environmental protection and consumer rights.

column1: Civil rights are recognized to all inhabitants with no distinction of nationality. This is a consequence of the traditional interest of Argentina in the affluence of foreigners and foreign investment. Labor rights are also acknowledged (this is part of the legacy of [[Peronism]]
column2: resulting in the 1949 and 1957 reforms). These include limited labor day
column3: just salary
column4: right of organization
column5: social security benefits
column6: etc.

column1: The constitution declares that no one can be deprived of property
column2: except in case of judicial sentence based on previously enacted legislation
column3: or through expropriation for reasons of public utility
column4: dully qualified by law and previously indemnified. The person
column5: its judicial defense
column6: its domicile and correspondence are inviolable.

column1: What the law does not forbid is permitted. Individuals have complete freedom to do or refuse to do anything in private
column2: except if that interferes with public order or morality
column3: or causes damage to third parties.

column1: The 1994 reform introduces several new legal figures: ''amparo judicial'' (an [[injunction]])
column2: ''habeas corpus'' and ''habeas data''. Injunctions are destined to protect citizens from actual or imminent damage; ''[[habeas corpus (Argentine law)|habeas corpus]]'' (known for a long time to Argentine jurisprudence
column3: and related to the [[habeas corpus]] of [[Common Law]]) is to protect the citizen's physical freedom; and ''[[habeas data (Argentine law)|habeas data]]'' is a person's right to access information about himself or herself
column4: and request its confidentiality
column5: a change or a suppression.

column1: The Argentine Constitution's rights are divided in four groups: Civil
column2: patrimonial
column3: politic and social.

column1: Declarations state the basis that hold the nation's politics and define it as an independent entity
column2: for example
column3: Article 1 states that the government is representative
column4: republican and federal and Article 35 lists the Country's official names.

column1: They are institutional methods to protect the exercise of fundamental rights. They are so important that it is possible to say that a right can be held as long as it has a guarantee to protect it.
Most of Guarantees are in the sections 18 and 43
column2: between these are: habeas corpus
column3: the abolition of death penalty and torture.

column1: The Argentine Constitution's rights are divided in four groups: Civil
column2: patrimonial
column3: politic and social.

column1: * '''Civil''' rights are related to the people as individuals. Some examples are: right to live
column2: have honor
column3: have a name
column4: make associations and to express opinions.

column1: * '''Patrimonial''' rights protect men in relation to their goods. Some examples are: to own
column2: to sell and to hire and build legal industries.

column1: * '''Politic''' rights allow people to take part in the government
column2: by themselves or by electing representatives: this category includes the right to choose and be chosen for the government and to make or join a political party.

column1: * '''Social''' rights are related to people as part of society: these are (among many others) the rights to work
column2: to have fair wages
column3: to know
column4: to learn
column5: to teach.

column2: Freedom is one of the most important rights. Section 19 says that private actions of men that don't harm the public order or another man can not be judged by authorities. Moreover
column3: it holds the \"principle of legality\": ''No inhabitant of the Nation will be forced to do what the law doesn't order nor forbidden to do what the law doesn't forbid''.

column1: Equality is as important as freedom. Section 16 states that in the country there are no noble titles and \"all its inhabitants are equal before the law\"

column2: Argentina is a representative [[federalism|federal]] [[republic]]
column3: divided in [[provinces of Argentina|provinces]]
column4: [[municipality|municipalities]]
column5: and the Autonomous City of [[Buenos Aires]]. Each province has the right and duty to dictate its own constitution
column6: respecting the same principles as the national constitution.

column1: [[Image:Edificio del Congreso en Buenos Aires 2004.JPG|thumb|250px|Congress building in Buenos Aires
column2: Argentina]]

column1: The Constitution mandates a strict separation of government powers
column2: into three branches (Executive
column3: Legislative
column4: and Judicial) and the Public Ministry.

column1: The Executive Branch is formed by the [[President of Argentina|President]]
column2: who is both head of state
column3: as well as chief executive and head of government. (Art. 87). The Vice-President replaces the President in case of illness
column4: absence from the capital
column5: death
column6: resignation
column7: or removal.

column1: The Vice-President doesn't belong to the executive branch. Curiously
column2: it belongs to the legislative branch since he is also the President of the Senate. (Art. 57)

column1: The President promulgates the laws sanctioned by Congress
column2: and has veto power over them. The President directs international relations and is the Commander in Chief of the Army. In some cases
column3: the President can issue [[Necessity and Urgency Decree|emergency decrees]].

column1: In the 1994 amendments to the 1853 Constitution
column2: the post of the Chief of the Cabinet Ministers was created who would serve as chief operating officer and would run the day-to-day operations of the government and will be at the same time
column3: be politically responsible to the both Houses of the National Congress
column4: the Senate and Chamber of Deputies and they can remove him or her via censure. The creation of the post was intended to reduce the presidentialist character of the country's presidential form of government.

column1: The Legislative Branch is composed of the Vice-President
column2: a bicameral Congress
column3: the General Auditing Office of the Nation and the Ombudsman. Congress is divided in two Houses: ''Cámara de Diputados'' ([[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|Chamber of Deputies]]
column4: the Lower House) and ''Cámara de Senadores'' ([[Argentine Senate|Senate]]
column5: the Upper House).

column1: The Vice-President belongs in the Legislative Branch since he (or she) is also the President of the Senate Chamber.
The General Auditing Office of the Nation is a technical advisory body of Congress with functional autonomy.
The Ombudsman is an independent body which works without receiving instructions from any authority. The mission of the Ombudsman is the defense and protection of human rights
column2: civil rights and guarantees
column3: and the control of the Administration.

column1: The Judicial Branch is formed by the Supreme Court
column2: and lower courts throughout the country. The Supreme Justices and all judges hold their offices as long as they are not deposed for misbehavior.

column1: The Public Ministry is an independent body with functional autonomy and financial autarchy
column2: with the function of promoting justice for the defense of legality
column3: of the general interests of society
column4: in coordination with the other authorities of the Republic.

column1: It is composed of an Attorney General of the Nation and an Ombudsman General of the Nation
column2: and such other members as the law may establish.
