The '''1996–97 Macedonian First League''' was the 5th season of the [[Macedonian First Football League]]
column2: the highest [[Association football|football]] league of [[North Macedonia|Macedonia]]. The first matches of the season were played on 16 August 1996 and the last on 1 June 1997.<ref name=\"First\" /> [[FK Sileks|Sileks]] defended their championship title
column3: having won their second title in a row.

column1: Worldwide he has charted 16 top-40 records
column2: including six No. 1 songs
column3: the first of which was 1970's \"[[Nothing Rhymed]]\". Across his career
column4: he has recorded 19 studio albums
column5: up to his UK top 20 self-titled record in 2018. Speaking in 2009 he said
column6: \"I write pop songs. That's all I want to do. I have no interest in just touring
column7: and living in the past.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b013rl86 |title=BBC Four – Gilbert O'Sullivan: Out on His Own |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=29 August 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref> The music magazine ''[[Record Mirror]]'' voted him the top UK male singer of 1972.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\">{{cite book| first= David| last= Roberts| year= 2006| title= British Hit Singles & Albums| edition= 19th| publisher= Guinness World Records Limited| location= London| isbn= 1-904994-10-5| page= 411}}</ref> He has received three [[Ivor Novello Awards]]

column1: Raymond Edward O'Sullivan was born in Cork Road
column2: [[Waterford]]
column3: Ireland.<ref name=\"AMG\">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p110770/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Jason Ankeny |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=5 March 2009}}</ref> In 1953
column4: when he was seven
column5: his family moved to [[Battersea]]
column6: London; when he was eight they moved to [[Swindon]]
column7: Wiltshire
column8: England. He attended St. Joseph's and the Swindon College of Art
column9: where he briefly played drums in a band called Rick's Blues
column12: and founder [[Rick Davies]] (who later founded [[Supertramp]]) and where he developed his lifelong interests in music and art.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book

column1: | title= The Book of Golden Discs

}}</ref><ref name=\"Harrison\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thisiswiltshire.co.uk/news/14990864.Singing_star___s_far_from_Alone_Again/|title=Gilbert O’Sullivan’s far from Alone Again as musicians reunite|last=Harrison|first=Flicky|date=28 December 2016|work=This Is Wiltshire|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> According to a 1972 interview with O'Sullivan
column2: Davies taught him how to play both drums and piano.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=The Supertramp Book|place=Toronto
column3: Canada|publisher=Omnibus Press|year=1986|isbn=0-9691272-2-7|page=18|ref=harv|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> Other semi-professional bands he played with while at college include the Doodles and the Prefects.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/>

column2: O'Sullivan was signed to a five-year contract with April Music
column3: [[Columbia Records|CBS Records']] house publishing company
column4: after coming to the attention of the professional manager Stephen Shane
column5: <ref>'In 1967 ... [h]e took a part-time Christmas job at the [[C&A]] department store on [[Oxford Street]]. While there
column6: a colleague brought his tapes to the attention of the [[CBS]] record company executives. They liked what they heard
column7: and he was signed up.' ''Ireland's Own''
column8: 12 June 2015
column10: pg 9</ref> who also suggested changing his name from Ray to Gilbert as a play on the name of the operetta composers [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]. His songs at the time were [[avant-garde]]
column11: and even drew the interest of [[Vivian Stanshall]] and the [[Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band]]
column12: who were interested in recording a couple of them. He was paid an advance of £12 (equivalent to £{{formatnum:{{inflation|UK|12|1967|r=-2}}}} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}})
column13: with which he bought a piano. He was signed to CBS Records by the [[A&R]] manager Mike Smith ([[the Tremeloes]] and [[Love Affair (band)|the Love Affair]]).

column1: After two unsuccessful singles with CBS
column2: \"Disappear\" and \"What Can I Do?\"
column3: and one with the Irish record label [[Major Minor Records|Major Minor]]
column4: \"Mr. Moody's Garden\"
column5: all released under the name \"Gilbert\"
column6: O'Sullivan sent some demo [[compact cassette|tapes]] to [[Gordon Mills]]
column7: the manager of [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] and [[Engelbert Humperdinck (singer)|Engelbert Humperdinck]]
column8: whereupon O'Sullivan was signed to Mills' label
column9: [[MAM Records]].<ref name=\"AMG\"/><ref>[http://www.classicbands.com/osullivan.html \"Gilbert O'Sullivan\"]
column11: accessed 9 January 2013</ref> O'Sullivan's self-created eye-catching visual image comprised a [[Bowl cut|pudding basin haircut]]
column12: cloth cap and short trousers. Mills reportedly hated the image
column13: but O'Sullivan insisted on using it initially
column14: {{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} until he assumed a more modern 'college-like' look in which he often wore a [[sweater]] bearing a large letter 'G'.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>

column2: O'Sullivan achieved his first UK [[Top 40|Top 10]] hit with \"[[Nothing Rhymed]]\"
column3: <ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/> which also reached [[chart-topper|No. 1]] in the [[Netherlands]]
column4: <ref name=\"Top40/\">{{cite web|url=http://www.top40.nl/top40/1971/week-08|title=Top40 Chart|website=Top40.nl|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> where it earned O'Sullivan his first [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]].<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/>  Subsequent hits followed including \"Underneath The Blanket Go\" (which also reached [[chart-topper|No. 1]] in the Netherlands)
column5: \"[[We Will (song)|We Will]]\" and \"No Matter How I Try\"
column6: the latter being named \"Best Ballad or Romantic Song\" at the 17th Ivor Novello Awards in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|title=1972|url=http://theivors.com/archive/1970-1979/the-ivors-1972/|website=The Ivors|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> O'Sullivan released his debut album
column7: ''[[Himself (Gilbert O'Sullivan album)|Himself]]''
column8: in 1971.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>

column1: In 1972 O'Sullivan reached international [[celebrity|stardom]] with \"[[Alone Again (Naturally)]]\"
column2: which reached No. 3 in UK; No. 1 in the US
column3: spending six non-consecutive weeks at [[Chart-topper|No. 1]] on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] [[record chart|chart]] and selling nearly two million copies; No. 2 in New Zealand (11 weeks on the charts in total); No. 1 in Canada for 2 weeks (13 weeks in the Top 40);<ref name=\"Webfitz\">[http://www.webfitz.com/lyrics/Charts/1972]{{dead link|date=April 2013}}</ref> and No. 1 in Japan (21 weeks on the chart). The guitar solo was played by [[Big Jim Sullivan]].

column2: O'Sullivan's hit was topped only by [[Roberta Flack]]'s \"[[The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face]]\". Both songs were nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] in the [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] categories in 1973
column3: but Flack won both.

column2: from the album ''[[Back to Front (Gilbert O'Sullivan album)|Back to Front]]''). The single reached No. 2 in the United States on the Hot 100 and No. 1 in the UK and Canada (14 weeks in the Canadian Top 40).<ref name=\"Webfitz\"/> O'Sullivan's [[gramophone record|disc]] sales exceeded ten million in 1972 and made him the top star of the year.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> O'Sullivan's success led to him taking part in the [[BBC]]'s anniversary programme ''Fifty Years of Music'' in November 1972.

column1: \"[[Out of the Question (Gilbert O'Sullivan song)|Out of the Question]]\" (also from ''Back to Front'') reached No. 17 in the US and No. 14 in Canada.<ref name=\"Webfitz\"/>  \"[[Get Down (Gilbert O'Sullivan song)|Get Down]]\" (1973)
column2: from the album ''I'm A Writer Not A Fighter''
column3: reached No. 1 in the UK and in Germany
column4: <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chartsurfer.de/artist/gilbert-o-sullivan/get-down-song_vrgg.html|title=Get Down von Gilbert O'Sullivan|first=|last=Chartsurfer.de|website=Chartsurfer.de|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> No. 7 in both the US and Canada
column5: and No. 3 in the Netherlands.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/><ref name=\"Webfitz\"/> Following \"Alone Again (Naturally)\" and \"Clair\"
column6: \"Get Down\" was his third million-seller
column7: with the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] gold disc award presented on 18 September 1973.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> His November 1974 single \"Christmas Song\" reached No. 12 in the UK and No. 5 in Ireland.

column1: O'Sullivan enjoyed nearly five years of success with MAM
column2: a run that included seven UK Top 10 singles and four UK Top 10 albums; three US Top 10 singles and one top 10 album; five Dutch Top 10 singles and three Top 10 albums; five New Zealand Top 10 singles; three Canadian Top 10 singles; and seven Japan Top 10 singles.<ref name=\"Gilbert\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gilbertosullivan.com |title=The Official Gilbert O'Sullivan Website – A Friend of Mine |publisher=Gilbertosullivan.com |accessdate=22 April 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050811074659/http://www.gilbertosullivan.com/ |archivedate=11 August 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

column1: \"Ooh Baby\" and \"Happiness Is Me and You\" charted
column2: but O'Sullivan's sales were decreasing.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> In June 1975 he had his last Top 20 hit
column3: \"I Don't Love You But I Think I Like You\".<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/><ref name=\"AMG\"/>

column1: Things turned more sour when he discovered his recording contract with MAM Records greatly favoured the label's owner
column2: Gordon Mills.  A lawsuit followed
column3: with prolonged argument over how much money his songs had earned and how much of that money he had actually received.<ref name=\"500 Number One Hits\">{{cite book

column1: | title= The Guinness Book of 500 Number One Hits

column2: Middlesex
in May 1982
column3: the court found in O'Sullivan's favour
column4: describing him as a \"patently honest and decent man\"
column5: who had not received a just proportion of the vast income his songs had generated.<ref name=\"500 Number One Hits\"/> They awarded him £7 million in [[damages]] (£{{formatnum:{{inflation|UK|7000000|1982|r=-2}}}} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}).  Although he had won
column6: the court battle put his [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] career on hold.

column2: after a five-year hiatus
column3: he returned to his old record label
column4: CBS.

column2: \"What's in a Kiss?\"
column3: reached No. 19 in the UK in 1980 and No. 21 in Japan.<ref name=\"Gilbert\"/> It was his first UK Top 20 hit in five years. Following this release
column4: and due in part to the then-ongoing MAM court case
column5: O'Sullivan released no new material between 1983 and 1986.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Apart from the single \"So What ?\" in 1990 and a [[compilation album]] in 1991 ''Nothing But The Best''
column6: O'Sullivan was absent from the charts until another compilation album
column7: ''The Berry Vest of Gilbert O'Sullivan''
column8: returned him to the UK Top 20 in 2004.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/>

column1: O'Sullivan is also noted for his role in bringing about the practice of clearing samples in [[hip hop music]] as a result of the 1991 court case
column2: [[Grand Upright Music
column3: Ltd. v. Warner Bros. Records
column4: Inc.]]
column5: <ref>''[[Grand Upright Music
column6: Ltd. v. Warner Bros. Records
column8: [[Case citation|780 F. Supp. 182]] ([[S.D.N.Y.]] 1991)</ref> in which he sued [[rapping|rapper]] [[Biz Markie]] over the rights to use a [[sampling (music)|sample]] of his song \"Alone Again (Naturally)\".<ref name=\"AMG\"/> He won 100% of the royalties and made sampling an expensive undertaking.<ref name=\"Grauiad-1\">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2011/aug/25/gilbert-o-sullivan-reappraisal|title=Gilbert O'Sullivan: time for a reappraisal?|last=Stanley|first=Bob|date=25 August 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>

column1: O'Sullivan has continued to record and perform into the 21st century. He enjoys [[Big in Japan (phrase)|particular acclaim in Japan]].<ref name=\"AMG\"/> His album ''A Scruff at Heart'' was released in 2007
column2: featuring \"Just So You Know\". On 14 July 2008
column3: O'Sullivan released \"Never Say Di\". He appeared at the [[Glastonbury Festival 2008|2008 Glastonbury Festival]]
column4: and played London's [[Royal Albert Hall]] on 26 October 2009. On 26 August 2010
column5: O'Sullivan announced that he had joined Hypertension
column6: a record company whose artists have included [[Leo Sayer]]
column7: [[Chris DeBurgh]]
column8: [[Fleetwood Mac]] and [[Gerry Rafferty]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hypertension-music.de/?page_id=3 |title=Hypertension \" Artists |publisher=Hypertension-music.de |date= |accessdate=2015-08-26}}</ref>

column1: His album ''Gilbertville'' was released on 31 January 2011; it featured \"All They Wanted To Say\"
column2: which dealt with the 2001 [[September 11 attacks|attacks on the World Trade Center]]
column3: and his single \"Where Would We Be (Without Tea)?\". On 19 July 2011
column4: O'Sullivan played live on the [[BBC Radio 2]] [[Ken Bruce]] Show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b012hkht |title=BBC Radio 2 – Ken Bruce
column5: 19/07/2011 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=19 July 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref> On 26 August that year
column6: the documentary ''Out on His Own'' was broadcast by BBC 4 (before by Irish RTÉ). In March 2012
column7: the compilation album ''Gilbert O'Sullivan: The Very Best Of – A Singer & His Songs''  entered the UK Albums Chart at No.12. 2015 saw Gilbert re-emerge on Irish and BBC radio and television. He toured Ireland beginning of June
column8: and on 8 June 2015 his Peggy Lee-inspired new album ''Latin ala G!'' was released.

column2: O'Sullivan released his 19th studio album ''Gilbert O’Sullivan''. The album entered the UK album charts at No. 20
column3: his first UK charting studio album for over 40 years.

column1: O'Sullivan purposely avoided dating at the peak of his career; he feared that doing so would inhibit his songwriting abilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gilbertosullivan.net/in_print/rolling_stone_02.htm |title=Gilbert O'Sullivan | In Print |website=Gilbertosullivan.net |date=1973-08-02 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> In January 1980
column2: O'Sullivan married his [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] girlfriend Aase. Later that year the first of their two daughters
column3: Helen-Marie
column4: was born. Tara was born two years later.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}

column1: He currently lives in Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/fame-fortune/gilbert-osullivan-success-was-the-postman-walking-up-the-garden/|title=Gilbert O'Sullivan: 'Success was the postman walking up the garden whistling my song'|first=Caroline|last=Rees|date=14 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
Clair one O’Sullivan’s biggest hits is said to a affectionate song about his then managers daughter who can be heard giggling at the end of the track. Although O’Sullivan
column2: had said that his fear of wet paper towels was his principal motivation in writing the classic. The Claire in the title refers to the brand of paper “Claire Fontaine”.

column4: <ref name=\"Top40/\">{{cite web|url=http://www.top40.nl/top40/1971/week-08|title=Top40 Chart|website=Top40.nl|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> where it earned O'Sullivan his first [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]].<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/>  Subsequent hits followed including \"Underneath The Blanket Go\" (which also reached [[chart-topper|No. 1]] in the Netherlands)
column5: \"[[We Will (song)|We Will]]\" and \"No Matter How I Try\"
column6: the latter being named \"Best Ballad or Romantic Song\" at the 17th Ivor Novello Awards in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|title=1972|url=http://theivors.com/archive/1970-1979/the-ivors-1972/|website=The Ivors|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> O'Sullivan released his debut album
column7: ''[[Himself (Gilbert O'Sullivan album)|Himself]]''
column8: in 1971.<ref name=\"AMG\"/>

column1: In 1972 O'Sullivan reached international [[celebrity|stardom]] with \"[[Alone Again (Naturally)]]\"
column2: which reached No. 3 in UK; No. 1 in the US
column3: spending six non-consecutive weeks at [[Chart-topper|No. 1]] on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] [[record chart|chart]] and selling nearly two million copies; No. 2 in New Zealand (11 weeks on the charts in total); No. 1 in Canada for 2 weeks (13 weeks in the Top 40);<ref name=\"Webfitz\">[http://www.webfitz.com/lyrics/Charts/1972]{{dead link|date=April 2013}}</ref> and No. 1 in Japan (21 weeks on the chart). The guitar solo was played by [[Big Jim Sullivan]].

column2: O'Sullivan's hit was topped only by [[Roberta Flack]]'s \"[[The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face]]\". Both songs were nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] in the [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]] categories in 1973
column3: but Flack won both.

column2: from the album ''[[Back to Front (Gilbert O'Sullivan album)|Back to Front]]''). The single reached No. 2 in the United States on the Hot 100 and No. 1 in the UK and Canada (14 weeks in the Canadian Top 40).<ref name=\"Webfitz\"/> O'Sullivan's [[gramophone record|disc]] sales exceeded ten million in 1972 and made him the top star of the year.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> O'Sullivan's success led to him taking part in the [[BBC]]'s anniversary programme ''Fifty Years of Music'' in November 1972.

column1: \"[[Out of the Question (Gilbert O'Sullivan song)|Out of the Question]]\" (also from ''Back to Front'') reached No. 17 in the US and No. 14 in Canada.<ref name=\"Webfitz\"/>  \"[[Get Down (Gilbert O'Sullivan song)|Get Down]]\" (1973)
column2: from the album ''I'm A Writer Not A Fighter''
column3: reached No. 1 in the UK and in Germany
column4: <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chartsurfer.de/artist/gilbert-o-sullivan/get-down-song_vrgg.html|title=Get Down von Gilbert O'Sullivan|first=|last=Chartsurfer.de|website=Chartsurfer.de|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> No. 7 in both the US and Canada
column5: and No. 3 in the Netherlands.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/><ref name=\"Webfitz\"/> Following \"Alone Again (Naturally)\" and \"Clair\"
column6: \"Get Down\" was his third million-seller
column7: with the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] gold disc award presented on 18 September 1973.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> His November 1974 single \"Christmas Song\" reached No. 12 in the UK and No. 5 in Ireland.

column1: O'Sullivan enjoyed nearly five years of success with MAM
column2: a run that included seven UK Top 10 singles and four UK Top 10 albums; three US Top 10 singles and one top 10 album; five Dutch Top 10 singles and three Top 10 albums; five New Zealand Top 10 singles; three Canadian Top 10 singles; and seven Japan Top 10 singles.<ref name=\"Gilbert\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gilbertosullivan.com |title=The Official Gilbert O'Sullivan Website – A Friend of Mine |publisher=Gilbertosullivan.com |accessdate=22 April 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050811074659/http://www.gilbertosullivan.com/ |archivedate=11 August 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

column1: \"Ooh Baby\" and \"Happiness Is Me and You\" charted
column2: but O'Sullivan's sales were decreasing.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> In June 1975 he had his last Top 20 hit
column3: \"I Don't Love You But I Think I Like You\".<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/><ref name=\"AMG\"/>

column1: Things turned more sour when he discovered his recording contract with MAM Records greatly favoured the label's owner
column2: Gordon Mills.  A lawsuit followed
column3: with prolonged argument over how much money his songs had earned and how much of that money he had actually received.<ref name=\"500 Number One Hits\">{{cite book

column1: | title= The Guinness Book of 500 Number One Hits

column2: Middlesex
in May 1982
column3: the court found in O'Sullivan's favour
column4: describing him as a \"patently honest and decent man\"
column5: who had not received a just proportion of the vast income his songs had generated.<ref name=\"500 Number One Hits\"/> They awarded him £7 million in [[damages]] (£{{formatnum:{{inflation|UK|7000000|1982|r=-2}}}} as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}).  Although he had won
column6: the court battle put his [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] career on hold.

column2: after a five-year hiatus
column3: he returned to his old record label
column4: CBS.

column2: \"What's in a Kiss?\"
column3: reached No. 19 in the UK in 1980 and No. 21 in Japan.<ref name=\"Gilbert\"/> It was his first UK Top 20 hit in five years. Following this release
column4: and due in part to the then-ongoing MAM court case
column5: O'Sullivan released no new material between 1983 and 1986.<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Apart from the single \"So What ?\" in 1990 and a [[compilation album]] in 1991 ''Nothing But The Best''
column6: O'Sullivan was absent from the charts until another compilation album
column7: ''The Berry Vest of Gilbert O'Sullivan''
column8: returned him to the UK Top 20 in 2004.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\"/>

column1: O'Sullivan is also noted for his role in bringing about the practice of clearing samples in [[hip hop music]] as a result of the 1991 court case
column2: [[Grand Upright Music
column3: Ltd. v. Warner Bros. Records
column4: Inc.]]
column5: <ref>''[[Grand Upright Music
column6: Ltd. v. Warner Bros. Records
column8: [[Case citation|780 F. Supp. 182]] ([[S.D.N.Y.]] 1991)</ref> in which he sued [[rapping|rapper]] [[Biz Markie]] over the rights to use a [[sampling (music)|sample]] of his song \"Alone Again (Naturally)\".<ref name=\"AMG\"/> He won 100% of the royalties and made sampling an expensive undertaking.<ref name=\"Grauiad-1\">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2011/aug/25/gilbert-o-sullivan-reappraisal|title=Gilbert O'Sullivan: time for a reappraisal?|last=Stanley|first=Bob|date=25 August 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>

column1: O'Sullivan has continued to record and perform into the 21st century. He enjoys [[Big in Japan (phrase)|particular acclaim in Japan]].<ref name=\"AMG\"/> His album ''A Scruff at Heart'' was released in 2007
column2: featuring \"Just So You Know\". On 14 July 2008
column3: O'Sullivan released \"Never Say Di\". He appeared at the [[Glastonbury Festival 2008|2008 Glastonbury Festival]]
column4: and played London's [[Royal Albert Hall]] on 26 October 2009. On 26 August 2010
column5: O'Sullivan announced that he had joined Hypertension
column6: a record company whose artists have included [[Leo Sayer]]
column7: [[Chris DeBurgh]]
column8: [[Fleetwood Mac]] and [[Gerry Rafferty]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hypertension-music.de/?page_id=3 |title=Hypertension \" Artists |publisher=Hypertension-music.de |date= |accessdate=2015-08-26}}</ref>

column1: His album ''Gilbertville'' was released on 31 January 2011; it featured \"All They Wanted To Say\"
column2: which dealt with the 2001 [[September 11 attacks|attacks on the World Trade Center]]
column3: and his single \"Where Would We Be (Without Tea)?\". On 19 July 2011
column4: O'Sullivan played live on the [[BBC Radio 2]] [[Ken Bruce]] Show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b012hkht |title=BBC Radio 2 – Ken Bruce
column5: 19/07/2011 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=19 July 2011 |accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref> On 26 August that year
column6: the documentary ''Out on His Own'' was broadcast by BBC 4 (before by Irish RTÉ). In March 2012
column7: the compilation album ''Gilbert O'Sullivan: The Very Best Of – A Singer & His Songs''  entered the UK Albums Chart at No.12. 2015 saw Gilbert re-emerge on Irish and BBC radio and television. He toured Ireland beginning of June
column8: and on 8 June 2015 his Peggy Lee-inspired new album ''Latin ala G!'' was released.

column2: O'Sullivan released his 19th studio album ''Gilbert O’Sullivan''. The album entered the UK album charts at No. 20
column3: his first UK charting studio album for over 40 years.

column1: O'Sullivan purposely avoided dating at the peak of his career; he feared that doing so would inhibit his songwriting abilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gilbertosullivan.net/in_print/rolling_stone_02.htm |title=Gilbert O'Sullivan | In Print |website=Gilbertosullivan.net |date=1973-08-02 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> In January 1980
column2: O'Sullivan married his [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] girlfriend Aase. Later that year the first of their two daughters
column3: Helen-Marie
column4: was born. Tara was born two years later.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}

column1: He currently lives in Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/fame-fortune/gilbert-osullivan-success-was-the-postman-walking-up-the-garden/|title=Gilbert O'Sullivan: 'Success was the postman walking up the garden whistling my song'|first=Caroline|last=Rees|date=14 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=28 December 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>

{{Italic title}} {{Speciesbox | name = ''Notiomastodon'' | fossil_range = late [[Early Pleistocene]]-Early [[Holocene]]
(Possible Earliest Pleistocene record)
~{{Fossil range|0.8|0.011|earliest=2.5}} | image = Stegomastodon CCB.JPG | image2 = Stegomastodon platensis.JPG | image_width = 250px | image_caption = Skeleton at the Centro Cultural del Bicentenario de Santiago del Estero | image2_caption = Skull at the Natural History Museum, London | parent_authority = Cabrera, 1929 | taxon = Notiomastodon platensis | authority = ([[Florentino Ameghino|Ameghino]], 1888) [originally ''Mastodon''] | synonyms = * ''Stegomastodon platensis'' Ameghino 1888 * ''Stegomastodon waringi'' Holland 1920 * ''Haplomastodon waringi'' Holland 1920 * ''Haplomastodon chimborazi'' Proaño 1922 * ''Haplomastodon guayasensis'' Hoffstetter 1952 * ''Amahuacatherium peruvium'' Romero-Pittman 1996 }} '''''Notiomastodon''''' is an extinct [[proboscidea]]n genus of [[gomphothere]]s (a distant relative to modern [[elephants]]) endemic to [[South America]] from the [[Pleistocene]] to the [[Holocene]].{{cite journal|last1=Shoshani|first1=Jeheskel|last2=Tassy|first2=Pascal|title=Advances in proboscidean taxonomy & classification
column5: anatomy & physiology
column6: and ecology & behavior|journal=Quaternary International|volume=126–128|year=2005|pages=5–20|issn=1040-6182|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2004.04.011|bibcode=2005QuInt.126....5S}}</ref> It was among the last known gomphotheres and one of two South American gomphotheres alongside ''[[Cuvieronius]]'' and was the predominant gomphothere on the continent ranging widely over most of South America excluding the [[Andes|High Andes]]. The species has a long and convoluted taxonomic history due to its morphological variability and confusion with related gomphothere taxa
column7: which was only resolved during the 2010's.

column2:
{{Italic title}} {{Speciesbox | name = ''Notiomastodon'' | fossil_range = late [[Early Pleistocene]]-Early [[Holocene]]
(Possible Earliest Pleistocene record)
~{{Fossil range|0.8|0.011|earliest=2.5}} | image = Stegomastodon CCB.JPG | image2 = Stegomastodon platensis.JPG | image_width = 250px | image_caption = Skeleton at the Centro Cultural del Bicentenario de Santiago del Estero | image2_caption = Skull at the Natural History Museum, London | authority = Cabrera, 1929 | taxon = Notiomastodon platensis | parent_authority = ([[Florentino Ameghino|Ameghino]], 1888) [originally ''Mastodon''] | synonyms = * ''Stegomastodon platensis'' Ameghino 1888 * ''Stegomastodon waringi'' Holland 1920 * ''Haplomastodon waringi'' Holland 1920 * ''Haplomastodon chimborazi'' Proaño 1922 * ''Haplomastodon guayasensis'' Hoffstetter 1952 * ''Amahuacatherium peruvium'' Romero-Pittman 1996 }} '''''Notiomastodon''''' is an extinct [[proboscidea]]n genus of [[gomphothere]]s (a distant relative to modern [[elephants]]) endemic to [[South America]] from the [[Pleistocene]] to the [[Holocene]].{{cite journal|last1=Shoshani|first1=Jeheskel|last2=Tassy|first2=Pascal|title=Advances in proboscidean taxonomy & classification
column3: anatomy & physiology
column4: and ecology & behavior|journal=Quaternary International|volume=126–128|year=2005|pages=5–20|issn=1040-6182|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2004.04.011|bibcode=2005QuInt.126....5S}}</ref> It was among the last known gomphotheres and one of two South American gomphotheres alongside ''[[Cuvieronius]]'' and was the predominant gomphothere on the continent ranging widely over most of South America excluding the [[Andes|High Andes]]. The species has a long and convoluted taxonomic history due to its morphological variability and confusion with related gomphothere taxa
column5: which was only resolved during the 2010's.

'''Dravet syndrome''', previously known as '''severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy''' ('''SMEI'''), is a catastrophic type of [[epilepsy]] with prolonged seizures that are often triggered by hot temperatures or [[fever]].<ref name=Lh2013/> It is very difficult to treat with [[anticonvulsant medication]]s. It often begins before 1 year of age.<ref name=Lh2013>{{cite book|last=Lhatoo|editor=Simon Shorvon|editor2=Renzo Guerrini|editor3=Mark Cook|editor4= Samden D|title=Oxford textbook of epilepsy and epileptic seizures|year=2013|publisher=Oxford Univ. Press|location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-965904-3 |page=13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LeGv1qOK_0wC&pg=PA13}}</ref>

==Signs and symptoms==
Dravet syndrome has been characterized by prolonged [[Febrile seizure|febrile]] and non-febrile [[seizure]]s within the first year of a child’s life. This disease progresses to other [[seizure types]] like myoclonic and partial seizures, psychomotor delay, and [[ataxia]].<ref name=Reference3>{{cite journal|last1=Selmer|first1=K.K.|last2=Eriksson|first2=A-S|last3=Brandal|first3=K.|last4=Egeland|first4=T.|last5=Tallaksen|first5=C.|last6=Undlien|first6=D.E.|title=Parental SCN1A mutation mosaicism in familial Dravet syndrome|journal=Clinical Genetics|date=1 October 2009|volume=76|issue=4|pages=398–403|doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2009.01208.x|pmid=19673951}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2015--></ref> It is characterized by cognitive impairment, behavioral disorders, and motor deficits.<ref name=Reference2>{{cite journal|last1=Granata|first1=Tiziana|title=Comprehensive care of children with Dravet syndrome|journal=Epilepsia|date=1 April 2011|volume=52|pages=90–94|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03011.x|pmid=21463289}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2015--></ref> Behavioral deficits often include hyperactivity and impulsiveness, and in more rare cases, autistic-like behaviors.<ref name=\Reference2\" /> Dravet syndrome is also associated with sleep disorders including [[somnolence]] and [[insomnia]].<ref name=\"Reference2\" />  The seizures experienced by people with Dravet syndrome become worse as the patient ages
column5: as the disease is not very observable when symptoms first appear.<ref name=\"Reference2\" /> This coupled with the range of severity differing between each individual diagnosed and the resistance of these seizures to drugs has made it challenging to develop treatments.<ref name=\"Reference2\" />

column1: Dravet syndrome appears during the first year of life
column2: often beginning around six months of age with frequent febrile seizures (fever-related seizures). Children with Dravet syndrome typically experience a lagged development of language and motor skills
column3: hyperactivity and sleep difficulties
column4: chronic infection
column5: growth and balance issues
column6: and difficulty relating to others. The effects of this disorder do not diminish over time
column7: and children diagnosed with Dravet syndrome require fully committed caretakers with tremendous patience and the ability to closely monitor them.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\">Miller
column8: I.O. and Sotero de Menezes. M.A. SCN1A-Related Seizure Disorders. 2007 Nov 29 [Updated 2014 May 15]. GeneReviews® [Internet]. Seattle (WA): University of Washington
column9: Seattle; 1993–2015. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1318/</ref>

column1: Febrile seizures are divided into two categories known as simple and complex. A febrile seizure would be categorized as complex if it has occurred within 24 hours of another seizure or if it lasts longer than 15 minutes. A febrile seizure lasting less than 15 minutes would be considered simple. Sometimes modest hyperthermic stressors like physical exertion or a hot bath can provoke seizures in affected individuals.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\"/> However
column2: any seizure uninterrupted after 5 minutes
column3: without a resumption of [[postictal]] (more normal; recovery-type; after-seizure) consciousness can lead to potentially fatal [[status epilepticus]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}

column1: In most cases the mutations in Dravet syndrome are not hereditary and the mutated gene is found for the first time in a single family member.<ref name=\"Reference3\" /> In 70–90% of patients
column2: Dravet syndrome is caused by [[nonsense mutations]] in the [[SCN1A]] gene resulting in a premature stop codon and thus a non-functional protein.<ref name=\"Reference3\" />  This gene normally codes for neuronal voltage-gated sodium channel Na(V)1.1.<ref name=Reference4>{{cite journal|last1=Cheah|first1=C|last2=Catterall|first2=W.A.|title=Characterizing the role of sodium channels in mouse models of Dravet Syndrome|date=2012}}</ref> In mouse models
column3: these loss-of-function mutations have been observed to result in a decrease in sodium currents and impaired excitability of GABAergic [[interneuron]]s of the [[hippocampus]].<ref name=\"Reference4\" /> The researchers found that loss of NA(V)1.1 channels was sufficient to cause the epilepsy and premature death seen in Dravet syndrome.<ref name=\"Reference4\" /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Couzin-Frankel |first1=Jennifer |title=Sudden death in epilepsy: Researchers finger possible cause |journal=Science |date=8 April 2015 |doi=10.1126/science.aab2456 }}</ref>

column1: The timing of the first signs and symptoms in Dravet syndrome occur about the same time as normal childhood vaccinations
column2: leading some to believe the vaccine was the cause. However
column3: this is likely a non-specific response to fever
column4: as vaccination often induces fever
column5: <ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lin YJ
column6: Wen CN
column7: Lin YY
column8: Hsieh WC
column9: Chang CC
column13: Chen CH
column14: Fang CT |title=Oil-in-water emulsion adjuvants for pediatric influenza vaccines: a systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=Nat Commun |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=315 |date=January 2020 |pmid=31949137 |pmc=6965081 |doi=10.1038/s41467-019-14230-x |url=}}</ref> and fever is known to be associated with seizures in persons with Dravet syndrome.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dravetfoundation.org/what-is-dravet-syndrome/|title=What is Dravet Syndrome?|last=admin|publisher=}}</ref>  Some of the patients who put forth vaccine injury claims from encephalopathy were later found
column16: to actually have Dravet syndrome.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ben-Menachem |first1=Elinor |title=Vaccination and the Onset of Dravet Syndrome |journal=Epilepsy Currents |date=4 January 2019 |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=120–122 |doi=10.5698/1535-7511-11.4.120 |pmid=21852883 |pmc=3152151 }}</ref>

column1: The genotypic explanation of the disorder has been located on the specific voltage-gated sodium channel genes known as [[SCN1A]] and [[SCN2A]]. These genes are located on the long (q) arm of chromosome 2 at position 24.3 and code for the alpha subunit of the transmembrane sodium channel protein. A mutation in either of these two genes will cause an individual to develop dysfunctional sodium channels
column2: which are crucial in the pathway for sending chemical signals in the brain
column3: causing the phenotypic display of myoclonic epilepsy from the individual. A properly functioning channel would respond to a voltage difference across the membrane and form a pore through which only sodium ions can pass. The influx of sodium induces the generation of action potential by temporarily changing the charge of the cell. When the gene is mutated
column4: the eventually translated protein improperly folds its pore segment within the cell membrane because it has different amino acid chemistry
column5: which renders the channel inactive. It is also possible for a mutation to reduce the number of channels produced by an individual
column6: which leads to the development of Dravet syndrome.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1535-7597.2005.05105.x |pmid=16059449 |pmc=1176321 |title=A Plethora of SCN1A Mutations: What Can They Tell Us? |journal=Epilepsy Currents |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=17–20 |year=2005 |last1=Wallace |first1=Robyn }}</ref>

column2: the SCN1A gene is the most clinically relevant; the largest number of epilepsy related mutations characterized thus far occur in this gene.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\"/><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sugawara T
column3: Tsurubuchi Y
column4: Agarwala KL
column5: Ito M
column6: Fukuma G
column7: Mazaki-Miyazaki E
column8: Nagafuji H
column9: Noda M
column13: Kaneko S
column17: Yamakawa K | year = 2001 | title = A missense mutation of the Na+ channel alpha II subunit gene Na(v)1.2 in a patient with febrile and afebrile seizures causes channel dysfunction | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A | volume = 98 | issue = 11| pages = 6384–9 | doi=10.1073/pnas.111065098 | pmid=11371648 | pmc=33477}}</ref> Typically
column18: a [[missense mutation]] in either the S5 or S6 segment of the sodium channel pore results in a loss of channel function and the development of Dravet syndrome. A heterozygous inheritance of an SCN1A mutation is all that is necessary to develop a defective sodium channel; patients with Dravet syndrome will still have one normal copy of the gene.<ref name=\"ReferenceA\"/>

column1: According to the Dravet Syndrome Foundation
column2: the diagnostic criteria for DS requires the patient to present with several of the following symptoms:<ref name=Reference5>{{cite web|title=Diagnostic Criteria|url=http://www.dravetfoundation.org/dravet-syndrome/consider-dravet/diagnostic-criteria|website=Dravet Syndrome Foundation|accessdate=17 March 2015|archive-url=https://archive.is/20150317204051/http://www.dravetfoundation.org/dravet-syndrome/consider-dravet/diagnostic-criteria|archive-date=17 March 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref>

column1: * Onset of seizures in the first year of life in an otherwise healthy infant
* Initial seizures are typically prolonged and are generalized or unilateral
* Presence of other seizure types (i.e. myoclonic seizures)
* Seizures associated with fever due to illness or vaccinations
* Seizures induced by prolonged exposure to warm temperatures
* Seizures in response to strong lighting or certain visual patterns
* Initially normal EEGs and later EEGs with slowing and severe generalized polyspikes
* Normal initial development followed by slow development during the first few years of life
* Ankle pronation and flat feet and/or development of a crouched gait with age
Seizures in Dravet syndrome can be difficult to manage but may be reduced by anticonvulsant medications such as [[clobazam]]
column2: [[stiripentol]]
column3: [[topiramate]] and [[valproate]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dravet Syndrome Foundation: Treatment|url=http://www.dravetfoundation.org/dravet-syndrome/medical-information/treatment|accessdate=1 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151228054002/http://www.dravetfoundation.org/dravet-syndrome/medical-information/treatment|archive-date=28 December 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref> Because the course of the disorder varies from individual to individual
column4: treatment protocols may vary. A diet high in fats and low in carbohydrates may also be beneficial
column5: known as a [[ketogenic diet]]. Although diet adjustment can help
column6: it does not eliminate the symptoms. Until a better form of treatment or cure is discovered
column7: those with this disease will have myoclonic epilepsy for the rest of their lives.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\"/>

column1: Certain anticonvulsant medications that are classed as sodium channel blockers are now known to make seizures worse in most Dravet patients. These medications include carbamazepine
column2: gabapentin
column3: lamotrigine
column4: and phenytoin.<ref>{{cite web|title=NICE: Epilepsies: diagnosis and management|url=https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg137/chapter/1-Guidance#pharmacological-treatment|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SCN1A Patients Advised to Avoid Sodium Channel Blockers|url=http://www.ice-epilepsy.org/scn1a-patients-advised-to-avoid-sodium-channel-blockers.html|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref>

column1: Treatments include cognitive rehabilitation through psychomotor and speech therapy.<ref name=\"Reference2\" /> In addition
column2: valproate is often administered to prevent recurrence of febrile seizures and a [[benzodiazepine]] is used for long lasting seizures
column3: but these treatments are usually insufficient.<ref name=Reference6>{{cite journal|last1=Chiron|first1=C|last2=Dulac|first2=O|title=The pharmacologic treatment of Dravet syndrome|journal=Epilepsia|date=1 April 2011|volume=52|pages=72–75|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03007.x|pmid=21463285}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2015--></ref>

column1: Stiripentol was the only medication for which a double-blind [[placebo]]-controlled [[randomized controlled trial]] was performed and this medication showed efficacy in trials.<ref name=\"Reference6\" /> It acts as a GABAergic agent and as a [[GABAA receptor positive allosteric modulator|positive allosteric modulator of GABA<sub>A</sub> receptor]].<ref name=\"Reference6\" /> Stiripentol
column2: can improve [[focal refractory epilepsy]]
column3: as well as Dravet's syndrome
column4: supplemented with clobazam and valproate was approved in Europe in 2007 as a therapy for Dravet syndrome and has been found to reduce overall seizure rate by 70%.<ref name=\"Reference6\" /> In cases with more drug-resistant seizures
column5: topiramate and the ketogenic diet are used as alternative treatments.<ref name=\"Reference6\" /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brigo |first1=Francesco |last2=Storti |first2=Monica |last3=Igwe |first3=Stanley C |title=Stiripentol for focal refractory epilepsy |journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |issue=10 |pages=CD009887 |date=21 October 2015 |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD009887.pub3 |pmid=26488459 }}</ref>

column1: [[Cannabidiol]] (CBD) was approved in United States for treatment of Dravet syndrome in 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Press Announcements - FDA approves first drug {{sic|comprised |hide=y|of}} an active ingredient derived from marijuana to treat rare
column2: severe forms of epilepsy |url=https://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm611046.htm |website=www.fda.gov |accessdate=27 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> A 2017 study showed that the frequency of seizures per month decreased from 12 to 6 with the use of cannabidiol
column3: compared with a decrease from 15 to 14 with placebo.<ref name=pmid28538134>{{cite journal |last1=Devinsky |first1=Orrin |last2=Cross |first2=J. Helen |last3=Laux |first3=Linda |last4=Marsh |first4=Eric |last5=Miller |first5=Ian |last6=Nabbout |first6=Rima |last7=Scheffer |first7=Ingrid E. |last8=Thiele |first8=Elizabeth A. |last9=Wright |first9=Stephen |last10=Cannabidiol in Dravet Syndrome Study |first10=Group. |title=Trial of Cannabidiol for Drug-Resistant Seizures in the Dravet Syndrome |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |date=25 May 2017 |volume=376 |issue=21 |pages=2011–2020 |doi=10.1056/NEJMoa1611618 |pmid=28538134 |url=https://www.pure.ed.ac.uk/ws/files/37478646/nejmoa1611618.pdf }}</ref>

column1: Dravet syndrome is a severe form of epilepsy
column2: responsible for roughly 10% of cases in children <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Berkovic|first1=Samuel F.|title=Epileptic encephalopathies of infancy: welcome advances|journal=Lancet|date=December 21
column3: 2019|volume=394|issue=10216|pages=2203-2204|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(19)31239-5}}</ref>. It is a rare genetic disorder that affects an estimated 1 in every 20
column5: 000 births.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hurst|first1=Daniel L.|title=Epidemiology of Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy|journal=Epilepsia|date=August 1990|volume=31|issue=4|pages=397–400|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1157.1990.tb05494.x|pmid=1695145}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yakoub|first1=M|last2=Dulac|first2=O|last3=Jambaqué|first3=I|last4=Chiron|first4=C|last5=Plouin|first5=P|title=Early diagnosis of severe myoclonic epilepsy in infancy.|journal=Brain & Development|date=September 1992|volume=14|issue=5|pages=299–303|doi=10.1093/brain/aws151|pmid=1456383}}</ref>

column1: [[Charlotte Dravet]] first described severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy in Centre Saint Paul
column2: [[Marseille]] France in 1978 and the name was later changed to Dravet syndrome in 1989.<ref name=CharlotteDravet>{{cite journal|last1=Dravet|first1=Charlotte |title=The core Dravet syndrome phenotype|journal=Epilepsia|date=1 April 2011|volume=52|pages=3–9|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.02994.x|pmid=21463272 }}</ref> Similar descriptions were given by Bernardo Dalla Bernardina in Verona.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bernardo Dalla Bernardina {{!}} University of Verona (UNIVR)|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Bernardo_Dalla_Bernardina|website=ResearchGate|language=en}}</ref>
who was diagnosed as having Dravet syndrome
column3: was the focus of a cause célèbre to provide a means for use of cannabidiol for persons with intractable seizures. She died in April
column4: 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://coloradosun.com/2020/04/08/charlotte-figi-cbd-coronavirus/ |title=Charlotte Fiji |last=Ingold |first=John |date=April 8
column5: 2020 |website= |publisher= The Colorado Sun |access-date=April 13
column6: 2020 |quote=\"Charlotte Figi
column7: the Colorado Springs girl who
column8: as a gleeful and fragile child
column9: launched a movement that led to sweeping changes in marijuana laws across the globe
column10: has died from complications possibly related to the new coronavirus.\"}}

'''Dravet syndrome''', previously known as '''severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy''' ('''SMEI'''), is a catastrophic type of [[epilepsy]] with prolonged seizures that are often triggered by hot temperatures or [[fever]].<ref name=Lh2013/> It is very difficult to treat with [[anticonvulsant medication]]s. It often begins before 1 year of age.<ref name=Lh2013>{{cite book|last=Lhatoo|editor=Simon Shorvon|editor2=Renzo Guerrini|editor3=Mark Cook|editor4= Samden D|title=Oxford textbook of epilepsy and epileptic seizures|year=2013|publisher=Oxford Univ. Press|location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-965904-3 |page=13|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LeGv1qOK_0wC&pg=PA13}}</ref>

==Signs and symptoms==
Dravet syndrome has been characterized by prolonged [[Febrile seizure|febrile]] and non-febrile [[seizure]]s within the first year of a child’s life. This disease progresses to other [[seizure types]] like myoclonic and partial seizures, psychomotor delay, and [[ataxia]].<ref name=Reference3>{{cite journal|last1=Selmer|first1=K.K.|last2=Eriksson|first2=A-S|last3=Brandal|first3=K.|last4=Egeland|first4=T.|last5=Tallaksen|first5=C.|last6=Undlien|first6=D.E.|title=Parental SCN1A mutation mosaicism in familial Dravet syndrome|journal=Clinical Genetics|date=1 October 2009|volume=76|issue=4|pages=398–403|doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2009.01208.x|pmid=19673951}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2015--></ref> It is characterized by cognitive impairment, behavioral disorders, and motor deficits.<ref name=Reference2>{{cite journal|last1=Granata|first1=Tiziana|title=Comprehensive care of children with Dravet syndrome|journal=Epilepsia|date=1 April 2011|volume=52|pages=90–94|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03011.x|pmid=21463289}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2015--></ref> Behavioral deficits often include hyperactivity and impulsiveness, and in more rare cases, autistic-like behaviors.<ref name=\Reference2\" /> Dravet syndrome is also associated with sleep disorders including [[somnolence]] and [[insomnia]].<ref name=\"Reference2\" />  The seizures experienced by people with Dravet syndrome become worse as the patient ages
column3: as the disease is not very observable when symptoms first appear.<ref name=\"Reference2\" /> This coupled with the range of severity differing between each individual diagnosed and the resistance of these seizures to drugs has made it challenging to develop treatments.<ref name=\"Reference2\" />

column1: Dravet syndrome appears during the first year of life
column2: often beginning around six months of age with frequent febrile seizures (fever-related seizures). Children with Dravet syndrome typically experience a lagged development of language and motor skills
column3: hyperactivity and sleep difficulties
column4: chronic infection
column5: growth and balance issues
column6: and difficulty relating to others. The effects of this disorder do not diminish over time
column7: and children diagnosed with Dravet syndrome require fully committed caretakers with tremendous patience and the ability to closely monitor them.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\">Miller
column8: I.O. and Sotero de Menezes. M.A. SCN1A-Related Seizure Disorders. 2007 Nov 29 [Updated 2014 May 15]. GeneReviews® [Internet]. Seattle (WA): University of Washington
column9: Seattle; 1993–2015. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1318/</ref>

column1: Febrile seizures are divided into two categories known as simple and complex. A febrile seizure would be categorized as complex if it has occurred within 24 hours of another seizure or if it lasts longer than 15 minutes. A febrile seizure lasting less than 15 minutes would be considered simple. Sometimes modest hyperthermic stressors like physical exertion or a hot bath can provoke seizures in affected individuals.<ref name=\"GeneReview1\"/> However
column2: any seizure uninterrupted after 5 minutes
column3: without a resumption of [[postictal]] (more normal; recovery-type; after-seizure) consciousness can lead to potentially fatal [[status epilepticus]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}

column1: In most cases the mutations in Dravet syndrome are not hereditary and the mutated gene is found for the first time in a single family member.<ref name=\"Reference3\" /> In 70–90% of patients
column2: Dravet syndrome is caused by [[nonsense mutations]] in the [[SCN1A]] gene resulting in a premature stop codon and thus a non-functional protein.<ref name=\"Reference3\" />  This gene normally codes for neuronal voltage-gated sodium channel Na(V)1.1.<ref name=Reference4>{{cite journal|last1=Cheah|first1=C|last2=Catterall|first2=W.A.|title=Characterizing the role of sodium channels in mouse models of Dravet Syndrome|date=2012}}</ref> In mouse models
column3: these loss-of-function mutations have been observed to result in a decrease in sodium currents and impaired excitability of GABAergic [[interneuron]]s of the [[hippocampus]].<ref name=\"Reference4\" /> The researchers found that loss of NA(V)1.1 channels was sufficient to cause the epilepsy and premature death seen in Dravet syndrome.<ref name=\"Reference4\" /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Couzin-Frankel |first1=Jennifer |title=Sudden death in epilepsy: Researchers finger possible cause |journal=Science |date=8 April 2015 |doi=10.1126/science.aab2456 }}</ref>

column1: The timing of the first signs and symptoms in Dravet syndrome occur about the same time as normal childhood vaccinations
column2: leading some to believe the vaccine was the cause. However
column3: this is likely a non-specific response to fever
column4: as vaccination often induces fever
column5: <ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lin YJ
column6: Wen CN
column7: Lin YY
column8: Hsieh WC
column9: Chang CC
column13: Chen CH
column14: Fang CT |title=Oil-in-water emulsion adjuvants for pediatric influenza vaccines: a systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=Nat Commun |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=315 |date=January 2020 |pmid=31949137 |pmc=6965081 |doi=10.1038/s41467-019-14230-x |url=}}</ref> and fever is known to be associated with seizures in persons with Dravet syndrome.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dravetfoundation.org/what-is-dravet-syndrome/|title=What is Dravet Syndrome?|last=admin|publisher=}}</ref>  Some of the patients who put forth vaccine injury claims from encephalopathy were later found
column16: to actually have Dravet syndrome.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ben-Menachem |first1=Elinor |title=Vaccination and the Onset of Dravet Syndrome |journal=Epilepsy Currents |date=4 January 2019 |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=120–122 |doi=10.5698/1535-7511-11.4.120 |pmid=21852883 |pmc=3152151 }}</ref>

column2: [[Marseille]] France in 1978 and the name was later changed to Dravet syndrome in 1989.<ref name=CharlotteDravet>{{cite journal|last1=Dravet|first1=Charlotte |title=The core Dravet syndrome phenotype|journal=Epilepsia|date=1 April 2011|volume=52|pages=3–9|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.02994.x|pmid=21463272 }}</ref> Similar descriptions were given by Bernardo Dalla Bernardina in Verona.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bernardo Dalla Bernardina {{!}} University of Verona (UNIVR)|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Bernardo_Dalla_Bernardina|website=ResearchGate|language=en}}</ref>
who was diagnosed as having Dravet syndrome
column3: was the focus of a cause célèbre to provide a means for use of cannabidiol for persons with intractable seizures. She died in April
column4: 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://coloradosun.com/2020/04/08/charlotte-figi-cbd-coronavirus/ |title=Charlotte Fiji |last=Ingold |first=John |date=April 8
column5: 2020 |website= |publisher= The Colorado Sun |access-date=April 13

column9: launched a movement that led to sweeping changes in marijuana laws across the globe

column2: Giorgio Fini
column3: is in [[Boston]] for a concert when he gets a phone call asking him to perform at [[Metropolitan Opera|The Met]]. The call brings up bad memories from his disastrous appearance there seven years earlier. It scares him to the point where he cannot sing at rehearsal. Everyone panics thinking he is losing his voice.

column2: Henry Pollack
column3: has a throat specialist Pamela Taylor
column4: look at Giorgio. He at first refuses her
column5: believing her not to be a doctor
column6: but \"a nurse\" because she is a woman. After being scared into seeing her by his manager
column7: she immediately detects that the problem is psychological
column8: not physical. Pamela makes up a serious-sounding name for the condition and gives Giorgio a shot to cure it
column9: which she reveals to Henry is harmless vitamin B12. After reacting to the prick of the needle
column10: Giorgio instantly gets his voice back and proceeds to sing the following day at the [[Hatch Shell]] in Boston.

column1: Giorgio is immediately physically attracted to Pamela
column2: and even though he is married with two children
column3: she agrees to go out on a dinner date. The date does not go well
column4: but Giorgio is persistent
column5: visiting the hospital where Pamela works. His quick thinking helps calm a scared child getting ready for surgery to remove his tonsils
column6: promising ice cream which he delivers after the surgery.  Impressed by his handling of the children
column7: she agrees to another date. She eventually becomes his traveling companion. After spending a romantic week in [[San Francisco]] and the wine country visiting friends of Giorgio
column8: the two eventually fall in love
column9: even though at the start of their relationship he told her this was just \"a fling\" and made her promise not to fall in love with him.  He gains the confidence through his love for her to agree to perform at the Met in the [[Giacomo Puccini]] opera ''[[Turandot]]''. However
column10: because Giorgio refuses to leave his wife
column11: Pamela throws him a kiss and leaves the Met while Giorgio is singing \"[[Nessun Dorma]]\" to her.

column2: ''Turandot''

column1: In June 1980 MGM announced they had signed a deal with Pavarotti to star in the movie. \"I have done a lot of television and think I have the experience to do a movie
column2: \" said the singer. \"I will put myself in the hands of those making this but hopefully my sense of humor will come through.<ref name=\"los\">LIGHTS
column3: CAMERA... PAVAROTTI: MGM signs tenor for motion picture debut in romantic comedy 'Yes
column4: Giorgio'

column2: Grant. Los Angeles Times 5 June 1980: h1.</ref>

column1: Pavarotti said he did the film \"Because they asked me\" and \"it has been almost 30 years since the days when Mario Lanza made a movie
column2: and I thought it was time for the world of opera to come out in a movie. I think it will be good for the opera and probably good for me.\"<ref>At the Movies; PAVAROTTI PREPARES FOR A DEBUT
Judy. New York Times

column1: The singer said [[Mario Lanza]] was an \"inspiration for me. He did a lot for the world of opera
column2: and I believe he had one of the greatest
column3: most exciting voices I have ever heard. Of course I never saw him on a stage; perhaps he would have been unable to sing opera. But I do know that his voice was definitely exciting.\"<ref name=\"debut\">PAVAROTTI IS RELISHING HIS MOVIE DEBUT Boston Globe 22 Aug 1981: 1.</ref>

column1: Producer Peter Fetterman said originally he had wanted to remake ''[[The Great Caruso]]'' \"But that wasn't very realistic. No one in Hollywood was going to invest a lot of money in a period piece. I just knew that someone had to make a movie with Pavarotti. He's got so much charisma. A talent like his appears only once in every generation. The story is a musical romance like those wonderful MGM films with Mario Lanza.\"<ref name=\"boston\"/>

\"The film's budget will be substantial\" said executive producer Herbert Breslin. \"We're not going to skimp on it. We'll spend whatever it takes to make a movie right for Mr Pavarotti.\"<ref name=\"los\"/>
In December 1980 it was announced that Franklin Schaffner would direct.<ref>FILM CLIPS: 'POPEYE

column1: Pavarotti said \"I am enjoying the movie... Are there any surprises? No surprises. Except being awakened at 5 a.m. For a man who usually gets out of bed at 10 or 12
column2: that is a surprise... Will I do another film? I'll tell you after I see this one.\" <ref name=\"debut\"/>

column2: Giorgio'' opened to negative reviews and is considered Schaffner's weakest film. [[Gene Siskel]] and [[Roger Ebert]] selected the film as one of the worst of the year in a 1982 episode of ''[[At the Movies (1982 TV program)|At the Movies]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siskelandebert.org/video/N44N7DM9RKON/At-the-Movies-Stinkers-of-1982|title=Worst of 1982|accessdate=December 11
column3: 2016|work=[[At the Movies (1982 TV program)|At the Movies]]|location=[[Chicago]]|publisher=[[Tribune Broadcasting]]}}</ref>

column1: [[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote in her review: \"[[Luciano Pavarotti|LUCIANO PAVAROTTI]] has a food fight
column2: rides in a balloon and sings ''[[I Left My Heart in San Francisco]]'' in ''Yes
column3: Giorgio
column4: '' a movie that means to be as broad and hearty as its star. These and other antics are the film's attempt to paint Mr. Pavarotti as a good sport
column5: a regular guy. Not too regular
column6: of course - at dependable intervals
column7: Mr. Pavarotti's Giorgio Fini bursts forth with ''[[La Donna e Mobile]]'' from ''[[Rigoletto]]''
column8: or ''[[Nessun Dorma]]'' from ''[[Turandot]]
column9: '' or something else designed to demonstrate his musical mastery. He sings ''[[Ave Maria]]'' and ''[[O Sole Mio]]'' and a painfully lighthearted new ballad by Marilyn and Alan Bergman. ''Yes
column11: emphasizing Fini's affability and his genius in equal measure. As if that weren't enough
column12: he is also supposed to be a world-class ladies' man. An opening title proclaims that ''this film is dedicated to lovers everywhere.'' [...] Mr. Pavarotti marches happily through ''Yes
column13: Giorgio'' with an air of utter confidence. The story seems to strike him as a perfectly plausible one
column14: and to some slight extent his optimism rubs off on the other players. Without him
column15: there wouldn't be a movie here at all; with him
column16: at least there is a good-natured spectacle. Not even his most ardent fans are liable to love it
column17: but they probably won't find it intolerable
column18: either. There's too much singing here for that. ''Opera puts me to sleep
column19: '' one character is made to tell Giorgio
column21: ''That is because you have never heard me sing.'' He means it
column23: Giorgio'' is rated PG (''Parental Guidance Suggested''). Its sexual innuendoes will not disturb children
column24: although adults may find them alarming.\"<ref name=\"NYT\">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9E0CE0DB103BF937A1575AC0A964948260|accessdate=December 11

column1: San Giacomo's first television appearances were four episodes on three television series during 1987.<ref name=\"imdb\">{{IMDb name|0000624}}</ref>  Two notable appearances were in ''[[Crime Story (U.S. TV series)|Crime Story]]'' in 1988 for the episode \"Protected Witness\" (Season 2 / Episode 13) as Theresa Farantino

column2: San Giacomo played a supporting role as [[Julia Roberts]]'s character's wisecracking friend Kit De Luca in ''[[Pretty Woman]]''. column3: San Giacomo shifted to television in the role of hot-tempered
column4: sassy journalist [[Maya Gallo]] in the [[situation comedy]] ''[[Just Shoot Me!]]'' (1997–2003).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Just-Shoot-Season-3/10949 |title=Laura San Giacomo interview by Chet Cooper |publisher=abilitymagazine.com |accessdate=2012-06-06 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916045406/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Just-Shoot-Season-3/10949 |archivedate=2011-09-16 }}</ref> Her character was partially based on an unproduced idea that executive producer [[Steven Levitan]] once had in mind for actress [[Janeane Garofalo]] when he was a writer for ''[[The Larry Sanders Show]]''. San Giacomo was originally cast in the starring role
column5: since the series was meant to center on her character; however
column6: the show soon adopted an ensemble style. Despite the shift in focus
column7: San Giacomo remained an integral part of the show and with top billing. She and the four other main cast members appeared in all 148 episodes of the series
column8: which lasted until 2003.

column1: San Giacomo's work during Season 2 (1997–1998) earned her a Golden Globe Award nomination in 1998 for [[List of Golden Globe Awards: Television
column2: Best Actress
column3: Comedy/Musical|Best Actress in a Television Comedy or Musical]]; the award went to ''[[Ally McBeal|Ally McBeal's]]'' [[Calista Flockhart]].

column1: After NBC cancelled ''Just Shoot Me!'' in 2003
column2: San Giacomo appeared sporadically on television and in films. She made guest appearances on several television series
column3: including the short-lived [[CBS]] crime drama ''[[The Handler (TV series)|The Handler]]'' in 2003 and [[HBO]]'s ''[[Unscripted]]'' in 2005. She was the narrator for the [[true crime]] series ''Snapped: Killer Couples'' on [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]]. San Giacomo also appeared in the 2005 films ''[[Checking Out (2005 film)|Checking Out]]'' and ''[[Havoc (2005 film)|Havoc]]''
column4: as well as the 2006 film ''Conquistadora''. San Giacomo was to have made her return to television on [[The WB Television Network|The WB's]] new drama ''[[Related]]'' in 2005
column5: but the character was recast due to creative differences. [[Kiele Sanchez]] took her place as \"Anne Sorelli\" on the show. San Giacomo also made few public appearances; she made her first public appearance in nearly a year on 19 October 2005 at the ''15th Annual Environmental Media Awards''.  She made two more public appearances at the ''Crystal and Lucy Awards'' on 6 June 2006 and at the ''3rd Annual [[Alfred E. Mann|Alfred Mann]] Foundation Innovation and Inspiration Gala'' on 9 September 2006.

column2: San Giacomo returned to network television with three guest appearances on the third season of ''[[Veronica Mars]]''. She reunited with her former [[love interest]] from ''Just Shoot Me!''
column3: [[Enrico Colantoni]]
column4: playing Harmony Chase. Both Colantoni and San Giacomo enjoyed their reunion so much that they lobbied for their characters to appear together in further episodes.<ref>[http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-story-laurasangiacomo-veronicamars
column6: 2855432.story Former 'Just Shoot Me' Stars Enjoy Life on 'Mars' – Laura San Giacomo and Enrico Colantoni reunite on CW drama – Zap2it] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120926125445/http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-story-laurasangiacomo-veronicamars%2C0%2C2855432.story |date=2012-09-26 }}</ref>

column2: San Giacomo secured her first starring role on a television program after ''Just Shoot Me!''
column3: when she reunited with a former peer and co-starred opposite fellow Carnegie-Mellon alum [[Holly Hunter]] in [[Turner Network Television|TNT's]] [[drama]] series ''[[Saving Grace (TV Series)|Saving Grace]]''. San Giacomo played Grace's best friend Rhetta Rodriguez.

column2: San Giacomo guest starred in the episode titled \"Death Becomes Her\" on the [[USA Network|USA network's]] ''[[In Plain Sight]]''. She played a woman from an organized crime family with a terminal illness. In December 2011
column3: San Giacomo appeared on the episode titled \"Beards\" on ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]''
column4: as Caroline
column5: Melanie's estranged sister.

column1: San Giacomo has been married twice
column2: first to actor [[Cameron Dye]] (1990–1998)
column3: with whom she had a son
column4: Mason Dye (b. November 19
column6: who has [[cerebral palsy]]
column7: and second to actor [[Matt Adler]] (m. 2000).

column1: San Giacomo is a cousin of [[Torry Castellano]]
column2: former drummer of the rock group [[The Donnas]].

column1: She lives in the [[San Fernando Valley]]
column2: [[California]]. Her hobbies include horseback riding
column3: gymnastics
column4: ice skating
column5: ballet
column6: tennis
column7: golf and playing piano.

column1: San Giacomo is a strong supporter of charitable causes
column2: most prominently those related to [[disabilities]]. She has appeared at the [[Environmental Media Awards]]
column3: the \"Voices For Change\" gala benefit and concert which benefits Children with Disabilities
column4: and the \"Friends Finding a Cure\" gala benefiting Project [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]]. She is also a founder of the CHIME Charter Elementary School
column5: an [[elementary school]] in [[Woodland Hills
column6: Los Angeles|Woodland Hills]]
column7: California. Chime is an inclusion school for all children of all abilities. The school opened its doors in 2001. As a charter school
column8: CHIME provides free [[public education]] to students and admits them through a lottery system. The school serves approximately 200 children in [[kindergarten]] through fifth grade who live in communities around California's [[San Fernando Valley]].<ref>[http://www.ed.gov/news/newsletters/innovator/2005/0509.html Archived: The Education Innovator-9 May 2005]</ref> Today CHIME services grade kindergarten through eighth grade and has almost 700 students.

column6: 2855432.story Former 'Just Shoot Me' Stars Enjoy Life on 'Mars' – Laura San Giacomo and Enrico Colantoni reunite on CW drama – Zap2it] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120926125445/http://www.zap2it.com/tv/news/zap-story-laurasangiacomo-veronicamars%2C0%2C2855432.story |date=2012-09-26 }}</ref>

column2: San Giacomo secured her first starring role on a television program after ''Just Shoot Me!''
column3: when she reunited with a former peer and co-starred opposite fellow Carnegie-Mellon alum [[Holly Hunter]] in [[Turner Network Television|TNT's]] [[drama]] series ''[[Saving Grace (TV Series)|Saving Grace]]''. San Giacomo played Grace's best friend Rhetta Rodriguez.

column2: San Giacomo guest starred in the episode titled \"Death Becomes Her\" on the [[USA Network|USA network's]] ''[[In Plain Sight]]''. She played a woman from an organized crime family with a terminal illness. In December 2011
column3: San Giacomo appeared on the episode titled \"Beards\" on ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]''
column4: as Caroline
column5: Melanie's estranged sister.

column1: San Giacomo has been married twice
column2: first to actor [[Cameron Dye]] (1990–1998)
column3: with whom she had a son
column4: Mason Dye (b. November 19
column6: who has [[cerebral palsy]]
column7: and second to actor [[Matt Adler]] (m. 2000).

column1: San Giacomo is a cousin of [[Torry Castellano]]
column2: former drummer of the rock group [[The Donnas]].

column1: She lives in the [[San Fernando Valley]]
column2: [[California]]. Her hobbies include horseback riding
column3: gymnastics
column4: ice skating
column5: ballet
column6: tennis
column7: golf and playing piano.

column1: San Giacomo is a strong supporter of charitable causes
column2: most prominently those related to [[disabilities]]. She has appeared at the [[Environmental Media Awards]]
column3: the \"Voices For Change\" gala benefit and concert which benefits Children with Disabilities
column4: and the \"Friends Finding a Cure\" gala benefiting Project [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]]. She is also a founder of the CHIME Charter Elementary School
column5: an [[elementary school]] in [[Woodland Hills
column6: Los Angeles|Woodland Hills]]
column7: California. Chime is an inclusion school for all children of all abilities. The school opened its doors in 2001. As a charter school
column8: CHIME provides free [[public education]] to students and admits them through a lottery system. The school serves approximately 200 children in [[kindergarten]] through fifth grade who live in communities around California's [[San Fernando Valley]].<ref>[http://www.ed.gov/news/newsletters/innovator/2005/0509.html Archived: The Education Innovator-9 May 2005]</ref> Today CHIME services grade kindergarten through eighth grade and has almost 700 students.
