{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = The Man Who Could Cheat Death | image = ManWhoCouldCheatDeathPoster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Terence Fisher]] | producer = [[Michael Carreras]]
[[Anthony Nelson Keys|Anthony Nelson-Keys]] | screenplay = [[Jimmy Sangster]] | based on = ''[[The Man in Half Moon Street (play)|The Man in Half Moon Street]]'' by [[Barré Lyndon]] | starring = [[Anton Diffring]]
[[Hazel Court]]
[[Christopher Lee]] | music = [[Richard Rodney Bennett|Richard Bennett]] | cinematography = [[Jack Asher]] | editing = John Dunsford | studio = [[Hammer Film Productions]] | distributor = Paramount British Pictures (UK)
[[Paramount Pictures]] (US) | released = {{fim date|df=y|1959|11|30}} | runtime = 83 min. | country = England | language = English | budget = [[Pound sterling|GBP]] £84,000 }} '''''The Man Who Could Cheat Death''''' is a 1959 British [[horror film|horror]] film, directed by [[Terence Fisher]] and starring [[Anton Diffring]], [[Hazel Court]] and [[Christopher Lee]]. [[Jimmy Sangster]] adapted the screenplay from the play ''[[The Man in Half Moon Street (play)|The Man in Half Moon Street]]'' by [[Barré Lyndon]], which had been [[The Man in Half Moon Street|previously filmed in 1945]]. ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was produced by [[Michael Carreras]] and [[Anthony Nelson Keys]] for [[Hammer Film Productions]]. It was released in the US on 19 August 1959 and in the UK on 30 November 1959. == Plot == Paris, 1890. Dr Georges Bonnet (Diffring), MD and sculptor, harbours an unusual secret. Although he appears to be in his mid-30s, he is actually 104-years-old, and has kept his youth and vitality through [[Parathyroid gland|parathyroid]] gland transplants every 10 years. But things are going wrong. Prof Ludwig Weiss ([[Arnold Marlé]]) of Vienna, co-discoverer of the anti-ageing process, is three weeks late in arriving at Georges' home to perform the latest transplant. As such, Georges must drink a steaming green liquid to stay young. When Georges' latest model, Margo Philippe ([[Delphi Lawrence]]), comes across Georges swilling the fluid, he strikes her down. Georges has invited a number of people to a reception at which he will unveil his bust of Margo, including Janine Dubois (Court), his former lover, and Dr Pierre Girard (Lee), Janine's current companion. When the 89-year-old Ludwig later arrives, it is quite apparent he will be unable to operate on Georges because a stroke has incapacitated his right hand. Ludwig tells Georges they must find another surgeon. Georges and Ludwig invite Janine and Pierre to dinner. In private, Ludwig convinces Pierre to perform the transplant. However, Janine is still in love with Georges, and when he mysteriously says he must soon leave Paris so he can 'lift the curtain of life and see what lies beyond', Janine asks to accompany him. As the dinner party ends, [[National Police (France)|Surété]] Inspector LeGris ([[Francis de Wolff|Francis De Wolff]]) arrives. He is investigating Margo's disappearance. Georges denies knowing her whereabouts and, when LeGris asks to see the bust of Margo, he tells him that he accidentally destroyed it. LeGris leaves and Georges admits to his startled guests that he lied but says the police would probably damage the bust if he turned it over to them. After Janine and Pierre have left, Ludwig tells Georges that Pierre will operate. But Ludwig has grown suspicious of Georges and says it is strange that Georges' models have gone missing right after Georges' transplants. Ludwig also tells him that after examining the newest parathyroid gland, he can tell Georges has harvested it from a living person, instead of it being 'revitalised' from a corpse. When Ludwig tells him that his actions are unjustified, Georges says sadly that he's done what he's done because he has been left 'utterly alone - again and again' and is tired of having to start a new life every decade. Georges horrifies Ludwig by saying he wants to end his loneliness by having Janine with him forever. The men argue violently, and Georges strangles Ludwig to death. Pierre arrives the following morning to perform the operation, but Georges tells him that Ludwig was unexpectedly called back to Vienna. Pierre refuses to carry on and suggests that Georges find another surgeon. But Georges can find no one who is willing or able, LeGris tells Pierre of the disappearances of three young women at 10 year intervals - in London, San Francisco and Bern, Switzerland - and that each modelled for a sculptor who was an MD and who went missing at the same time. With Margo also missing, LeGris believes Georges is responsible for all the disappearances. Georges takes Janine to a storeroom which holds his sculptures. He proudly shows her the first figurine he made as a boy. The figurine is dated 1798. Janine laughingly says the date must be incorrect because if it weren't, Georges would be 104. Georges abruptly leaves, locking Janine in the storeroom. Georges tells Pierre that he and Ludwig discovered the secret of 'perpetual life' decades earlier. But he can't reveal the secret to the world because if everyone could live forever, paradoxically, everyone would die as there would be no supply of parathyroid glands to keep them alive. Pierre again refuses to perform the transplant, calling it 'an offence against nature [and] and offence against God'. But he relents when Georges threatens Janine's life. Janine finds a now-mad Margo imprisoned in the storeroom. Meanwhile, Pierre fakes the operation - making the incision at Georges' waist but not transplanting the gland. Georges rushes to the storeroom, and as Pierre and LeGris follow, Georges tells Janine that the same operation will allow her to live forever, always young and beautiful and in love. She refuses. Suddenly, Georges begins ageing rapidly and realises that Pierre didn't actually perform the operation. As he exclaims he's dying, Margo, laughing dementedly, throws an oil lamp on him, setting him and the storeroom afire. Pierre and LeGris rescue Janine. Georges and Margo die in the flames. == Cast == ''Credited:'' * [[Anton Diffring]] as Dr. Georges Bonnet * [[Hazel Court]] as Janine Dubois * [[Christopher Lee]] as Dr. Pierre Gerard * [[Arnold Marlé]] as Prof. Ludwig Weiss * [[Delphi Lawrence]] as Margo Phillipe * [[Francis de Wolff]] as Insp. LeGris ''Uncredited:'' * Gerda Larsen as Street Girl * Middleton Woods as Little Man * [[Denis Shaw]] as Tavern Customer * Ian Hewitson as Roger * Frederick Rawlings as Footman * [[Marie Burke]] as Woman * [[Charles Lloyd-Pack|Charles Lloyd-Park]] as Man * John Harrison as Servant * [[Lockwood West]] as 1st Doctor * [[Ronald Adam (actor)|Ronald Adam]] as 2nd Doctor * [[Barry Shawin]] as 3rd Doctor
== Production == The lead role of Bonnet was originally offered to [[Peter Cushing]], who turned it down six days before shooting started. Cushing's reason was that he was completely exhausted 'following the shooting of ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles (1959 film)|The Hound of the Baskervilles]]'' (1959), which had just wrapped up'. The loss of Cushing caused Hammer to threaten legal action against him. However, Cushing had not signed a final contract with Hammer, and nothing could be done,{{Cite book|last=Maxford|first=Howard|title=Hammer Complete: The Films
column5: the Personnel
column6: the Company|publisher=McFarland & Co. Inc.|year=2019|isbn=9781476670072|location=Jefferson NC|pages=531-533}}</ref> although an angry [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]]
column7: which was partly financing and distributing the film
column8: 'relegated to picture to the lower half of double bills in the States'.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite book|last=Fellner|first=Chris|title=The Encyclopedia of Hammer Films|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2019|isbn=9781538126585|location=Lanham MD|pages=273-276}}</ref> The lead went to Diffring
column9: who had played it 18 months earlier in the British ABC-TV adaptation of ''The Man in Half Moon Street''
column10: and episode of the programme ''Hour of Mystery''.<ref name=\":0\" /> ABC was part of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] commercial consortium and broadcast primarily in the Midlands and North of England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.screenonline.org.uk/id/521981/index.html|title=ABC Television|last=Elen|first=Richard G.|date=|website=BFI Screenonline|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=22 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: Filming of ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' took place between 17 November and 30 December 1958 at [[Bray Studios (UK)|Bray Studios]]. Its working title was ''The Man in the Rue Noire''.<ref name=\":1\" />
The European release of the film featured a scene in which Court appeared topless.{{sfn|Hallenbeck|2011|p=104}} She was paid 'an extra £2000 ($5
column2: 600 in 1959 dollars)' for the scene
column3: in which she is posing for a sculpture made by Diffring's character. The stone bust of Janine that is shown repeatedly in the film is in fact 'a plaster cast made from Court's torso'.<ref name=\":1\" /> The scene does not appear in the UK or US prints and the footage is 'unfortunately lost (...) although a photo exists'.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Meikle|first=Denis|title=A History of Horrors: The Rise and Fall of the House of Hammer|last2=Koetting|first2=Christopher T.|publisher=The Scarecrow Press|year=2009|isbn=9780810863538|location=Lanham MD|pages=71-73}}</ref><ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book|last=Carter|first=Robert Michael 'Bobb'|title=The Women of Hammer Horror: A Biographical Dictionary and Filmography|publisher=McFarland & Co. Inc.|year=2013|isbn=9780786472086|location=Jefferson NC|pages=50}}</ref>

column1: A scene in which [[Michael Ripper]] portrayed a morgue attendant was cut from the film's release print.<ref name=\":0\" />

''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was granted an X-certificate by the [[British Board of Film Classification|BBFC]] on 8 April 1959. The X-cert meant that the film could only be exhibited to people age 16 or older. The film was cut in order to get the certificate
column2: which allowed it to be shown in the UK
column3: but the details of what or how much was cut are unknown.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/man-who-could-cheat-death-1959|title=The Man Who Could Cheat Death (1959)|last=|first=|date=|website=British Board of Film Classification|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was distributed in the UK and the US by Paramount.<ref name=\":0\" /> The film was first screened at the London Trade Show on 5 June 1959. It went into general release in the UK on 30 November 1959 as the first film on a double bill with ''[[The Evil That is Eve]]'' (1957). However
column2: the movie was in general release earlier in the US
column3: where it opened on 19 August 1959.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The film was still being shown in US movie theatres into the 1960s. For example
column2: it was the second film in a triple feature - between ''[[The Black Orchid (film)|The Black Orchid]]'' (1958) and ''Maracaibo'' (1959) - at the Mt Lebanon Drive-In in Lebanon PA on 19 July 1963.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oberver-reporter.com/blogs/driveintimemachine/witches-werewolves-and-a-weasel-at-local-drive-ins-in-the-past/article_0f171790-8aa9-11e8-b0a5-7357ac34e9fc.html|title=Witches
column3: werewolves and a weasel at local drive-ins in the past|last=Channell|first=Justin|date=23 July 2018|website=The Washington PA Observer-Reporter|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=31 March 2020}}</ref> Two years later
column4: the movie continued to be at the bottom of a double bill. On 7 May 1965
column5: it ran as the second film to [[Dr. Terror's House of Horrors|''Dr. Terror's House of Horrors'']] (1965) at three theatres in San Francisco - the New Mission Theatre
column6: the El Rancho Drive-In and the Esquire Theatre - as well as at theatres in the surrounding [[East Bay]] communities of Oakland
column7: Fremont
column8: Hayward and San Leandro.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32934619/dr-terrors-house-of-horrosthe/|title=The San Francisco Examiner advertisement|last=Clipped by|first=rivamarsh|date=16 June 2019|website=Newspapers.com|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=22 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: For home viewing in the UK
column2: the video was given a 12 certificate by the BBFC on 28 August 2015 for 'limited' but 'moderate injury detail'
column3: which includes scarred faces
column4: rapid ageing
column5: strangulation and death by fire.<ref name=\":2\" /> The first US release of a video of the film was on 21 October 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/82724/Man-Who-Could-Cheat-Death-The/misc-notes.html|title=Man Who Could Cheat Death
column6: The (1959)|last=|first=|date=|website=Turner Classic Movies Data Base|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: ''The'' ''Hammer Story: The Authorised History of Hammer Films'' calls the film an \"odd mish-mash of mad scientist sci-fi flick and gothic flannel\" that \"suffers from an excess of dialogue and a lack of action.\"{{sfn|Hearn|Barnes|2007|p=41}}

This assessment is reflected in other contemporary reviews. Film scholar Chris Fellner quotes several: the 20 June 1959 issue of ''[[Harrison's Reports]]'' says that the movie's 'chief drawback' is 'that it is given more to talk than to movement'; ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''<nowiki/>'s issue of 24 June 1959 calls it 'well acted and intelligently conceived. But invention and embellishment in this field appear to have been exhausted'; and the ''[[Motion Picture Exhibitor]]'' issue of 1 July 1959 describes ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' as suffering from 'relying mainly on talk'.<ref name=\":1\" />

The film is referred to by journalist Howard Maxford as a 'commercial and artistic disaster' and a 'bog standard surgical thriller' that is 'by no means a Hammer classic'. He calls Terence Fisher's direction 'curiously unambitious'
column2: characterised by 'many scenes filmed in lengthy
column3: static takes
column4: almost as if from the stalls of a theatre'. Maxford also dislikes the 'Bright
column5: bland lighting' and 'garish Technicolor film stock' which together 'make for some visually tedious and unattractive images'.<ref name=\":0\" />

column2: film scholar Phil Hardy writes that visually the film 'looks like one of Hammer's more lavish productions'
column3: although it is a 'minor item' in Fisher's work. He describes the movie as having a 'perfunctory script'
column4: which makes it a 'rather awkward variation on the [[Dorian Gray (character)|Dorian Gray]] motif'.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book|last=Hardy
column5: ed.|first=Phil|title=The Encyclopedia of Horror Movies|publisher=Harper & Row
column6: Publishers|year=1986|isbn=0060550503|location=NY|pages=115}}</ref>

column1: In the 'Hazel Court' chapter of ''Scream Queens: Heroines of the Horrors''
column2: author Calvin Thomas Beck praises the performances of the three main actors. He writes that Diffring shows 'unique and excellent villainy' and is a 'magnificent heavy who has been shamefully neglected by filmmakers'. Court
column3: he writes
column4: is a 'fine
column5: striking actress at all times' who 'screams and cringes properly' during the movie. He calls ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' one of her 'finest British thrillers'. Beck also notes that Lee 'unexpectedly reversed his monster-villain image' in the film.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Beck|first=Calvin Thomas|title=Scream Queens: Heroines of the Horrors|publisher=Macmillan Publishing Co. Inc.|year=1978|isbn=0025081705|location=NY|pages=280-281}}</ref>

column1: Author 'Bobb' Carter agrees with Beck's view of Court's performance. Carter calls it 'on the whole (...) a solid
column2: impassioned performance that makes it a shame that this was her last role for Hammer'
column3: even though her character
column4: Janine
column5: has the 'distressing trait of not being able to smell something fishy even if there was a whale in the room'.<ref name=\":3\" />

column1: Other critics disagree about the quality of the acting in the film. Maxford calls Diffring's performance 'cold-eyed' and suggests that 'audiences were more used to seeing [him] playing ruthless Nazis'
column2: <ref name=\":0\" /> while Hardy says that 'Lee simply walks through his part'.<ref name=\":4\" />

column1: The screenplay of ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was rewritten as an inexpensive paperback novel in 1959. It was published in the US by [[Avon Books]] and sold for 35¢
column2: with the authors named as 'Barre' Lyndon and Jimmy Sangster. In the UK
column3: where the book sold for 2/6
column4: [[Ace Books]] listed the author as John Sansom
column5: the pen name of Sangster.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abebooks.com/first-edition/Man-Who-Could-Cheat-Death-Lyndon-Barre/10079019346/bd#&grid=1&pid=1|title=The Man Who Could Cheat Death|last=|first=|date=|website=Abe Books|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>

[[Paramount Pictures]] (US) | released = {{fim date|df=y|1959|11|30}} | runtime = 83 min. | country = England | language = English | budget = [[Pound sterling|GBP]] £84,000 }} '''''The Man Who Could Cheat Death''''' is a 1959 British [[horror film|horror]] film, directed by [[Terence Fisher]] and starring [[Anton Diffring]], [[Hazel Court]] and [[Christopher Lee]]. [[Jimmy Sangster]] adapted the screenplay from the play ''[[The Man in Half Moon Street (play)|The Man in Half Moon Street]]'' by [[Barré Lyndon]], which had been [[The Man in Half Moon Street|previously filmed in 1945]]. ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was produced by [[Michael Carreras]] and [[Anthony Nelson Keys]] for [[Hammer Film Productions]]. It was released in the US on 19 August 1959 and in the UK on 30 November 1959. == Plot == Paris, 1890. Dr Georges Bonnet (Diffring), MD and sculptor, harbours an unusual secret. Although he appears to be in his mid-30s, he is actually 104-years-old, and has kept his youth and vitality through [[Parathyroid gland|parathyroid]] gland transplants every 10 years. But things are going wrong. Prof Ludwig Weiss ([[Arnold Marlé]]) of Vienna, co-discoverer of the anti-ageing process, is three weeks late in arriving at Georges' home to perform the latest transplant. As such, Georges must drink a steaming green liquid to stay young. When Georges' latest model, Margo Philippe ([[Delphi Lawrence]]), comes across Georges swilling the fluid, he strikes her down. Georges has invited a number of people to a reception at which he will unveil his bust of Margo, including Janine Dubois (Court), his former lover, and Dr Pierre Girard (Lee), Janine's current companion. When the 89-year-old Ludwig later arrives, it is quite apparent he will be unable to operate on Georges because a stroke has incapacitated his right hand. Ludwig tells Georges they must find another surgeon. Georges and Ludwig invite Janine and Pierre to dinner. In private, Ludwig convinces Pierre to perform the transplant. However, Janine is still in love with Georges, and when he mysteriously says he must soon leave Paris so he can 'lift the curtain of life and see what lies beyond', Janine asks to accompany him. As the dinner party ends, [[National Police (France)|Surété]] Inspector LeGris ([[Francis de Wolff|Francis De Wolff]]) arrives. He is investigating Margo's disappearance. Georges denies knowing her whereabouts and, when LeGris asks to see the bust of Margo, he tells him that he accidentally destroyed it. LeGris leaves and Georges admits to his startled guests that he lied but says the police would probably damage the bust if he turned it over to them. After Janine and Pierre have left, Ludwig tells Georges that Pierre will operate. But Ludwig has grown suspicious of Georges and says it is strange that Georges' models have gone missing right after Georges' transplants. Ludwig also tells him that after examining the newest parathyroid gland, he can tell Georges has harvested it from a living person, instead of it being 'revitalised' from a corpse. When Ludwig tells him that his actions are unjustified, Georges says sadly that he's done what he's done because he has been left 'utterly alone - again and again' and is tired of having to start a new life every decade. Georges horrifies Ludwig by saying he wants to end his loneliness by having Janine with him forever. The men argue violently, and Georges strangles Ludwig to death. Pierre arrives the following morning to perform the operation, but Georges tells him that Ludwig was unexpectedly called back to Vienna. Pierre refuses to carry on and suggests that Georges find another surgeon. But Georges can find no one who is willing or able, LeGris tells Pierre of the disappearances of three young women at 10 year intervals - in London, San Francisco and Bern, Switzerland - and that each modelled for a sculptor who was an MD and who went missing at the same time. With Margo also missing, LeGris believes Georges is responsible for all the disappearances. Georges takes Janine to a storeroom which holds his sculptures. He proudly shows her the first figurine he made as a boy. The figurine is dated 1798. Janine laughingly says the date must be incorrect because if it weren't, Georges would be 104. Georges abruptly leaves, locking Janine in the storeroom. Georges tells Pierre that he and Ludwig discovered the secret of 'perpetual life' decades earlier. But he can't reveal the secret to the world because if everyone could live forever, paradoxically, everyone would die as there would be no supply of parathyroid glands to keep them alive. Pierre again refuses to perform the transplant, calling it 'an offence against nature [and] and offence against God'. But he relents when Georges threatens Janine's life. Janine finds a now-mad Margo imprisoned in the storeroom. Meanwhile, Pierre fakes the operation - making the incision at Georges' waist but not transplanting the gland. Georges rushes to the storeroom, and as Pierre and LeGris follow, Georges tells Janine that the same operation will allow her to live forever, always young and beautiful and in love. She refuses. Suddenly, Georges begins ageing rapidly and realises that Pierre didn't actually perform the operation. As he exclaims he's dying, Margo, laughing dementedly, throws an oil lamp on him, setting him and the storeroom afire. Pierre and LeGris rescue Janine. Georges and Margo die in the flames. == Cast == ''Credited:'' * [[Anton Diffring]] as Dr. Georges Bonnet * [[Hazel Court]] as Janine Dubois * [[Christopher Lee]] as Dr. Pierre Gerard * [[Arnold Marlé]] as Prof. Ludwig Weiss * [[Delphi Lawrence]] as Margo Phillipe * [[Francis de Wolff]] as Insp. LeGris ''Uncredited:'' * Gerda Larsen as Street Girl * Middleton Woods as Little Man * [[Denis Shaw]] as Tavern Customer * Ian Hewitson as Roger * Frederick Rawlings as Footman * [[Marie Burke]] as Woman * [[Charles Lloyd-Pack|Charles Lloyd-Park]] as Man * John Harrison as Servant * [[Lockwood West]] as 1st Doctor * [[Ronald Adam (actor)|Ronald Adam]] as 2nd Doctor * [[Barry Shawin]] as 3rd Doctor
== Production == The lead role of Bonnet was originally offered to [[Peter Cushing]], who turned it down six days before shooting started. Cushing's reason was that he was completely exhausted 'following the shooting of ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles (1959 film)|The Hound of the Baskervilles]]'' (1959), which had just wrapped up'. The loss of Cushing caused Hammer to threaten legal action against him. However, Cushing had not signed a final contract with Hammer, and nothing could be done,{{Cite book|last=Maxford|first=Howard|title=Hammer Complete: The Films
column3: the Personnel
column4: the Company|publisher=McFarland & Co. Inc.|year=2019|isbn=9781476670072|location=Jefferson NC|pages=531-533}}</ref> although an angry [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]]
column5: which was partly financing and distributing the film
column6: 'relegated to picture to the lower half of double bills in the States'.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite book|last=Fellner|first=Chris|title=The Encyclopedia of Hammer Films|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2019|isbn=9781538126585|location=Lanham MD|pages=273-276}}</ref> The lead went to Diffring
column7: who had played it 18 months earlier in the British ABC-TV adaptation of ''The Man in Half Moon Street''
column8: and episode of the programme ''Hour of Mystery''.<ref name=\":0\" /> ABC was part of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] commercial consortium and broadcast primarily in the Midlands and North of England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.screenonline.org.uk/id/521981/index.html|title=ABC Television|last=Elen|first=Richard G.|date=|website=BFI Screenonline|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=22 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: Filming of ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' took place between 17 November and 30 December 1958 at [[Bray Studios (UK)|Bray Studios]]. Its working title was ''The Man in the Rue Noire''.<ref name=\":1\" />
The European release of the film featured a scene in which Court appeared topless.{{sfn|Hallenbeck|2011|p=104}} She was paid 'an extra £2000 ($5
column2: 600 in 1959 dollars)' for the scene
column3: in which she is posing for a sculpture made by Diffring's character. The stone bust of Janine that is shown repeatedly in the film is in fact 'a plaster cast made from Court's torso'.<ref name=\":1\" /> The scene does not appear in the UK or US prints and the footage is 'unfortunately lost (...) although a photo exists'.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Meikle|first=Denis|title=A History of Horrors: The Rise and Fall of the House of Hammer|last2=Koetting|first2=Christopher T.|publisher=The Scarecrow Press|year=2009|isbn=9780810863538|location=Lanham MD|pages=71-73}}</ref><ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book|last=Carter|first=Robert Michael 'Bobb'|title=The Women of Hammer Horror: A Biographical Dictionary and Filmography|publisher=McFarland & Co. Inc.|year=2013|isbn=9780786472086|location=Jefferson NC|pages=50}}</ref>

column1: A scene in which [[Michael Ripper]] portrayed a morgue attendant was cut from the film's release print.<ref name=\":0\" />

''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was granted an X-certificate by the [[British Board of Film Classification|BBFC]] on 8 April 1959. The X-cert meant that the film could only be exhibited to people age 16 or older. The film was cut in order to get the certificate
column2: which allowed it to be shown in the UK
column3: but the details of what or how much was cut are unknown.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/man-who-could-cheat-death-1959|title=The Man Who Could Cheat Death (1959)|last=|first=|date=|website=British Board of Film Classification|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was distributed in the UK and the US by Paramount.<ref name=\":0\" /> The film was first screened at the London Trade Show on 5 June 1959. It went into general release in the UK on 30 November 1959 as the first film on a double bill with ''[[The Evil That is Eve]]'' (1957). However
column2: the movie was in general release earlier in the US
column3: where it opened on 19 August 1959.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: The film was still being shown in US movie theatres into the 1960s. For example
column2: it was the second film in a triple feature - between ''[[The Black Orchid (film)|The Black Orchid]]'' (1958) and ''Maracaibo'' (1959) - at the Mt Lebanon Drive-In in Lebanon PA on 19 July 1963.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oberver-reporter.com/blogs/driveintimemachine/witches-werewolves-and-a-weasel-at-local-drive-ins-in-the-past/article_0f171790-8aa9-11e8-b0a5-7357ac34e9fc.html|title=Witches
column3: werewolves and a weasel at local drive-ins in the past|last=Channell|first=Justin|date=23 July 2018|website=The Washington PA Observer-Reporter|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=31 March 2020}}</ref> Two years later
column4: the movie continued to be at the bottom of a double bill. On 7 May 1965
column5: it ran as the second film to [[Dr. Terror's House of Horrors|''Dr. Terror's House of Horrors'']] (1965) at three theatres in San Francisco - the New Mission Theatre
column6: the El Rancho Drive-In and the Esquire Theatre - as well as at theatres in the surrounding [[East Bay]] communities of Oakland
column7: Fremont
column8: Hayward and San Leandro.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/32934619/dr-terrors-house-of-horrosthe/|title=The San Francisco Examiner advertisement|last=Clipped by|first=rivamarsh|date=16 June 2019|website=Newspapers.com|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=22 March 2020}}</ref>

column1: For home viewing in the UK
column2: the video was given a 12 certificate by the BBFC on 28 August 2015 for 'limited' but 'moderate injury detail'
column3: which includes scarred faces
column4: rapid ageing
column5: strangulation and death by fire.<ref name=\":2\" /> The first US release of a video of the film was on 21 October 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/82724/Man-Who-Could-Cheat-Death-The/misc-notes.html|title=Man Who Could Cheat Death
column6: The (1959)|last=|first=|date=|website=Turner Classic Movies Data Base|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>

column2: whose scene as a morgue attendant
column3: was cut from the film's release print.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: ''The'' ''Hammer Story: The Authorised History of Hammer Films'' calls the film an \"odd mish-mash of mad scientist sci-fi flick and gothic flannel\" that \"suffers from an excess of dialogue and a lack of action.\"{{sfn|Hearn|Barnes|2007|p=41}}

This assessment is reflected in other contemporary reviews. Film scholar Chris Fellner quotes several: the 20 June 1959 issue of ''[[Harrison's Reports]]'' says that the movie's 'chief drawback' is 'that it is given more to talk than to movement'; ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''<nowiki/>'s issue of 24 June 1959 calls it 'well acted and intelligently conceived. But invention and embellishment in this field appear to have been exhausted'; and the ''[[Motion Picture Exhibitor]]'' issue of 1 July 1959 describes ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' as suffering from 'relying mainly on talk'.<ref name=\":1\" />

The film is referred to by journalist Howard Maxford as a 'commercial and artistic disaster' and a 'bog standard surgical thriller' that is 'by no means a Hammer classic'. He calls Terence Fisher's direction 'curiously unambitious'
column2: characterised by 'many scenes filmed in lengthy
column3: static takes
column4: almost as if from the stalls of a theatre'. Maxford also dislikes the 'Bright
column5: bland lighting' and 'garish Technicolor film stock' which together 'make for some visually tedious and unattractive images'.<ref name=\":0\" />

column2: film scholar Phil Hardy writes that visually the film 'looks like one of Hammer's more lavish productions'
column3: although it is a 'minor item' in Fisher's work. He describes the movie as having a 'perfunctory script'
column4: which makes it a 'rather awkward variation on the [[Dorian Gray (character)|Dorian Gray]] motif'.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book|last=Hardy
column5: ed.|first=Phil|title=The Encyclopedia of Horror Movies|publisher=Harper & Row
column6: Publishers|year=1986|isbn=0060550503|location=NY|pages=115}}</ref>

column1: In the 'Hazel Court' chapter of ''Scream Queens: Heroines of the Horrors''
column2: author Calvin Thomas Beck praises the performances of the three main actors. He writes that Diffring shows 'unique and excellent villainy' and is a 'magnificent heavy who has been shamefully neglected by filmmakers'. Court
column3: he writes
column4: is a 'fine
column5: striking actress at all times' who 'screams and cringes properly' during the movie. He calls ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' one of her 'finest British thrillers'. Beck also notes that Lee 'unexpectedly reversed his monster-villain image' in the film.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Beck|first=Calvin Thomas|title=Scream Queens: Heroines of the Horrors|publisher=Macmillan Publishing Co. Inc.|year=1978|isbn=0025081705|location=NY|pages=280-281}}</ref>

column1: Author 'Bobb' Carter agrees with Beck's view of Court's performance. Carter calls it 'on the whole (...) a solid
column2: impassioned performance that makes it a shame that this was her last role for Hammer'
column3: even though her character
column4: Janine
column5: has the 'distressing trait of not being able to smell something fishy even if there was a whale in the room'.<ref name=\":3\" />

column1: Other critics disagree about the quality of the acting in the film. Maxford calls Diffring's performance 'cold-eyed' and suggests that 'audiences were more used to seeing [him] playing ruthless Nazis'
column2: <ref name=\":0\" /> while Hardy says that 'Lee simply walks through his part'.<ref name=\":4\" />

column1: The screenplay of ''The Man Who Could Cheat Death'' was rewritten as an inexpensive paperback novel in 1959. It was published in the US by [[Avon Books]] and sold for 35¢
column2: with the authors named as 'Barre' Lyndon and Jimmy Sangster. In the UK
column3: where the book sold for 2/6
column4: [[Ace Books]] listed the author as John Sansom
column5: the pen name of Sangster.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abebooks.com/first-edition/Man-Who-Could-Cheat-Death-Lyndon-Barre/10079019346/bd#&grid=1&pid=1|title=The Man Who Could Cheat Death|last=|first=|date=|website=Abe Books|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=19 March 2020}}</ref>
